The purchaser should refer to any applicable provisions of the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province or territory for particulars of these rights or consult with a legal advisor. Pursuant to Section 3A.3 of National Instrument 33-105 _Underwriting Conflicts (“NI 33-105”), the Initial Purchasers are not required to comply with the disclosure requirements of NI 33-105 regarding underwriter conflicts of interest in connection with this offering.
There shall be no invitation to the public in Jersey to apply for any Notes and there shall be no circulation in Jersey of any offer for subscription, sale or exchange of the Notes.

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom (the “U.K.”). For these purposes, a “retail investor” means a person who is one (or more) of the following: (i) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (the “EUWA”); (ii) a customer within the meaning of the provisions of the FSMA and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA; or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in Article 2 of Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the “U.K. Prospectus Regulation”), and the expression an offer includes the communication in any form and by any means of sufficient information on the terms of the offer and the Notes to be offered so as to enable an investor to decide to purchase or subscribe for the Notes. Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the “U.K. PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the U.K. has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the U.K. may be unlawful under the U.K. PRIIPs Regulation. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of the Notes in the U.K. will be made pursuant to an exemption under section 86 of the FSMA from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of Notes. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the U.K. Prospectus Regulation. U.K. product governance / professional client and eligible counterparty only target market** Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer’s product approval process, the target market assessment in the United Kingdom in respect of the Notes described in the Offering Memorandum has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is only eligible counterparties as defined in the Financial Conduct Authority (“FCA”) Handbook Conduct of Business Sourcebook, and professional clients, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA; and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturers’ target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to the FCA Handbook Product Intervention and Product Governance Sourcebook is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either ----- adopting or refining the manufacturers’ target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

The Offering is being made in the United States in reliance upon an exemption from registration under the U.S. Securities Act for an offer and sale of the Notes that does not involve a public offering. In making your purchase, you will be deemed to have made certain acknowledgments, representations and agreements. See “Transfer Restrictions.” This Offering Memorandum is being provided: (1) to a limited number of U.S. investors that the Issuer reasonably believes to be QIBs within the meaning of Rule 144A; and (2) to non-U.S. investors outside the United States in connection with offshore transactions complying with Rule 903 or Rule 904 under Regulation S, in each case for informational use solely in connection with their consideration of the purchase of the Notes. Prospective investors are hereby notified that sellers of the Notes may be relying on the exemption from the registration requirements of Section 5 of the U.S. Securities Act provided by Rule 144A. The Notes may be offered and sold outside the United States in offshore transactions in reliance on Regulation S. Until 40 days after the later of (i) the commencement of this Offering and (ii) the Issue Date of the Notes, an offer or sale of the Notes within the United States by a dealer (whether or not participating in the Offering) may violate the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act if such offer or sale is made otherwise than in accordance with Rule 144A or pursuant to another exemption from or in a transaction not subject to the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. See “Transfer Restrictions.” Terms used in this paragraph have the meanings given to them by Regulation S. The Notes described in the Offering Memorandum have not been registered with, recommended by or approved by the SEC, any state securities commission in the United States or any other securities commission or regulatory authority, nor has the SEC, any state securities commission in the United States or any such securities commission or authority passed upon the accuracy or adequacy of this Offering Memorandum. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offence.

Section Title: THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM CONTAINS IMPORTANT INFORMATION WHICH YOU SHOULD READ BEFORE YOU MAKE ANY DECISION WITH RESPECT TO AN INVESTMENT IN THE NOTES.

Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the securities laws of certain applicable jurisdictions. These forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, all statements other than statements of historical facts contained in this Offering Memorandum, including, without limitation, those regarding our future financial position and results of operations, our strategy, plans, objectives, goals and targets, future developments in the markets in which we participate or are seeking to participate, or anticipated regulatory changes in the markets in which we operate or intend to operate. In some cases, you can identify forward-looking statements by terminology such as “aim,” “anticipate,” “believe,” “continue,” “could,” “estimate,” “expect,” “forecast,” “guidance,” “intend,” “may,” “plan,” “potential,” “predict,” “projected,” “should,” or “will” or the negative of such terms or other comparable terminology. By their nature, forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors because they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. We caution you that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and are based on numerous assumptions and that our actual results of operations, including our financial condition and liquidity and the development of the industry in which we operate, may differ materially from (and be more negative than) those made in, or suggested by, the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, even if our results of operations, including our financial condition and liquidity and the development of the industry in which we operate, are consistent with the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum, those results or developments may not be indicative of results or developments in subsequent periods. Important risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause these differences include, but are not limited to: - the business depending on its ability to continuously source and present a variety and quantity of attractive products from various popular brands at attractive prices that will satisfy our customers’ preferences and demands; - the business facing strong competition in our markets and such competition may intensify further; - consolidation in the online retail fashion industry could have a material adverse effect on the business, financial condition, and results of operations; - negative developments in global and local economic conditions in the markets in which the business operates could adversely impact consumer spending in the fashion market; - the business’s industry and product sales are subject to seasonal fluctuations and unfavorable weather; - if sensitive information about the business’s customers is disclosed, customers may curtail use of the business’s sites, the business may be exposed to liability and the business’s reputation would suffer, and disclosure of the business’s confidential information could adversely affect the business and operations; - the business is exposed to the risk of security breaches, including cyber-attacks, and unauthorized use of one or more of the business’s websites, databases, online security systems or computerized logistics management systems; - any failure to operate, maintain, integrate and scale information technology systems could result in customer dissatisfaction, loss of revenue or subject the business to claims for damages; - customer growth and activity on mobile devices depends upon effective use of mobile operating systems, networks, and standards that the business does not control; - failure of the business to improve delivery systems and infrastructure to meet the technological developments and demands of the business’s growing operations could materially and adversely affect the business, results of operations and financial condition; - the inability to accurately forecast the business could prevent the business from properly planning expenses and process capacity; ii ----- - if the business is unable to manage its inventory, or its online presence and store network in line with customer demand, or if it is unable to otherwise forecast its business accurately, its sales levels and profitability may decline; - the business depends on a reliable and efficient supply chain, which includes fulfillment and returns centers, transport service providers, third-party carriers that deliver merchandise to online customers and stores. Capacity constraints, interruptions or other failures in the business’s supply chain could materially and adversely affect the business, results of operations and financial condition; - the business’s investments to grow its customer base through paid customer acquisition and viral growth and to retain a loyal customer base may not be effective; - operational disruptions at the business’s fulfillment centers could have a material adverse effect on the business, results of operations and financial condition; - if the business is unable to price its products competitively, the business, financial condition and results of operations could be negatively impacted; - the business sources the majority of its merchandise on the basis of purchase orders with its brand partners, and the lack of formal supply agreements could impact the business’s ability to maintain these relationships; - the business is subject to certain risks in connection with the quality and timely delivery of pre-order private label merchandise and relationships with the manufacturers of such merchandise; - the business faces certain risks in relation to its e-commerce business; - the business’s operations may be interrupted or otherwise adversely affected as a result of failures in the business’s IT systems; - failure to secure or preserve the value of the business’s brand partners’ brand equity could negatively impact financial results; - the strategy to continue to expand business in Germany and internationally may fail or advance at a slower pace than planned; - the business may be unable to manage its growing business activities effectively; - the business’s compliance management system and internal controls may not be sufficient to adequately protect the business from all legal or financial risks, especially with regards to business in certain countries where corruption and money laundering may be considered widespread; - the business is subject to numerous laws and regulations with respect to data protection and failure to comply with such laws and regulations may result in litigation and administrative or arbitration proceedings and/or significantly damage relationships with the business’s customers; - the business faces a risk of theft or misappropriation of funds and products in its stores and centralized fulfillment center; - the business’s user metrics and other estimates are subject to inherent challenges in measurement, and inaccuracies in those metrics could have an adverse impact on the business, results of operations, and financial condition; - changes in customer return rates might increase costs and harm the business; - environmental, social and governance matters may impact the business and its reputation; - dissatisfaction with the business’s convenience proposition could negatively affect its customer retention and the implementation of its growth strategy; - the business is exposed to risks associated with the payment options it offers; iii ----- - the business might be exposed to tax risks or tax liabilities resulting from deviating interpretations of applicable tax laws or tax audits or a challenge of the transfer pricing model by the tax authorities; - application of international tax laws on international operations may expose the business to potentially adverse tax consequences; - the business depends on qualified personnel, including certain key personnel such as senior management, as well as external employees, and may not be able to retain or replace such personnel; - the business is exposed to the risk of rising labor costs as well as work stoppages, strikes or other collective actions; - the business faces certain risks in relation to future acquisitions; - the business is subject to a variety of regulations, including but not limited to laws governing data protection, telemedia services, consumer protection, foreign trade and customs, packaging, cyber security as well as competition laws, and future regulations might impose additional requirements and other obligations; - climate change and related regulatory responses as well as customer awareness may adversely impact the business; - third parties might accuse the business of infringing their intellectual property rights; - currency volatility may materially adversely affect the business; - inflation may materially adversely affect the business; - the business may incur liabilities that are not covered by insurance; - many of the business’s suppliers rely on credit insurance to protect their receivables, and any changes to, or slow adjustments or withdrawals of, such credit insurance might cause suppliers to seek to reduce their credit exposure to the business; - the business might be exposed to tax risks or tax liabilities resulting from adverse amendments to current legislation, including developments in the tax treatment of companies engaged in e-commerce in the jurisdictions in which the business operates, that could adversely affect the commercial use of the business’s sites and financial results; - the business’s intangible assets, such as goodwill and trademarks, are subject to the risk of impairment; - the business might be unable to adequately protect its intellectual property rights, including local trademarks and domain names for its sites; - the business may be subject to claims based on unfair commercial practices which could have a material adverse effect on the business, financial condition and results of operations; - conducting business in multiple countries requires the company to comply with numerous, complex, and sometimes conflicting legal and regulatory requirements, which makes compliance more costly and challenging; - the company is exposed to risks related to conducting operations in several different countries; - the business is subject to consumer protection laws and other regulatory requirements which may change, resulting in additional costs; - the company is subject to risks from legal and arbitration proceedings, which may adversely affect financial results and position; - product recalls, product liability claims, and breaches of corporate social responsibility could harm the company’s reputation and business; i ----- - the use of open-source software could increase the risk that hackers could gain unauthorized access to the company’s systems, and the company could be subject to litigation if third parties challenge its rights to use such software on an exclusive basis; - the company is subject to customs and international trade laws that could require it to modify its current business practices and incur increased costs or could result in a delay in getting products through customs and port operations, which may limit growth and cause reputational damage; - the business uses use standardized sales agreements, as well as standardized terms and conditions, and plans to implement standardized purchase and supply agreements, which increase the potential that all contract terms used therein may be invalid or unenforceable if any clause is held to be void; - other risks associated with the Transactions, our financial profile, the Notes, our structure and the financing; and - other factors discussed or referred to in this Offering Memorandum. The risks described in the “Risk Factors” section of this Offering Memorandum are not exhaustive. Other sections of this Offering Memorandum describe additional factors that could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. New risks emerge from time to time and it is not possible for us to predict all such risks; nor can we assess the impact of all such risks on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements. We urge you to read carefully the sections of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Risk Factors,” “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Industry” and “Our Business” for a_ more detailed discussion of the factors that could affect our future performance and the markets in which we operate. In light of these risks, uncertainties and assumptions, the forward-looking events described in this Offering Memorandum may not be accurate or occur at all. Accordingly, you should not place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date on which the statements were made. In addition, from time to time we and our representatives, acting in respect of information provided by us, have made or may make forward-looking statements orally or in writing. These forward-looking statements may be included in, but are not limited to, press releases (including on our website), reports to our security holders and other communications. Although we believe that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, there can be no assurance that such expectations will prove to be correct. We undertake no obligation, and do not intend, to update or revise any forward-looking statements or risk factors, whether as a result of new information, future events or developments or otherwise. All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to us or to persons acting on our behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements referred to above and contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. -----

Unless otherwise indicated or the context requires otherwise in this Offering Memorandum the following terms have the meanings ascribed to them below: - “Active customer” means a customer who has made at least one purchase within the last 12 months; - “Authority” means The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited; - “BestSecret **Group”, “Group”, “we”, “us” or “our” means Issuer and its subsidiaries from time to time; - “CAC” means customer acquisition costs and is defined as the total marketing expenses (excluding personnel-related and re-targeting expenses) divided by total number of new customers. - “CAGR” means compound annual growth rate; - “Co-Investors” has the meaning ascribed to “BestSecret Investors” under “Description of the Notes— _Certain Definitions”;_ - “Collateral” has the meaning ascribed to it under “Summary—The Offering—Security, Enforcement of _Security”;_ - “DACH” means Germany, Austria and Switzerland; - “DTC” means direct to consumer business; - “EU” means the European Union; - “EURIBOR” means the Euro Interbank Offered Rate; - “Euro” or “€” mean the lawful currency of the EU Member States participating in the European Monetary Union; - “Eurozone” means the collective group of member states of the European Union which use the Euro as their common currency; - “Exchange” means The International Stock Exchange; - “Existing Notes Indenture” means the indenture dated December 20, 2016 governing the Existing Notes (until such Existing Notes are redeemed in connection with the Transactions) by and among, inter _alios, the Issuer and Citibank, N.A., London Branch, as trustee._ - “Existing Notes” means the €260,000,000 Senior Secured Notes due 2023 issued by the Issuer on December 20, 2016 and expected to be repaid in full and redeemed as part of the Transactions; - “Existing Revolving Credit Facility” means the super senior revolving credit facility entered into on December 16, 2016, as amended and restated by an amendment and restatement agreement on March 8, 2019 and as further amended by an additional facility notice on April 29, 2022, and as further amended, supplemented and/or restated from time to time; - “Guarantors” means, collectively, Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH; - “HGB” means the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch); i ----- - “Holdco” means Best Secret Group AG (previously PrestigeBidCo Holding GmbH), a stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft) incorporated and existing under the laws of Germany with its registered office at Margaretha-Ley-Ring 27, 85609 Aschheim, Germany, and registered with the commercial register at the local court (Amtsgericht) of Munich under number HRB 273631, which holds the entire share capital of the Issuer; - “IFRS” means the International Financial Reporting Standards, as adopted by the European Union; - “Indenture” means the indenture to be dated the Issue Date governing the Notes by and among, _inter _alios, the Issuer and the Trustee, as amended and/or restated from time to time;_ - “Initial **Purchasers” means Deutsche Bank AG, Goldman Sachs Bank Europe SE, J.P. Morgan SE and UniCredit Bank AG; - “Intercreditor **Agreement” means the intercreditor agreement to be dated on or about the Issue Date, among, _inter alios, Holdco, the Issuer, the original lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Trustee, each original obligor in respect of the New Revolving Credit Facility and the Security Agent, as amended and/or restated from time to time. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”;_ - “Invitation-only membership model” means the closed membership model whereby potential members can only gain membership to our platform through an invitation from an existing member who has earned the right to invite new members or via one of our targeted social media marketing campaigns; - “Issue **Date” means the date on which the Notes offered hereby are issued; - “Issuer” or “Company” means PrestigeBidCo GmbH, a company with limited liability (Gesellschaft _mit beschränkter Haftung) incorporated and existing under the laws of Germany with its registered office_ at Margaretha-Ley-Ring 27, 85609 Aschheim, Germany, and registered with the commercial register at the local court (Amtsgericht) of Munich under number HRB 227078; - “LTV” means lifetime value and is defined as the cumulative PCII per customer since first order; - “Member” means, unless context provides otherwise, an individual who we have approved to purchase merchandise in our online and offline stores; - “New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement” means the new revolving credit facility agreement to be dated on or prior to the Issue Date among, inter alios, the Issuer, as an original borrower and an original guarantor, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, Goldman Sachs Bank Europe SE, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., London Branch and UniCredit Bank AG, as original lenders, as the same may be further amended and/or restated from time to time; - “New Revolving Credit Facility” means the new €110.0 million revolving credit facility made available under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement; - “NMV” means net merchandise value and is calculated as the value of goods sold after actual and anticipated returns and rejections, excluding VAT, regardless of whether it was sold by us or a partner; - “Note **Guarantees” has the meaning ascribed to it under “Summary—The Offering—Note Guarantees”; - “Offering” means the offering of the Notes pursuant to the Offering Memorandum; - “Payback period” is defined as the period, starting from the first order, until cumulative PCII of a customer (i.e. LTV) has reached CAC; - “PCII” is defined as gross profit minus fulfillment, payment and customer care costs; - “Permira” or “Permira Funds” means Permira Advisers LLP or any Permira general partnership managed, controlled or advised by Permira Advisers LLP (or by any other affiliated Permira advisory entity); ii ----- - “Person” means an individual, corporation (including a business trust), company, partnership, joint venture, association, joint stock company, trust (including any beneficiary thereof), unincorporated association or government or any agency or political subdivision thereof; - “Security Agent” means UniCredit Bank AG; - “Security Documents” means the public or private agreements to be entered into between, among others, the Security Agent, the Issuer, the Guarantors and any other grantor, as applicable, pursuant to which security interests over the Collateral will be granted to secure the Notes; - “Sponsor” means the Permira Funds; - “Transactions” means, collectively, (i) the Offering, (ii) the entry into the New Revolving Credit Facility, (iii) the entry into the Security Documents and the Intercreditor Agreement, (iv) the redemption of the Existing Notes, and (v) the payment of fees and expenses; and - “Trustee” means Deutsche Trustee Company Limited, in its capacity as trustee under the Indenture. iii -----

Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The historical financial information included and presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries. In particular, this Offering Memorandum includes and presents: - the English-language translation of the original German-language audited consolidated financial statements of the Issuer as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019 (the “2019 Audited

Subsection Title: Consolidated Financial Statements”), December 31, 2020 (the “2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”) and December 31, 2021 (the “2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”, and together with the 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and the 2020
Subsubsection Text: Audited Consolidated Financial Statements the “Audited **Consolidated Financial Statements”), in each case, including the notes thereto, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and the additional requirements of German commercial law pursuant to Section 315e para. 1 of the HGB; and - the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements of the Issuer as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2022, including the notes thereto (the “Unaudited Condensed Consolidated

Subsection Title: Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the
Subsubsection Title: Change in Accounting Policies and Presentation
Subsubsection Text: In our 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, we reclassified and re-presented certain comparative amounts in the consolidated statement of financial position and the consolidated statement of cash flows, to implement the latest developments on the interpretation of IFRS and to improve presentation of our consolidated financial statements. As a result, certain amounts in the Group’s statement of financial position and cash flow information for the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020 have been taken from the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. For more information see Note 2.4 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the
Subsubsection Title: Twelve Months Ended March 31, 2022 Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 has been calculated by adding the consolidated financial information for the three months ended March 31, 2022 derived from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements to the consolidated financial information for the year ended December 31, 2021 derived from the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and subtracting the consolidated financial information for the three months ended March 31, 2021, derived from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements. The unaudited consolidated financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 has not been audited by any external auditors and is not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for such period any future period or our financial condition at any past or future date and is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting.

Subsection Title: Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial information for the three months ended March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31 for each of the years 2019 and 2020 and for the three months ended, June 30, September 30 and December 31, 2021, (collectively, the “Additional Historical Quarterly Financial Information”), in each case, i ----- has been derived from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial reports of the Issuer as of and for the respective period, which do not represent condensed consolidated interim financial statements that would have been prepared in accordance with IFRS on interim financial reporting (IAS 34). The Additional Historical Quarterly Financial Information has not been audited by any external auditors and is not presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles.

Subsection Title: Interim Financial Statements” and, together with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the
Subsubsection Text: “Consolidated **Financial Statements”) which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS on interim financial reporting (IAS 34). The German-language versions of the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements have been audited by Ernst & Young Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft GmbH (“EY”), in accordance with Section 317 of the HGB, and German generally accepted standards for financial statements audits promulgated by the German Institute of Public Auditors (Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer, IDW). The financial information marked as “audited” in the tables included in this Offering Memorandum is taken from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The financial information marked as “unaudited” in the tables included in this Offering Memorandum is taken from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements and our internal accounting systems or is based on calculations of figures from the abovementioned sources.

This Offering Memorandum contains non-IFRS financial measures and ratios, including EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Capital Expenditure, Operating Net Working Capital, Operating Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion and certain leverage and coverage ratios, among others, that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. Our non-IFRS financial measures are defined by us as set out below. We define “EBITDA” as net income/(net loss) for the period before income taxes, financial income, financial expenses, depreciation, amortization and impairment losses and the reversal of impairment losses, each as shown in the Consolidated Financial Statements. We define “Adjusted EBITDA” as EBITDA adjusted for restructuring and reorganization costs, new store opening, extension store/fulfillment center and improvement expenses, introduction/improvement of tools and processes expenses and COVID-19 pandemic/geopolitical tensions related expenses. We define “Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue. There is no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. We define “Capital Expenditure” as the sum of: (i) purchase of property, plant and equipment, (ii) purchase of intangible assets and (iii) capitalized development costs each as shown in the consolidated statements of cash flows in the Consolidated Financial Statements. We define “Operating **Net Working Capital” as the sum of (i) inventories and prepayments for inventories, (ii) trade and other receivables, (iii) trade and other payables and (iv) others. ‘Others’ includes refund liabilities and assets for the right to recover possession of goods for expected returns. We define “Operating Free Cash Flow” as EBITDA plus the changes in net foreign exchange differences, increase/decrease in other liabilities and provisions, decrease/increase in other assets, decrease/increase in trade and other receivables, decrease/increase in inventories and similar assets, increase/decrease in trade payables and other liabilities each as shown in net cash flows from operating activities (changes in current assets, non-current financial assets, current and non-current liabilities presented in net cash flows from operating activities), minus payment of lease liabilities as shown in net cash flows from financing activities and minus Capital Expenditure. We define “Cash Conversion” as the ratio between Operating Free Cash Flow and Adjusted EBITDA. For a reconciliation of our net income/net loss for the period to EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as well as a reconciliation of Operating Free Cash Flow and Cash Conversion, see “Summary Consolidated Financial and _Other Information.” For a reconciliation and description of Capital Expenditure and Operating Net Working_ Capital, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.” We present non-IFRS financial measures because we believe that they are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. The non-IFRS financial measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and should not be considered in isolation or be used as a substitute for an analysis of our operating result as reported under IFRS. There can be no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. Non-IFRS financial measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to net income/ net loss for the period or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. The non-IFRS financial measures may not give an accurate or complete picture of our financial condition or results of operations for the periods presented and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. The non-IFRS financial measures have limitations as analytical tools. Some of these limitations are: ----- - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or principal payments, on our debts; - although amortization, depreciation and write-downs are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and certain of these non-IFRS financial measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements; and - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as used in this Offering Memorandum are not calculated in the same manner as “Consolidated EBITDA” is calculated pursuant to the Indenture governing the Notes as described under “Description of the Notes” or for purposes of any of our other indebtedness.

Certain key performance indicators and other non-financial operating data, such as indexed customer growth figures and cohort figures, included in this Offering Memorandum are derived from management estimates, are not part of our Consolidated Financial Statements or financial accounting records, and have not been audited by outside auditors, consultants or experts. Our use or computation of this data may not be comparable to the use or computation of similarly titled measures reported by other companies. Any or all of this data should not be considered in isolation or as an alternative measure of performance under IFRS.

Certain numerical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial information presented in millions or thousands and percentages describing market shares, have been rounded according to established commercial standards and, as a result, rounded figures in the tables below may not add up to the aggregate amounts in such tables (sum totals or subtotals), which are calculated based on unrounded figures. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other information set forth in “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” are calculated using the rounded_ numerical data included in this Offering Memorandum and not the numerical data in each of the Consolidated Financial Statements or Issuer’s internal accounting systems. With respect to financial information set out in this Offering Memorandum, a dash (“—”) signifies that the relevant figure is not available, while a zero (“0.0”) signifies that the relevant figure is available but is or has been rounded to zero. The financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to comply with the applicable accounting requirements of the Securities Act and the related rules and regulations of the SEC which would apply if the Notes were being registered with the SEC. i -----

In this Offering Memorandum, all references to “euro,” “EUR” and “€” are to the single currency of the participating member states of the European Monetary Union of the Treaty Establishing the European Community, as amended from time to time. All references to “U.S. dollars” and “$” are to the lawful currency of the United States of America.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the off-price market with a focus on mid-market to luxury fashion in Europe. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio of around 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a discreet and controlled channel and protecting their brand equity. With a heritage going back nearly 100 years, we have evolved from an offline retail business to a tech-driven online platform. We offer a wide range of midmarket to luxury fashion brands at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80%, providing a permanent assortment of approximately 250,000 items at any moment in time. Our online offering is available in multiple languages and in 27 European countries. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €996.3 million, an Adjusted EBITDA of €131.4 million and an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.2%. Our online revenue, which accounted for 91.7% of total revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, grew at a CAGR of 41.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022. While 70.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 was generated in Germany, our international business outside of Germany continues to gain in importance relative to our Germany business and experienced strong revenue growth of 86.3% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 (with a CAGR of 62.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022).

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Our business operates successfully in a large and resilient market with long-term growth supported by structural tailwinds
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the European online fashion market (excluding Russia and the United Kingdom) for mid-market to luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season sectors. By targeting the online off-price sector, we are well-positioned to take advantage of three structural long-term trends in the fashion sector: (1) disproportional demand growth in the off-price market, expected to grow at 5% per year from 2021-2025, (2) a shift to more premium fashion, with the mid-market to luxury fashion market expected to grow at 4% per year from 2021-2025 and (3) rising online penetration in the European fashion market, expected to grow at 9% per year from 2021-2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). The growing importance of sustainability for consumers and brands makes the off-price sector an increasingly attractive choice for brands, as it allows for overstock, a structural phenomenon in the fashion industry, to be monetized in a sustainable manner, at discounted prices to consumers and thus avoiding the destruction or disposal of such overstock in landfills. Our closed-membership model offers brands the additional value of discreet overstock clearing at scale and we believe it presents a unique business opportunity to build upon the growing importance of sustainability. As a result of the above factors, and as illustrated in the chart below, the online off-price sector amounted to €44 billion in revenue across Europe (excluding the U.K. and Russia) in 2021, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 12% from 2021 to 2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). 1 ----- (1) All market sizes refer to 2021 and continental Europe, excl. UK and Russia. (2) Market segments excluded: discount, value, pinnacle. (3) Off-price and discounted in-season or end-of season-fashion market for mid-market to luxury fashion. (4) Online, off-price and discounted in-season or end-of season-fashion market for mid-market to luxury fashion. Source: A leading international consulting firm; Company Analysis

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: The most powerful flywheel in online fashion
Subsubsection Text: The “flywheel” that drives our growth and profitability is the result of several strong elements that feed into one another and that accelerate our viral engine. First, we develop strong brand relationships as a result of our closed and discreet model that allows us to “silently” clear our brand partners’ overstock at scale. Second, based on our strong brand relationships we are able to offer our members a current and attractive assortment of highly desirable brands at discounts ranging from 20% to 80%. Third, we believe this in turn, leads to our members preferring to shop with us, as reflected by exceptional customer key performance indicators (“KPIs”). In combination, these three favorable elements lead to a continuous acceleration of our “viral engine” in which existing members make use of their invitation rights to invite their families and friends. As a consequence, the “flywheel” has generated low double-digit top line growth every year, thereby attracting new brand partners and reinforcing relationships with existing brand partners. Our viral engine has contributed to an exponential growth engine as illustrated in the chart below. (1) Online revenue evolution prior to introduction of performance marketing in 2021. Financials from 2017 to 2020 in accordance with IFRS, German GAAP prior to 2017. 2) 2021. Online only. 3) Based on survey results in the DACH region (n = 1,059 respondents). Share of respondents stating “I like BestSecret and I want my friends and family to be able to get to know it, too”. Question: “What is your main motivation to invite family and friends to join BestSecret”. Source: Company To complement our “viral engine”, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter of 2021. Paid marketing efforts allow us to invite potential new members in a targeted manner to join our closed membership model who can then make use of their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral 2 ----- engine. Paid marketing efforts drive our non-viral growth, especially in areas with currently low penetration (such as international markets). See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition” and “Our Business— Marketing—Paid customer acquisition.” Our brand partners_ Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model enables brands to discreetly clear large volumes of overstock in a premium environment entirely separate from their full-price channels. Discretion is increasingly important to brands, as overstock potentially threatens brand equity when sold openly, because the high degree of price visibility in online shopping allows customers to view full-price and discounted offerings side-by-side. We recently introduced a marketplace as part of our online platform to provide our brand partners the option to market their products within our ecosystem without us having to hold these products in our own inventory. We believe that the marketplace model will strengthen the relationship with our brand partners as it allows them to increase their direct to customer (or “DTC”) revenue through our online platform while maintaining price control. We offer brand partners to clear their overstock within a closed ecosystem. This also provides our brand partners comfort that their merchandise is not being re-sold through the grey market (i.e., channels that our brand partners have not authorized) or other channels that could harm their brand image. Thus, our discreet model protects their brand equity and fosters our long-term and deep strategic partnerships leading to direct relationships with around 95% of all our brand partners, thereby avoiding intermediaries. Our model has also resulted in high brand partner retention: we have retained all of our top 50 brand partners from 2017 (excluding intermediaries, private label suppliers and suppliers who went out of business). These strong relationships allow us to offer attractive products at desirable prices, which in turn, allow us to provide our brand partners with access to an affluent and loyal customer base. _Our products, prices and services_ Our superior brand proposition in turn leads to our ability to offer highly desirable products at attractive prices to our customers and provide them with a service experience matching that of full-price online platforms. Our brand proposition and the resulting strong relationships ensure that we are able to secure an attractive brand portfolio of around 3,000 brands, comprising approximately 250,000 articles at any given time. Unlike almost all other online platforms in the off-price segment, our offered assortment is broad and available permanently: we do not rely on flash sales campaigns with long delivery times. Furthermore, our customers benefit from a fresh assortment: the majority of our inventory has been listed on our online platform for less than six months. This desirable assortment is complemented by attractive discounts of 20% to 80% on every single article and a fast delivery time of approximately 3 days on average in 2021. Our online platform is accessible to our customers through our highly rated app and website which offers a highend shopping and service experience on par with leading online full-price platforms, resulting in high customer satisfaction and an excellent net promoter score (“NPS”) of approximately 60 at the end of 2021. As the fashion market and its consumers increasingly make sustainability a driver of their purchasing decisions, we expect that they will increasingly turn to us for their fashion needs, as our model allows customers a chance to shop fashion in one of the most sustainable ways by giving them access to overstock and ensuring that every piece of fashion that is produced is worn. _Our customers_ Our desirable products, prices and service in turn attract a customer base that is active, loyal, and earns above average disposable income. Driven by our broad offering and incentivized by our attractive loyalty scheme, our customer base has been growing steadily. Our number of active customers was approximately 1.2 million, 1.5 million and 2.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, and 2.5 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, representing a CAGR of 38% between 2019 and 2021. Revenue by customer cohort, grouped by year, or customers who joined in a given year, typically stays stable during the first year of membership. For example, online revenue from our active customers from the years 2018, 2019 and 2020 changed in the respective subsequent years to 99% (2019), 96% (2020) and 118% (2021). Our strong revenue retention track record is further illustrated by the following revenue by cohort chart: 3 ----- (1) Revenue retention is defined as online revenue (NMV after returns incl. shipping income, but excluding cut-off effects and commission) of existing customers divided by revenue of previous year. ‘Existing customers’ defined as customers with first order in previous year. Source: Company. We believe our value proposition caters to a highly attractive customer demographic, especially to affluent consumers, which drives our strong revenue retention rate, that has increased from 100% to 118% in the period between the year ended December 31, 2018 and the year ended December 31, 2021. Spend in the fashion industry is heavily skewed toward the most affluent consumer demographic: in Germany for instance, 70% of total fashion spending is made by 30% of the consumers (source: a leading international consultancy firm). These affluent consumers spend more than €1,000 per year on fashion. The off-price market is inherently attractive to affluent consumers. These consumers’ spend is approximately 2.5x more than the average consumer on fashion overall, and 2.4x more in premium, 2.7x more in affordable luxury and 2.9x more in luxury, when compared to the market average (source: a leading international consultancy firm). _Viral engine_ Our “viral engine” is a self-reinforcing model in which existing members invite their friends, colleagues or other acquaintances, thus creating multiple new customers. These new members then repeat the cycle, allowing a single original customer to lead to substantial growth over time. New “viral customers” are the primary drivers of our year-on-year structural revenue growth and an important driver for our expansion. Our viral engine resulted in our online business revenue growing at a CAGR of 22% from 2016 to 2020, after which time we introduced our paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter of 2021. Moreover, the viral engine is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue being spent annually to incentivize customers to invite other customers. The overall effect of this viral model is substantial, with four new active customers generated by ten active customers in 2021.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Our proprietary technology platform supports our growing business
Subsubsection Text: We are investing, on an ongoing basis, in building what we believe to be a world-class technology organization to support our growing online platform. To provide for an engaging online storefront, we have designed attractive websites and one of the best-rated online fashion apps (4.8* average app rating), which we regularly update to match the high expectations of our customer base and the experience offered by full-price platforms. Our customers enjoy access to a multi-device shopping experience from their mobile phones, tablets and desktop computers that we believe allows for a convenient and frictionless shopping experience. Our technology supports all major online and mobile platforms, including dedicated iOS and Android applications for both smartphones and tablets. We program, develop and maintain our apps and website in-house, and we frequently update our applications to offer new features. Over the past few years, we have developed sophisticated IT systems which support our apps and websites, customer service, supplier connectivity, communications and the monitoring of customer sales and improved management of inventories. To support this effort, in addition to tech investments in our online platform, we have 4 ----- built a tech driven value chain that integrates tech into our online and offline operations (including for our supply, demand and onsite teams). To facilitate continued growth and build up our tech capacity in our operations, we are expanding our tech hubs in Germany and Spain. A significant number of our FTEs relative to our overall business are in tech-based roles (36% in tech, with tech and data headcount having grown more than 80% in 2021). We believe that we operate a state-of-the-art cloud-based data infrastructure, which allows key business data to be readily accessible across our business units to ensure faster, more data-driven decision making. Data analysts, data scientists and data engineers are embedded across all business units, ensuring that the data we produce and analyze is put to its best use. We have aimed to make technology and data a driver of each and every part of our business by eschewing a dedicated IT department and instead embedding technology and data teams within all of our business units.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Our operations are enabled for growth
Subsubsection Text: To ensure customer satisfaction, we aim to make online off-price fashion shopping as convenient as with fullprice online players along the entire customer journey. From the initial browsing session to the customer receiving their new products at their home, to providing any support that the customer may need along the way. This has resulted in our online orders increasing by 29% and user sessions increasing by 37%, in each case, in the three months ended March 31, 2022 as compared to the same period in 2021. Our browsing sessions generally averages 7 minutes and 29 seconds per customer, with 84% of our browsing sessions in the three months ended March 31, 2022 being mobile share. Our operational platform includes (1) a highly developed content management system that quickly and efficiently develops all our online content according to our content guidelines, (2) our extensive array of payment methods, (3) our expansive logistics operation, with a modern fulfillment center in Poing, Germany and a second large fulfillment center currently under development and (4) a highly trained customer service team that steps in whenever a customer has a question or a problem – both pre- and post- order. In 2021, we simultaneously improved and scaled our operational platform. We improved our on-time delivery rate for our top customers, decreased the time-to-online for our merchandise and reduced the contact rate in customer service, while shipping significantly more orders than in 2020.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model with strong growth trajectory, adjusted EBITDA margins and high Cash Conversion
Subsubsection Text: Our business has delivered a consistent track-record of highly profitable growth and Cash Conversion, strongly outperforming the market. In 2021 we recorded revenue of €942.9 million, which represents an overall CAGR of 28.5% from 2019 to 2021 and again outperformed the wider fashion and our off-price market segment as illustrated in the chart below. Source: Company. Our online business is the strongest driver of our performance and its revenue CAGR was 41% in the period from 2019 to 2021. This strong growth momentum in 2021 was ahead of listed online fashion companies such as Zalando and Mytheresa, which saw revenue growth rates of 26.4% and 27.4% respectively from 2019 to 2021. 5 ----- Our revenue growth acceleration has been complemented by our strong Adjusted EBITDA margin. In the year ended December 31, 2021, our Adjusted EBITDA was €138.7 million and the Adjusted EBITDA CAGR was 18% in the period from 2019 to 2021. We are able to convert our profitable growth into attractive cash flows due to our high profitability, efficient working capital management and the limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements of our business model. For the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, our total capital expenditures were 6.4%, 5.5% and 3.0% of revenue, respectively, and Cash Conversions for these periods were 47.9%, 66.1% and 51.1%, respectively. In the first three months ended March 31, 2022, our cash flow development reflected temporarily increased investments in growth projects and inventory, as illustrated in the charts below, due to growing business volume. We have further demonstrated our fundamental resilience throughout the COVID-19 pandemic as illustrated by the following charts of the Group’s revenue year-on-year growth including strong Group revenue growth, Adjusted EBITDA margin levels and Operating Net Working Capital. Source: Company. Source: Company. 6 ----- (1) Trade receivables including cash in transit Source: Company We also believe that the segment of the market in which we operate exhibits attractive resilience from a supply and demand perspective through the economic cycle, it offers an attractive opportunity for consumers to spend less for highly branded fashion items in an economic downturn, in which brand partners are under pressure to sell overstock. Selling mid-market to luxury brands, we cater to a high income customer demographic that is less sensitive to the effect of economic downturns.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Strong leadership team with proven track record
Subsubsection Text: Our leadership team is headed by Dr. Moritz Hahn who joined the Company after nine years of experience in various senior roles at Zalando SE. Dr. Hahn has since focused on recruiting a diverse and experienced leadership team that combines entrepreneurial spirit with longstanding industry expertise and a strong commitment to our vision. In the past year, we have grown our senior leadership team including with the addition of our COO, Dr. Andreas Reichhart, our Chief Technology Officer, Ramy Kamel and our SVP People & Organization, Annelot Fluitman. Further, on May 30, 2022, the Group announced the appointment of Axel Salzmann as new Chief Financial Officer of HoldCo, effective July 4, 2022. He follows outgoing Chief Financial Officer Claudius Peleskei. Together, our experienced leadership team has extensive experience in relevant areas. They are supported by an extensive team of professionals working in a variety of specializations who we believe are well-positioned to manage our growing business. We expect that our experienced and entrepreneurial management team will continue to achieve attractive growth for our shareholders while increasing profitability for our expanding business.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our business is characterized by a number of key strengths that set it apart from our competitors:

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Driving customer growth with paid customer acquisition
Subsubsection Text: To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the second quarter of 2021. Paid marketing efforts help us to invite potential new members who will act as new base for future viral growth in underpenetrated regions where we want to grow the most. These new members will drive our future viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral engine. Paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer demographics and regions to drive our non-viral growth in areas in which we have currently a low customer penetration (such as Northern Germany and international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly favorable marketing efficiency ratio (defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy divided by marketing spend) and has maintained short payback periods while scaling marketing investment. Moreover, our paid marketing strategy is closely aligned with our brand partners. As illustrated in the chart below, we have experienced strong profitability as the roll-out of performance marketing continues. 7 ----- Note: New segment reporting started in 2021. Adjusted operating expenses in the chart above have been presented adjusted to exclude exceptional items and depreciation and amortization. Source: Company. As a result of these successful performance marketing efforts, we expect our viral engine to further accelerate and continue to drive sustained growth while always focusing on maximum brand protection. See “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition” and “Our Business—Marketing—Paid customer acquisition._

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the highly attractive and growing dedicated online off-price sector and discounted in-season and end-of-season sector in Europe. Our international expansion has increasingly diversified our geographic revenue streams, with the proportion of revenue derived outside our home market Germany steadily increasing in recent years. In 2021, almost one-third of our revenue was generated in our international markets. Our unique proposition provides us with the opportunity to continuously capture market share and participate in the structural growth momentum of our market. We believe that we have developed a proven expansion strategy that will allow us to expand into new international markets and increase penetration in our existing markets: (1) targeting and prioritizing future growth markets, (2) localizing our offering for specific markets, (3) using performance marketing campaigns to establish a customer base and (4) achieving viral customer acquisition that leads to selfreinforcing growth.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Establishing the leading European off-price marketplace
Subsubsection Text: In 2021, we introduced a new marketplace model. Through our marketplace model, we offer our brand partners to market their products on our BestSecret online platform without having BestSecret to hold these products as own inventory. The marketplace model will allow our brand partners to increase their DTC revenue through our online platform. We expect to achieve full scale operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022. Through the expansion of our marketplace offering, we aim to expand our assortment through acquiring new brand partners in the luxury segment and further grow the end of season fashion segment on BestSecret. We view the marketplace as a unique growth opportunity. There are no existing online off-price marketplaces at scale in the sector and we aim to become the number one fashion marketplace for off-price fashion in Europe. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting _our Results of Operations—Marketplace.”_

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Title: Taking advantage of the consolidation trend
Subsubsection Text: The dedicated online off-price sector in Germany, our core region, is expected to undergo significant consolidation through 2025, when the top five market participants are expected to command 68% of the market. This consolidation is predicted to be driven by brands reducing the number of their distribution partners, the increasing 8 ----- professionalization of the online space and economies of scale pushing out smaller participants (source: a leading international consultancy firm). As a leading player in the dedicated online off-price market in Germany, Austria and Switzerland, we are in a strong position to take advantage of the consolidation trend within the European market. Our scale, our highly professionalized operations and our value proposition to clear overstock in a discrete manner underline our advantageous position towards brands. With the aim of further benefitting from the consolidation trend, we will continue to invest in increasingly scaling our business and advancing our offering.
