Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: _The unaudited preliminary financial results for the periods presented below are derived from our accounting records. This information has neither been audited, verified or subject to any procedures by any external auditors nor has it been approved by our Board of Directors. Accordingly, you should not place undue reliance on such unaudited preliminary financial results, and no opinion or any other form of assurance is provided with respect thereto. Our preliminary unaudited financial results are based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to review, change and adjustment in the course of preparation of our consolidated financial statements, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the periods presented. Although we believe the management estimates and unaudited preliminary financial information and the assumptions on which they are based to be reasonable, our preliminary financial results are subject to change, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the six months ended June 30, 2022. In addition, we have included certain forward looking statements with respect to our expectations for revenue and Adjusted EBITDA for the year ending December 31, 2022, which are subject to the same limitations outlined above. The assumptions related to our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA performance for the year ending December 31, 2022 (our “guidance”) include our expectation that overstock availability will increase, that the seasonality patterns we have observed historically will be reflected in our sales during the year ending December 31, 2022, that viral growth engine and our paid customer acquisition activities will be effective and that the measures we have taken to align our cost profile with our growth profile will be effective. Furthermore, if our assumptions upon which we have based our guidance prove to be inaccurate, this may result in lower than expected revenue and Adjusted EBITDA during the year ending December 31, 2022 or a less favorable position of the Group in the market, which may in turn have a negative impact on our business, financial condition, results of operation and prospects. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” for a discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance and results of operation._ We recorded preliminary revenue growth of approximately 20% for the six months ended June 30, 2022 compared to €397.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021. This increase was achieved despite a high comparison base, a challenging market environment characterized by reduced overstock availability and lower consumer sentiment due to inflationary pressures. Compared to the pre-COVID period in the six months ended June 30, 2019 in which we recorded revenues of €244.4 million, we expect to have achieved a revenue CAGR of approximately 25% in the six months ended June 30, 2022. Our Adjusted EBITDA margin for the six months ended June 30, 2022 is anticipated to have followed the same seasonality as the pre-COVID years of 2019 and earlier, when the Adjusted EBITDA margin in the six month period was around two to three percentage points below that of the full year. This seasonality is typical for any regular business year due to the volume and margin difference between the spring/summer and autumn/winter seasons. The anticipated margin also reflects the increase of our paid customer acquisition activities during the six months ended June 30, 2022, which represents one of the key pillars of our strategy to drive growth in underpenetrated regions and markets. Our cash and cash equivalents stood at €82.5 million as of June 30, 2022 (March 31, 2022: €68.1 million; June 30, 2021: €69.2 million restated). The Existing Revolving Credit Facility, which has a total size of €110 million, was undrawn as of June 30, 2022. The leverage ratio, which is calculated as net financial debt to LTM Adjusted EBITDA, is expected to be at a similar level as the 2.4x as at March 31, 2022 (June 30, 2021: 2.2x). For the year ending December 31, 2022, compared to the year ended December 31, 2021, management expects an increase in revenue in the low 20s percent range and an Adjusted EBITDA growth by at least a high single 9 ----- digit rate. Based on management estimates, 2022 is thus expected to be another year in which we will further expand our leading position for online off-price fashion in Europe.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: BestSecret draws on a heritage of nearly 100 years in the textile industry. In 1924, Herman Schustermann founded a textile company in Makredwitz, Germany and relocated to Munich in the late 1940s. In the early 1950s, Benno Borenstein established his textile business in Munich. The two companies merged in 1960, and, after the death of Herman Schustermann, a new cooperation was established with Herman’s son, Emil Schustermann, and Benno Borenstein as partners. While Schustermann & Borenstein initially started out as a combination of two textile trading companies with regional customer bases around Munich, ready-to-wear clothes were added to the portfolio over the next decades and the closed membership retail business model was born. Prior to 2007, our business operations were limited to our Schustermann & Borenstein offline retail stores in Munich. In 2007, we launched our BestSecret online platform. In 2011, we made the BestSecret online platform available in the Austrian market, setting the first milestone for our international expansion strategy. Since then, we have continued our online expansion with the launch of our online presence in Sweden (2015), Switzerland (2015), France (2016), The Netherlands (2018) and, most recently, Belgium (2021) and Poland (2022). Today, our multi-language online platform is available across Europe with shipping available to 27 countries. We have continued to maintain a limited physical presence with premium and outlet stores in strategic locations, with such locations designed primarily to support our online platform. In 2012, the BestSecret Group’s founding families sold a majority stake of 61% of the business to Ardian. In 2014, construction commenced on the new centralized fulfillment center in Poing, Germany (near Munich), which became operational in early 2016 and consolidated our then-existing seven warehouses. In 2014, we expanded our offline retail footprint through the opening of a new store in Vienna, Austria. In 2016, we acquired Swiss Online Shopping AG, a leading off-price player in Switzerland, to further expand our online presence in Germany, Austria and Switzerland (hereafter referred to as the DACH region). In January 2017, funds owned and managed by Permira acquired a majority stake in the Group. In 2019 and 2020, we expanded our fulfillment center in Poing, Germany by approximately 60% to support our business growth. In late 2020, Dr. Moritz Hahn joined us after nine years of experience at Zalando SE where he served as a member of the Executive Committee and held numerous senior positions. He has since built a strong leadership team of ecommerce pioneers with decades of relevant experience across the tech and e-commerce industry, complemented by senior individuals with long-term experience at and in-depth knowledge of the Company. In early 2021, this senior leadership team announced the new vision “to become the number one online destination for off-price fashion in Europe.” The accompanying strategy is focused on online pure-play, profitable growth across Europe. The offline strategy was sharpened to focus on supporting our online value proposition with premium stores designed to elevate our brand image and outlet stores to clear inventory that fails to sell online. In 2021, the structure and brand profile across the Group was simplified and harmonized, merging and renaming the companies to solely feature the BestSecret name across the Group.

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: Permira is a global investment firm that backs successful businesses with growth ambitions. Founded in 1985, the firm advises funds with total assets under management of more than €60 billion and makes long-term majority and minority investments. The Permira Funds have made approximately 300 private equity investments in four key sectors: technology, consumer, healthcare and services. Permira employs over 450 people in 16 offices across Europe, North America, and Asia. The Permira Funds have invested in various businesses in the DACH region, such as Engel & Völkers, Neruaxpharm, P&I and TeamViewer. The Permira Funds also have extensive expertise in the premium and luxury fashion space and in-depth knowledge of dealing with global brands, including Hugo Boss, Valentino, Golden Goose and Dr. Martens. 10 -----

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the markets in which we operate and compete. These references represent our best estimates at the time of this Offering Memorandum and are based on management’s knowledge of the industry and the market data and other statistical information obtained from a variety of other public sources including, but not limited to independent industry publications, statistics from governmental agencies (“Company Analysis”). Certain market share information and other statements presented herein as Company Analysis regarding our position relative to our competitors are not based on published statistical data or information obtained from independent third parties, but reflects our best estimates. We have based these estimates upon publicly available information about our competitors as well as information obtained from our clients, trade and business organizations and associations and other contacts in our industry. In addition to our Company Analysis, certain market information contained in this Offering Memorandum is derived from reports by market research firms., including industry and market reports by independent international consultancy firms including publicly available reports prepared by McKinsey & Company (“a leading international consultancy firm”). Industry publications, surveys and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. While we believe that these industry publications, surveys and forecasts are reliable, we have not independently verified them and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. While we accept responsibility for accurately summarizing the information from these external sources, and as far as we are aware and able to ascertain no facts have been omitted which would render this information inaccurate or misleading, we accept no further responsibility in respect of such information. Certain information in this Offering Memorandum, including, without limitation, statements regarding the industry in which we operate, our position in the industry, our market share and the market shares of various industry participants are based on our internal estimates and analyses and based in part on third-party sources. These estimates have been derived from management’s knowledge and experience in the markets in which we operate, as well as information obtained from public third party industry reports and from our customers, distributors, suppliers, trade and business organizations and other contacts in the markets in which we operate. We also provide certain estimates of the growth of markets and certain other projections related to our industry. This information is inherently speculative and subject to risk. Because such data is often incomplete, multiple sources are typically triangulated to develop consensus estimates. Market data and statistics, including information regarding penetration rates and growth, volume and growth and other information about particular regions or markets, are inherently predictive and speculative and are not necessarily reflective of actual market conditions. Such statistics are generally based on market research, which itself is based on sampling and subjective judgments by both the researchers and the respondents. In addition, the value of comparisons of statistics of different markets is typically limited by many factors, including that (i) the underlying information was gathered by different methods with varying levels of access and information available in different markets and (ii) different assumptions were applied in compiling the data. Market studies are frequently based on information and assumptions that may not be exact and their methodology is by their nature forward-looking and speculative. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that our estimates or any of the assumptions underlying our estimates are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the industry. None of our internal surveys or information has been verified by any independent sources. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of this information. All of the information set forth in this Offering Memorandum relating to the operations, financial results or market share of our competitors has been obtained from publicly available information or independent research. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified this information and cannot guarantee its accuracy. Certain market share information and other statements presented herein regarding our position relative to our competitors are not based on published statistical data or information obtained from independent third parties, but reflects our best estimates. We have based these estimates upon information obtained from our clients, trade and business organizations and associations and other contacts in our industry. Furthermore, certain forward-looking statements contained in such industry and certain market data may not fully include the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, geopolitical tensions relating to Ukraine conflict, or other related developments, including the impacts of future national or local lockdowns or other measures implemented by national and/or local authorities. There can be no assurance that such forward-looking statements would not have been materially different if such developments related to the COVID-19 pandemic or the impact resulting from ii ----- the conflict in Ukraine had been taken into account. See “Forward-looking Statements.” Further, please be aware that data and statistical information in this Offering Memorandum, may differ from estimates made by our competitors or from information found in current or future studies conducted by market research institutes, consultancy firms or independent sources. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding the industry or similar data presented herein, such data involves risks, assumptions and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under the heading “Risk Factors.” iii -----

Section Title: CORPORATE STRUCTURE AND CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: _The following chart shows a simplified summary of our corporate and financing structure as of the date of this Offering Memorandum adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. All entities shown below are 100% wholly owned unless otherwise indicated. The chart does not include all of our parent companies or subsidiaries, or all the debt obligations thereof. For a summary of the debt obligations identified in this diagram, please refer to the sections entitled “Description of the Notes,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Capitalization.”_ (1) Permira Funds has beneficial ownership, indirectly through intermediate holding companies, of the share capital of the Issuer (excluding any shares held indirectly by the Co-Investors). For a description of our principal shareholders, see “Principal Shareholders.” (2) Our management and members of the founding families (some of whom are also members of management) hold voting rights (excluding the management equity participation plan) in PTGMidco S.à r.l. For a description of our principal shareholders, see “Principal _Shareholders.”_ (3) The Issuer will use the proceeds from the issuance of the Notes (i) to repay and redeem the Existing Notes and satisfy and discharge the Existing Indenture, and (ii) to pay certain fees and expenses in relation to the Transactions. (4) The Notes will be general, senior obligations of the Issuer and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including indebtedness incurred under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, certain cash management obligations, if any, and certain hedging obligations, if any; (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, if any; (iii) be secured by the Collateral as set forth under “Description of the Notes—Security”; (iv) be guaranteed by the Guarantors as described under “Description of the Notes—Brief Description of the Notes and the Note Guarantees—The Note _Guarantees”; (v) be structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations of any of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not_ guarantee the Notes; and (vi) be effectively subordinated to any existing and future secured obligations of the Issuer that are secured by liens over property and assets that do not secure the Notes to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations. (5) We expect to enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement on or prior to the Issue Date, which provides for up to €110.0 million of senior secured credit borrowings. The New Revolving Credit Facility is secured by first ranking security interests over the Collateral, which will also secure the Notes and the Note Guarantees. We expect the New Revolving Credit Facility to be undrawn on the Issue Date (other than in respect of a potential rollover of any existing ancillary facilities under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility into the New Revolving Credit Facility). On the Issue Date, the New Revolving Credit Facility will, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, be secured on an equal and ratable basis with the Notes and certain hedging obligations by the Collateral. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.” 11 ----- (6) For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, the unaudited aggregated unconsolidated EBITDA of the Guarantors represented substantially all of the unaudited aggregated unconsolidated EBITDA of the Issuer and its subsidiaries. As of March 31, 2022, the unaudited consolidated total assets of the Guarantors represented 98.5% of the unaudited consolidated total assets of the Group. (7) 60% of the shares of Best Secret GmbH are held by PrestigeBidCo GmbH and 40% of the shares are treasury shares held by Best Secret GmbH. (8) 99% of the shares of Best Secret Poland Sp. z.o.o. are held by PrestigeBidCo GmbH and 1% of the shares is held by Best Secret GmbH. 12 -----

Subsection Title: Issuer ..................................................... PrestigeBidCo GmbH, a company with limited liability (Gesellschaft mit
Subsubsection Text: _beschränkter Haftung) incorporated and existing under the laws of_ Germany. Notes Offered ....................................... €315** million aggregate principal amount of      % Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2027.

Subsection Title: Issue Date .............................................     , 2022. Issue Price.............................................      % (plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date). Maturity Date .......................................     , 2027. Interest Rate ......................................... Interest will accrue at a rate per annum, reset quarterly, equal to the sum
Subsubsection Text: of the three-month Euro Interbank Offered Rate (“EURIBOR”) (which is subject to a 1.0% floor) plus      %.

Subsection Title: Interest Payment Dates ....................... Quarterly in arrears on     ,     ,      and      of each year,
Subsubsection Text: commencing on     , 2022. Interest will accrue from the Issue Date.

Subsection Title: Form and Denomination ..................... The Issuer will issue the Notes on the Issue Date in global registered
Subsubsection Text: form. Each Note will have a minimum denomination of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof maintained. No Notes in denominations of less than €100,000 will be available. The Notes will be maintained in book-entry form.

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes ........................... The Notes will:
Subsubsection Text: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer; - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including indebtedness incurred under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, certain cash management obligations and certain hedging obligations, if any; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be secured by the Collateral, as set forth under “Description of the _Notes—Security”;_ - be guaranteed by the Guarantors as described below under “Description of the Notes—Note Guarantees;” - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness or obligation of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes including obligations to trade creditors. 13 ----- The Notes will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, including certain exceptions and turnover provisions. In addition, the Issuer’s obligations in respect of the Notes may be released in certain circumstances. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— Intercreditor Agreement”_ and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the _Notes.”_

Subsection Title: Note Guarantees .................................. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed (the “Note Guarantees”)
Subsubsection Text: on a senior basis by Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH (collectively, the “Guarantors”). (a) The Note Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and may be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description _of_ _Certain_ _Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement,”_ “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes,”_ “Description of the Notes––Note Guarantees” and “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Note _Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ (b) For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, the unaudited aggregated unconsolidated EBITDA of the Guarantors represented substantially all of the unaudited aggregated unconsolidated EBITDA of the Issuer and its subsidiaries. (c) As of March 31, 2022, the unaudited consolidated total assets of the Guarantors represented 98.5% of the unaudited consolidated total assets of the Group.

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Note Guarantees ........ The Note Guarantee of each Guarantor will:
Subsubsection Text: - be a general senior obligation of that Guarantor; - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Note Guarantee, including that Guarantor’s obligations under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and certain hedging obligations; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Note Guarantee; - be secured by the Collateral, as set forth under “Description of the _Notes—Security”;_ - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or obligation of that Guarantor that is secured by property and assets that do not secure such Note Guarantee, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such other indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness, including obligations to trade creditors, of the subsidiaries of such Guarantor that are not Guarantors. 14 -----

Subsection Title: Security, Enforcement of Security ................................................. On or around the Issue Date, and in any case within 30 days, the Notes
Subsubsection Text: will be secured, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, by firstpriority security interests in: - a German law governed third party limited recourse share pledge granted by HoldCo over its shares in the Issuer; - a German law governed third party limited recourse security agreement granted by HoldCo over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it by the Issuer; - a German law governed security agreement granted by the Issuer in respect of any material bank accounts of the Issuer located in Germany; - a German law governed share pledge granted by the Issuer over its shares in Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH; - a German law governed security agreement granted by the Issuer over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it - a German law governed security agreement granted by Best Secret GmbH over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it; and - a German law governed security agreement granted by Best Secret Logistik GmbH over any material structural intercompany loan receivables owed to it, (collectively, the “Collateral”). (a) The Collateral also secures (or will also secure) liabilities under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and certain hedging obligations and may also secure certain future indebtedness on an equal and ratable basis with the Notes. The Collateral has been (or will be) granted subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, certain Agreed Security Principles and the terms of the Security Documents. (b) The security interests in the Collateral may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. See “Description of the Notes—Security” and “Certain Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Note _Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes.”_ (c) The security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description _of_ _Certain_ _Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security.”_

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds .................................... The Issuer intends to use the gross proceeds from the Offering to (i) to
Subsubsection Text: repay and redeem the Existing Notes and satisfy and discharge the Existing Indenture, and (ii) to pay certain fees and expenses in relation to the Transactions.

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption .......................... The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at any time on or
Subsubsection Text: after     , 2023 at the redemption prices as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” 15 ----- At any time prior to     , 2023, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to but not including the date of redemption plus a “make-whole” premium, as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption.”_ In connection with any tender offer or other offer to purchase all of the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% of the aggregate principal amount of the then outstanding Notes validly tender and do not validly withdraw such Notes in such tender offer, the Issuer will have the right to redeem all Notes that remain outstanding. See “Description of the Notes— _Optional Redemption upon Certain Tender Offers.”_

Subsection Title: Additional Amounts; Tax Redemption ................................... Any payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any Guarantor in
Subsubsection Text: respect of the Notes or with respect to any Note Guarantee will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes in any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Withholding _Taxes”) unless required by law. Subject to certain exceptions and_ limitations, if the Issuer, any Guarantor or the Paying Agent is required by law to withhold or deduct such taxes with respect to a payment on any Note, the Issuer or that Guarantor will pay the Additional Amounts (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes”) necessary so that the net amount received by each holder after such withholding is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding. If certain changes in the law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction become effective after the issuance of the Notes that would impose withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes, and would require the Issuer or any Guarantor to pay Additional Amounts, the Issuer may redeem the Notes, in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to but not including the date of redemption.

Subsection Title: Change of Control ............................... Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: may be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.”

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ............................... The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuer
Subsubsection Text: and its Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined therein), to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; 16 ----- - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests created for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Notes obtain and maintain an investment-grade rating. Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_

Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions ........................... The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been, and will not be,
Subsubsection Text: registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes under the securities laws in any jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer).

Subsection Title: OID ....................................................... The Notes will be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for
Subsubsection Text: U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, U.S. holders (as defined under “Taxation—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) generally will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, U.S. holders will generally include any OID in income in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See “Taxation—Certain _U.S. Federal_ _Income_ _Tax _Considerations—Original Issue Discount.”_

Subsection Title: No Established Market for the Notes ......................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
Subsubsection Text: established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes.

Subsection Title: Listing ................................................... Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority
Subsubsection Text: Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. Consummation of the offering of the Notes is not contingent upon obtaining such listing.

Subsection Title: Governing Law .................................... The Indenture, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be governed by
Subsubsection Text: the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement and the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by German law.

Subsection Title: Trustee .................................................. Deutsche Trustee Company Limited Security Agent ...................................... UniCredit Bank AG Paying Agent and Transfer Agent ...... Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch Registrar ............................................... Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. Listing Agent ........................................ Mourant Securities Limited, Jersey Branch

Subsubsection Text: Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section of this Offering Memorandum before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes. 18 -----

_The following summary contains basic information about the Notes. It is not intended to be complete and it is subject to important limitations and exceptions. For a more complete description of the terms of the Notes, including certain definitions of terms used in this summary, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.”_

(2) We define “EBITDA” as net income/(net loss) for the period before income taxes, financial income, financial expenses, depreciation, amortization and impairment losses and the reversal of impairment losses, each as shown in the Consolidated Financial Statements. We define “Adjusted EBITDA” as EBITDA adjusted for restructuring and reorganization costs, new store opening, extension store/fulfillment center and improvement expenses, introduction/improvement of tools and processes expenses and COVID-19 pandemic/geopolitical tensions related expenses. We use Adjusted EBITDA as a measure of our operating cash flow generation and the liquidity of our business. Neither EBITDA nor Adjusted EBITDA is a measure of financial performance calculated in accordance with IFRS and should each be viewed as a supplement to, not a substitute for, our results of operations presented in accordance with IFRS. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA should not be considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as presented in this Offering Memorandum may differ from and may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies and differ from “Consolidated EBITDA” contained in the section ”Description of the Notes” of this Offering Memorandum and in the Indenture. We 22 ----- present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA for informational purposes only. There is no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. The non-IFRS financial measures may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations of the transactions for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our Consolidated Financial Statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. We present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA because we believe they are helpful to investors as measures of our operating performance and ability to service our debt. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents costs for consulting fees in connection with strategy projects and other process optimizations as well as severance payments and headhunter services. (b) Represents (i) expenses incurred in connection with new store openings and extensions, comprised of marketing expenses, agency fees, recruiting, legal and consultancy expenses and additional personnel expenses, (ii) expenses in connection with warehouse expansions, (iii) expenses in connection with additional storage requirements and in connection with the reorganization of processes for the outsourcing of returns and bulky goods and (v) expenses for an additional fulfillment center which is currently being planned. (c) Represents costs incurred in connection with the continuous enterprise resource planning (ERP) optimization, the implementation of a human resources tool and a merchandise management system, the implementation of our marketplace as well as other financial reporting advancements and process optimizations. (d) Represents costs relating to COVID-19 measures, including bonus payment, hazard pay, extensive hygienic measures and regular tests and other costs for the BestSecret Group stationary retail business during closing periods as well as expenses incurred in connection with geopolitical tensions, in the three months ended March 31, 2022, resulting from the conflict in Ukraine such as costs for donations in kind. (3) Adjusted EBITDA margin is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue. For the year ended December 31, 2018, Adjusted EBITDA margin was 17.7% calculated based on an Adjusted EBITDA of €86.6 million in the period. In the period from 2018 through 2021, Adjusted EBITDA margin declined by approximately 3% from 2019 to 2021 (“margin investment”), however Adjusted EBITDA growth resulted in 2x higher Adjusted EBITDA growth from 2019 to 2021 (from 15% Adjusted EBITDA growth for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the year ended December 31, 2018 to 29% Adjusted EBITDA growth for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the year ended December 31, 2020). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, Adjusted EBITDA was €126.0 million. (4) Operating Free Cash Flow is defined as EBITDA plus the changes in net foreign exchange differences, increase/decrease in other liabilities and provisions, decrease/increase in other assets, decrease/increase in trade and other receivables, decrease/increase in inventories and similar assets, increase/decrease in trade payables and other liabilities each as shown in net cash flows from operating activities (changes in current assets, non-current financial assets, current and non-current liabilities presented in net cash flows from operating activities), minus payment of lease liabilities as shown in net cash flows from financing activities and minus Capital Expenditure.

Section Title: SUMMARY CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables present the Issuer’s summary financial information and should be read in conjunction with the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements as well as the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements which are reproduced elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, and the section entitled “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.” The Audited Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with IFRS and the additional requirements of German commercial law pursuant to Section 315e para. 1 of the HGB and were audited in accordance with Section 317 of the HGB and German generally accepted standards for financial statements audits promulgated by the German Institute of Public Auditors (Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer, IDW) by EY, which issued an unqualified independent auditor’s report (Bestätigungsvermerk des unabhängigen Abschlussprüfers) thereon in each case. The Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with IFRS on interim financial reporting (IAS 34). The financial information below is not necessarily indicative of the results of future operations. In the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the Issuer reclassified and re-presented certain comparative amounts in the consolidated statement of financial position and the consolidated statement of cash flows, to implement the latest developments on interpretations of IFRS and to improve presentation of our consolidated financial statements. As a result, certain amounts in the Group’s statement of financial position and cash flow information for the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020 have been taken from the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. For more information see Note 2.4 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The financial information marked as “audited” in the following tables is taken from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The financial information marked as “unaudited” in the following tables is taken from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements and our internal accounting systems or is based on calculations of figures from the abovementioned sources. We present below certain non-IFRS financial measures and ratios that are not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS, including EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA, and certain leverage and coverage ratios, among others. There can be no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. The non-IFRS financial measures are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. The non-IFRS financial measures as presented in this Offering Memorandum may differ from and may not be comparable to similarly titled financial measures used by other companies, and EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA differ from “Consolidated EBITDA” contained in the section “Description of the Notes” of this Offering Memorandum and the Indenture. The non-IFRS financial measures may not give an accurate or complete picture of our financial condition or results of operations for the periods presented and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” The historical financial information below is not necessarily indicative of results of future operations and should be read in conjunction with “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Selected Consolidated Financial Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements and our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._ 19 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business depends on our ability to continuously source and present a variety and quantity of attractive products from various popular brands at attractive prices that will satisfy our customers’ preferences and demands.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our business depends on our ability to continuously source attractive and high-quality merchandise from a broad selection of high-quality brands at attractive prices and in a timely manner. If we are unable to maintain our existing relationships or build new relationships with brands on favorable commercial terms, we may be unable to offer an appropriate selection or quantity of merchandise at discounted prices, which would reduce the appeal of our offering. Only a few of the brand partners we work with have a continuing obligation to provide us with merchandise at historical levels or at all. Furthermore, building new relationships with prospective brand partners can be a lengthy and time-consuming process leading to prolonged lead times until merchandise becomes available for our members to purchase, which in turn could lead to a decrease in customer satisfaction. Our business depends on successful merchandise financial planning and open-to-buy management (a management system that aligns budgets to planned inventory). If these prove inadequate, we could fail to secure and offer an attractive inventory to our customers, which could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations. We must also be able to present our offering to our customers by providing our customers with a unique and personalized online fashion experience using machine learning algorithms and big data. If we are unable to present our offering on our apps, websites and in our stores in an inspiring and attractive way or if we are unable to adapt to the fast-changing developments of social media platforms, we may be unable to attract new customers, may lose existing customers or may be faced with reduced volumes of purchases on our apps and websites, which could limit our growth and prevent us from achieving or maintaining profitability. To deliver a desirable online fashion experience to our customers, we rely on third parties and our brand partners to create content (including photography, other media, and text) which we use on our online platform, in marketing campaigns, advertisements and our online presence generally. Any failure by such third parties or brand partners to produce content that effectively promotes our products could have an adverse effect on our business. Our business also depends on sufficient availability of overstock in the market, which could be adversely affected by supply chain disruptions, changes to the distribution plans of our brand partners or an overall decline in the fashion market. For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine in late February 2022 has and will potentially continue to have a wide range of supply chain implications, including increases in cost and disruption in freight transport. Similarly, the lockdowns and the temporary port closures in China due to the COVID-19 pandemic have and will potentially continue to lead to lower availability of stock because of reduced merchandise production or transportation delays. See also “––Negative developments in global and local economic conditions in our markets _could adversely impact consumer spending in the fashion market.” Additionally, our brand partners may not be_ willing or able to fulfill our product requests or fulfill our product request in full due to lack of stock, a change in their supply-chain model or aggressive competition from other industry participants, including other off-price retailers, on and offline, bidding against us for the same merchandise. Furthermore, brand partners may start managing their product relationships with sellers on a global, rather than local level, which could adversely affect us. As a result of our exclusive, invitation-only membership model, we must balance exclusivity and the protection 26 ----- of brand equity with our growth ambitions. If we fail to strike an appropriate balance, we could fail to achieve our desired growth or negatively affect the brand equity of our brand partners, who may decide to prevent us from offering merchandise for sale through a particular sales channel. Our ability to build a relevant offering for our customers through a broad assortment of desirable products in the right categories and quantities could be affected if we are prevented from offering merchandise through a particular sales channel. If we are unable to secure an appropriate selection and quantity of merchandise on terms and conditions acceptable to us, we may be unable to attract new customers and retain existing customers and consequently increase or maintain sales, which could also diminish the attractiveness of our proposition for brand partners, limiting access to merchandise, any one of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face strong competition in our markets and such competition may intensify further.
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading European members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the market for mid-market to luxury fashion. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio of approximately 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a discreet and controlled channel. The markets in which we operate are highly competitive. Our primary competitors are online off-price and full-price retailers and platforms, including those devoted solely to fashion as well as other types of online platforms and including single-brand as well as multi-brand retailers and marketplaces. In addition, we are to some extent also competing with offline off-price and full-price retailers, such as traditional retail stores, brand outlet stores and off-price fashion stores, due to the operation of our outlet locations and due to partially overlapping customer demographics and supply markets. New competitors who enter our markets or existing offline competitors that shift to online platforms may be successful in attracting customers, including our customers, and thereby capturing market share from us, particularly in Germany, our core market. Some of our current and potential future competitors may have greater financial, distribution, marketing, and other resources than we do. Such competitors may be able to out-bid us for merchandise we would like to access, acquire more attractive merchandise in greater quantities, deliver merchandise more rapidly, or devote more resources to technology, order fulfillment and marketing than we can. The internet facilitates competitive entry and comparison-shopping and renders e-commerce inherently more competitive than other retail platforms. In addition, new and enhanced technologies, including search services, may favor our competition. Also, alternative business models may emerge that would compete with us or diminish the attractiveness or utility of our business model. In particular, social commerce, that is, the use of social networks in the context of e-commerce transactions, as well as the growing popularity of online secondhand fashion retail, could potentially disrupt our business model. If we are unable to compete effectively and fail to attract our target customers to purchase our merchandise, we could lose market share to our competitors. In addition, our brand partners allocate merchandise among ourselves and our competitors depending on the timeliness of orders. If we are unable to act quickly when our brand partners make their merchandise available for purchase, or if we otherwise fail to procure merchandise from our brand partners, for example, due to lack of availability in the market or if the brand partner decides to sell it to another competitor in the market, we could lose market share to our competitors. Furthermore, our plans to expand our business operations into new markets and markets in which we currently have a relatively small presence may be adversely affected by strong competition. For example, some of our competitors may already have long established customer or brand relationships and operations in these markets, which may put them at a competitive advantage. We cannot be certain that we will be able to compete successfully. Should competitive pressure intensify, the resources available to adjust our operations effectively and in a timely manner could be negatively impacted, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Consolidation in the online retail fashion industry could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The online market for off-price mid-market to luxury fashion is undergoing rapid growth and substantial change, which has resulted in increased competition and a consolidation trend. Acquisitions or other consolidating transactions could harm us in a number of ways, including losing customers, revenue and market share, or forcing our company to expend greater resources to meet new or additional competitive threats, all of which could harm our operating results. Newly formed competitors and increased competition, threatening our market position or copying our business model, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. 27 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Negative developments in global and local economic conditions in our markets could adversely impact consumer spending in the fashion market.
Subsubsection Text: We primarily sell fashion products online. Purchases of our customers are discretionary, and therefore dependent upon the level of customer spending, particularly among affluent customers. As a result, our performance depends on global and regional economic conditions, which have shown significant volatility in recent years. For example, economic contraction, economic uncertainty, and the perception by our customers of weak or weakening economic conditions, whether as a result of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 (“COVID-19”), the conflict in Ukraine or otherwise, has and could continue to cause a decline in the demand for the merchandise we sell. In addition, the continued prevalence of the COVID-19 pandemic, the conflict in Ukraine and their related effects has and could continue to lead to a disruption of our supply chain or a decline in the supply of products produced by our brand partners, which could in turn lead to supply shortages and inflationary pressure. The COVID-19 pandemic has in the past led, and in the future could lead, to closure of our retail stores on a temporary or permanent basis. If we are forced to close any of our retail stores, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic or for any other reason, there is no guarantee that we would be able to terminate the relevant lease, secure a sublease or implement any other cost-defraying arrangement for the remainder of the lease term. Furthermore, changes in discretionary consumer spending may be influenced, among other things, by factors such as inflation, higher unemployment levels, rising interest rates, reduced access to credit, recessionary economic cycles, increases in taxes or perceived or actual declines in disposable consumer income and wealth. Our online platform is available in multiple languages and offers shipping to 27 European countries, with the majority of our revenue currently generated in our core market Germany and the DACH region. A negative development, contraction or lack of growth in the economies of the DACH region or the other European countries where we operate or may operate in the future, and in overall macroeconomic conditions, could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. We may be more affected by such economic weakness or uncertainty than some of our competitors with more diversified international operations. There is also a risk of increased taxes, for the purpose of addressing the extraordinary levels of public spending and public debt related to the COVID-19 pandemic, in some or all of the European countries in which we sell our merchandise. Tax increases that lead to increases in the sales prices of our products or the prices of services we purchase or offer or reduce the income available for consumption could also weaken demand for our fashion products. Germany, our home market, which had seen a long period of stable economic growth since the financial crisis of 2007 - 2008, reported a 5.0% decline in its gross domestic product for 2020 compared to 2019 according to Destatis. Although Germany’s gross domestic product reported a 2.7% increase for 2021 compared to 2020, the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and related countermeasures and the Russian invasion of Ukraine will likely continue to dampen economic prospects in Europe in the short term. While Germany still generates most of our revenue (72% in the year ended December 31, 2021), the international sales share has increased substantially in recent years and international growth is one of our current strategic focus areas. Although the COVID-19 pandemic contributed to growth in the online fashion industry both in 2020 and 2021, an end to government support programs, increased interest rates and the lifting of quantitative easing measures, could trigger a continued economic downturn in one or more of our markets which may result in higher levels of unemployment and as a consequence materially negatively affect consumer confidence and discretionary consumer spending, including purchases of fashion and lifestyle products. Geopolitical tensions, including but not limited to tensions between Russia and its neighboring countries, including Ukraine, Poland and the Baltic states, tensions between China and the United States or acts of terrorism, could also negatively affect the demand for and supply of our merchandise. In late February 2022, Russian military forces launched a significant military action against Ukraine, which continues to date, and sustained conflict and disruption in the region is likely. The instability of the general security situation, as well as any actions taken by other countries, including new and stricter sanctions by the United Kingdom, the European Union, the U.S. and other countries and organizations against officials, individuals, regions, and industries in Russia, Ukraine and Belarus, and each country’s potential response to such sanctions, tensions, and military actions could have a material adverse effect on our operations. Such instability could lead to delays in completing our planned fulfillment center in Poland, as well as disruptions to the fulfillment center’s operations if such instability continues after the fulfillment center is operational. We may also be affected due to the negative impact of such geopolitical tensions on consumer confidence and consumer shopping behavior, resulting in lower sales and results of operation. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the pace and extent of the global economic recovery remains highly uncertain, and certain markets may not in the future achieve the growth rates that they have historically observed. 28 ----- The aggravation of the foregoing factors including the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict and/or, more generally, an extended recession or other periods of declining economic conditions, either globally or in any of the markets in which we operate, could substantially decrease the demand for our products and adversely affect our business. If our markets do not develop as anticipated or are negatively affected by global and local economic conditions, as well as geopolitical tensions, consumer spending in the fashion market may be adversely affected and demand for our products may not increase as currently anticipated. Consequently, we may not be able to recoup the investments made in these markets and may be forced to close, or decide to divest, our operations in selected markets, which could have an adverse material effect on the implementation of our expansion strategy and consequently on our financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our industry and the sale of our products are subject to seasonal fluctuations and unfavorable weather.
Subsubsection Text: The industry in which we operate is seasonal in nature, and our revenue, profits, liquidity and inventory levels are therefore subject to seasonal fluctuations. For example, we typically experience an increase in sales in the fourth quarter of the year due to special sales events (e.g., Cyber Week) and the Christmas shopping season. In the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue in the fourth quarter accounted for 34.2% of our total revenue for the year. These seasonal influences have a direct impact on our results of operations and overall profitability. Any factors that deter customers from purchasing online or visiting our stores during these periods could have a disproportionate effect on our results of operations for the entire fiscal year. In addition, atypical weather conditions could impact our sales and operating results. When the weather is warmer than expected in the autumn and winter months, our customers tend to purchase fewer winter collection items. Similarly, when the weather is cooler than expected in the summer months, our customers tend to purchase fewer summer collection items. During times of such unfavorable weather, we may be required to lower our prices, negatively impacting our margins and our profit. If we cannot offset the lower-sales seasons with those having stronger sales, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be adversely affected. Seasonal fluctuations also impact our working capital, liquidity levels and inventory. We incur additional expenses in the preparation for the increased demand we typically expect leading up to, and around, the special sales events (e.g., Cyber Week sale) and Christmas season and other peak selling periods and must carry a significant amount of inventory before such periods, which is also reflected in our liquidity. If too many customers access our website within a short period of time due to increased demand or unexpectedly strong peaks, our businesses may experience system interruptions that make our website unavailable or prevent us from efficiently fulfilling orders, which may reduce the volume of goods we offer or sell and the attractiveness of our products and services. In addition, we may be unable to adequately staff our fulfillment networks and customer service centers during these peak periods and delivery and other third-party shipping (or carrier) companies may be unable to meet the seasonal demand. In addition, seasonal products, such as winter clothing, being delayed may only be sold in the next season and may increase storage costs. Our quarterly results of operations may also fluctuate significantly as a result of a variety of other factors, including but not limited to unfavorable weather, age and quantity of inventory at period end and the timing, extent and impact of government-imposed restrictions related to COVID-19. As a result, historical period-toperiod comparisons of our results of operations are not necessarily indicative of future period-to-period results. The results of a single fiscal quarter may not be an indication of our annual results or our future performance. Increasing weather anomalies could complicate forecasting seasonal demand. Natural disasters, such as storms, tornadoes, floods, earthquakes or other major weather disasters may also have a negative impact on our business. Our inability to compensate for seasonal fluctuations and adapt to weather conditions may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If sensitive information about our customers is disclosed, our customers may curtail use of our sites, we may be exposed to liability and our reputation would suffer, and disclosure of our confidential information could adversely affect our business and operations.
Subsubsection Text: We operate apps, websites and other data systems through which we collect, maintain, transmit and store information about our customers, brand partners and others, including credit card or other financial and personal information, as well as other confidential and proprietary information. In addition, we gather and retain information about our employees in the normal course of business. We also employ third-party service providers that store, process and transmit proprietary, personal, and confidential information on our behalf. Furthermore, 29 ----- we rely on a variety of security measures, including encryption and authentication technology licensed from third parties in an effort to securely transmit confidential and sensitive information, including but not limited to credit card details. Any compromise or breach of our security measures, or those of our third-party service providers, could violate applicable privacy and data security laws, including the General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) as well as other applicable laws, and cause significant legal and financial risks, adverse publicity, or a loss of confidence in our security measures. Customer data may be misappropriated as a result of computer viruses, telecommunications failures, electronic break-ins and similar disruptions. If we or our third-party service providers experience, or are believed to have experienced, security breaches that result in our sites’ performance or availability problems or the loss or corruption of, or unauthorized access to or disclosure of, personal data or confidential information, people may become unwilling to provide us the information necessary to make purchases on our sites. Existing customers may also decrease their purchases or close their accounts altogether. We could also face potential liability and litigation as a result of security breaches, our online content or other consumer privacy concerns, which may not be adequately covered by insurance. Any of these results could harm our growth prospects, our business, and our reputation. Furthermore, our key employees and officers have access to sensitive confidential information relating to our business, especially relating to the functioning of our apps and websites, our proprietary machine learning algorithms, and big data infrastructure. While we have confidentiality agreements and technical measures in place, we cannot assure that third parties or the general public never gain access to such information. Any ineffective protection of such information relating to our business might materially weaken our market position and thus adversely affect our business and operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to the risk of security breaches, including cyber-attacks, and unauthorized use of one or more of our websites, databases, online security systems or computerized logistics management systems.
Subsubsection Text: Like other online platforms, we are vulnerable to the risk of security breaches, including real or perceived cyberattacks and unauthorized use of one or more of our websites, databases, online security systems or computerized logistics management systems. While we take extensive steps to protect the security, integrity and confidentiality of sensitive and confidential information (e.g., password policies and firewalls), our security practices or those of our third-party service providers may be insufficient and third parties may breach our systems (e.g., through Trojans, spyware, ransomware or other malware attacks, or breaches by our employees or third-party service providers). Such attacks or breaches which may result in shutdowns of our sites, loss or corruption of data or unauthorized use or disclosure of information. Such attacks might lead to blackmailing attempts, forcing us to pay substantial amounts to release our captured data or resulting in the unauthorized release of such data, or to identity theft or unauthorized purchases, requiring us to pay compensation to the victims. Cyberattacks could also target our logistics, supply or office systems, which could result in order fulfillment delays, leading to cancelled orders and a subsequent decline in revenue, as well as reputational damages. We have been subject to attempted cyber, phishing or social engineering attacks in the past and may continue to be subject to such attacks in the future. As we gain greater visibility, we may face a higher risk of being targeted by cyberattacks. We may also need to devote significant resources to protect against security breaches or to address problems caused by breaches, which may require us to divert resources from the growth and expansion of our business. We and our third-party service providers may not have the resources or technical sophistication to anticipate or prevent all such cyberattacks. Moreover, techniques used to obtain unauthorized access to systems change frequently and may not be known until launched against us or our third-party service providers, and consequently it may be impossible to properly secure our systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and increased complexity of our IT infrastructure, as well as non-technical issues, including intentional or inadvertent actions by our employees, our third-party service providers, or their personnel, could increase the likelihood of security breaches. As we have significantly increased the number of employees working remotely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and as our businesses’ vendors and other business partners continue to work remotely as well, our business and our partners may be more vulnerable to cyber-attacks. The techniques used to gain such access to our business or our business partners’ information technology systems, our data, disable or degrade service, or sabotage systems are constantly evolving, may be difficult to detect quickly, and often are not recognized until launched against a target. Increasingly, unauthorized parties are exploiting access they gain to third party vendors to target companies that do business with these vendors, and this may include third party vendors with whom we do business. 30 ----- Advances in computer capabilities, new technological discoveries or other developments have increased and could further increase the frequency or likelihood of security breaches. In addition, security breaches can also occur as a result of non-technical issues, including intentional or inadvertent breaches by our employees or by persons with whom we have commercial relationships, including third-party developers, consultants, outsourced customer support or operational personnel of hosting providers (e.g., Microsoft, Noris AG) with direct access to databases and customer-related services. The materialization of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects as well as our reputation.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any failure to operate, maintain, integrate and scale our information technology systems could result in customer dissatisfaction, loss of revenue or subject us to claims for damages.
Subsubsection Text: Our business, as an online platform with physical retail presence, is dependent on the smooth functioning of our information technology systems, especially our internet and mobile infrastructure, as well as third-party infrastructure such as Microsoft Azure, which are critical to our business and inherently subject to various operating risks. For example, our offering is founded on our vertically integrated, proprietary technology platform specifically designed for the sourcing, presentation, curation, marketing, and fulfillment of fashion products. In addition, as an e-commerce platform, we generate a high volume of traffic on, and use of, our apps and websites to analyze a broad range of customer data, tracking individual journeys and ensuring efficient spending of our marketing resources. Our reputation and ability to acquire, retain and serve our customers are dependent upon the reliable performance of our apps and websites and their underlying network infrastructure. As our customer base and the amount of information shared on our apps and websites continue to grow, we will require additional network capacity and computing power. In addition, we need to maintain reliable internet and mobile networks with the necessary speed, data capacity and security, as well as ensuring timely development of complementary products. Furthermore, we currently rely and expect to continue to rely on third parties in part to maintain and develop our computer hardware and software. The operation of our technology systems is expensive and complex and could result in operational failures. Certain of our technology platforms have long development cycles and comparatively low productivity, resulting in extended periods required to introduce new features as well as high development costs. In addition, we are exposed to the risk of our technology systems being undersized and functionally maladjusted or incompatible with certain electronic devices that are used by our customers. Our customers may also find our websites difficult to use or may be unwilling to use our online platform for other reasons. In addition, our customers may lack confidence in the security of our online platform and may consequently be unwilling to share personal information with us through the online platform. In the event that our customer base or the amount of traffic on our websites grows more quickly than anticipated, we may be required to incur significant additional costs to enhance the underlying network infrastructure. Inadequate performance of our technology systems, whether due to telecommunication problems, software errors, inadequate capacity at IT centers, fire, power outages or damage, attacks by third parties, computer viruses and the delayed or failed implementation of new computer systems or other unexpected events or causes, could affect the security or availability of our apps and websites, prevent customers from accessing our apps and websites and result in limited capacity, reduced demand, processing delays and loss of customers. Our existing safety systems, data backup, access protection, user management and IT emergency planning may not be sufficient to prevent information loss or disruptions to our IT infrastructure. Any actual or perceived failure to maintain the performance, reliability, security and availability of our products and technology systems to the satisfaction of our customers and certain regulators could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. As our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we need to continuously improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure to offer an increasing number of user-enhanced services, features and functionalities, while maintaining or improving the reliability and integrity of our systems and infrastructure. If we fail to make necessary upgrades, our technology systems and data platform could be insufficient to allow us to make datadriven decisions, in both the context of our day-to-day operations and our larger business initiatives as our business grows and expands in scope. We are currently, among other projects, working on a new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system. There is the potential risk that the project’s goals are not achieved, delayed, or not fully achieved, the system is inoperable after its completion, or that there are difficulties in implementing the system that could impact the operating business. In addition, other business projects may have to be postponed, which would result in the failure to achieve the planned level of efficiency. There is also the risk that, even after a successful launch, the ERP system fails to interface successfully or work in conjunction with our existing systems. As a result, dependent projects may not be realized within expected timeframes. Any of the foregoing is likely to create additional costs for manual adjustments and negatively impact our topline growth goals. In addition, our 31 ----- growing IT needs have led to increasing levels of utilization of our existing IT branch offices in Spain. In addition, any upgrade, development or maintenance of our systems and infrastructure could lead us to incur unexpected costs. We use cloud services to store and maintain customer data as well as to support our IT infrastructure. An interruption or breakdown of our technology systems and IT infrastructure due to power outages, fire, natural disasters, acts of terrorism, vandalism or sabotage, actions of third-party providers or any other unanticipated reason cannot be ruled out completely. The disaster recovery arrangements we have put in place, have not been tested during actual disasters or similar events and may not effectively permit us to continue to run our business in the event of any problems with respect to the data that we use. Therefore, we cannot provide any assurances that these types of events will not occur in the future. If our cloud service partners fail, we may experience downtime on our apps and websites which could reduce the attractiveness of our apps and websites to customers. Failure in our IT infrastructure could also result in unfavorable media coverage, damage our reputation, and/or result in regulatory inquiries or other proceedings.
