Any failure to operate and maintain our technology systems, integrate, and scale our network and mobile infrastructure could result in customer dissatisfaction, and thus harm our reputation, lead to a loss of revenue or subject us to claims for damages, which could jeopardize the implementation of our further growth strategy and have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition, and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Customer growth and activity on mobile devices depends upon effective use of mobile operating systems, networks, and standards that we do not control.
Subsubsection Text: Purchases using mobile devices by customers generally, and by our customers specifically, have increased significantly, and we expect this trend to continue. To optimize the mobile shopping experience, we are dependent on our customers downloading our specific mobile app for their particular device(s) or accessing our website from an internet browser. With the continued release of new mobile devices and operating systems, we face difficulties predicting the problems we may encounter in developing apps for these alternative devices and operating systems, and we may need to devote significant resources to the creation, support, and maintenance of such applications. In addition, our future growth and our results of operations could suffer if we experience difficulties in the future in integrating our apps into mobile devices, if problems arise with our relationships with providers of mobile operating systems or mobile app stores, such as those of the Apple App Store or Google Play, if our apps receive unfavorable treatment compared to competing applications, such as the order of our apps within application stores, or if we face increased costs to distribute or have customers use our mobile applications. We are further dependent on the interoperability of our sites with popular mobile operating systems that we do not control, such as iOS and Android, and any changes in such systems that degrade the functionality of our sites or give preferential treatment to competitive products could adversely affect the usage of our sites on mobile devices. Further, we continually upgrade existing technologies and business applications, and we may be required to implement new technologies or business applications in the future. The implementation of upgrades and changes requires significant investments. The timing, effectiveness and costs associated with the successful implementation of any upgrades or changes to our systems and infrastructure could have adverse effects on our results of operations. In the event that it is more difficult for our customers to access and use our sites on their mobile devices, or if our customers choose not to access or to use our sites on their mobile devices or to use mobile products that do not offer access to our sites, our customer growth could be harmed and our business, financial condition and results of operations may be materially and adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Failure to improve our delivery systems and infrastructure to meet the technological developments and demands of our growing operations could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: As our operations expand in size and scope, we will need to continually improve and upgrade the systems and infrastructure that support our supply chain while maintaining or improving the reliability and integrity of our systems and infrastructure. We must be able to incorporate new technologies into our services in order to address the needs of our customers. Our e-commerce platform may become unstable or unavailable due to failure to perform necessary upgrades, exposure to cyber-attacks or any other failure of our computer systems and related information technology infrastructure. The emergence of alternative platforms such as mobile and tablet computing devices and the emergence of niche competitors who may be able to optimize products, services or strategies for such platforms will require new investment in technology. New developments in other areas, such 32 ----- as cloud computing, could also make it easier for competition to enter our markets due to lower up-front technology costs. There can be no assurance that we will be able to compete with advancing technology or be able to maintain existing systems or replace or introduce new technologies and systems as quickly as we would like or in a cost-effective manner, and any failure to do so could result in customers seeking alternative products or service providers, thereby adversely impacting our revenue and operating income. The functioning of our online business depends to a large extent on our customers receiving the ordered goods in a timely and smooth manner and being able to return them without any difficulties. If the traffic volume on our websites or the number of purchases made by customers substantially increases, our current transaction processing systems, network infrastructure, storage facilities and delivery systems may be unable to accommodate the increased volume. This includes our own systems, services and infrastructure as well as those owned and/or managed by third parties. Additionally, we may be unable to accurately forecast these increases or to upgrade our supply chain systems in time to accommodate them. If our delivery infrastructure comes under strain from an unexpected or higher-than-expected spike in customer orders, or for any other reason, we may be unable to honor orders on our usual delivery terms, which could lead to negative reputational consequences for ourselves and our brand partners. Furthermore, our transaction processing systems may result in our online platform displaying expected delivery times to our customers that do not reflect actual order backlogs or delivery times. Inconsistencies between expected and actual delivery times could lead to customer dissatisfaction with our online platform. We are constantly monitoring our fulfillment and logistics capacity to keep up with those requirements and match our continued growth. However, we cannot rule out that our significant and continued growth results in our warehouse capacities being brought to their limits faster than anticipated. Due to the increasing levels of utilization of our existing fulfillment and returns centers, we are currently planning a new fulfillment center in Sulechów, Poland to provide us with additional flexibility and to address further future growth. The new fulfillment center is scheduled to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023 and is expected to be larger than our current main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany. We may make incorrect assumptions regarding the necessary size, the technical design and the level of automation required of the new facility. Any unexpected cost overruns, poor planning, delays or other unforeseen factors, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. In addition, after the new logistics center is completed, our increasingly complex order fulfillment operation could have an adverse effect on our ability to supply our customers, including as a result of split orders and orders that require movement between warehouses. Furthermore, an increase in political tensions between Poland and other European nations (and in particular, other members of the European Union) culminating in a withdrawal from the European Union by Poland could have a negative impact on our order fulfillment operations. As of March 31, 2022, our total capital expenditure for this project amounted to €0.2 million. We currently anticipate that the new fulfillment center in Poland will require additional capital expenditure across the years ending December 31, 2022 through December 31, 2024. There can be no guarantee, however, that volatile raw material prices and inflation will not cause our projected capital expenditure to be inaccurate or that we will be able to raise additional financing on favorable terms or at all. Also, as we continue to grow and expand internationally, it is not certain that we will be able to find suitable fulfillment center sites on commercially acceptable terms to support any future expansion plans. We might also need to increase our capital expenditures more than anticipated in order to increase the capacity of our logistics infrastructure. Any failure in the expansion of our fulfillment and logistics infrastructure as our business expands could materially impact our growth strategy.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Inability to forecast our business accurately could prevent us from properly planning expenses and process capacity.
Subsubsection Text: We base our current and future expense levels on our forecasts of our business and estimates of future revenue. Such future revenue and results of operations are difficult to forecast because they generally depend on the volume, timing and type of orders we receive, all of which are uncertain. Seasonal variations in our inventories, working capital requirements and cash flows, among other things, also increase the difficulty of our financial forecasting and could adversely affect our ability to accurately predict financial results. For any given season, a substantial portion of our expenses is incurred in advance, and therefore fixed, due to the seasonality of demand for our products and the necessity of purchasing merchandise with significant lead times. As a result, we may be unable to adjust our spending in a timely manner to compensate for any unexpected shortfall in revenue, which could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations. 33 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we are unable to manage our inventory, or our online presence and store network in line with customer demand, or if we are unable to otherwise forecast our business accurately, our sales levels and profitability may decline.
Subsubsection Text: The off-price market for mid-market to luxury fashion is driven in part by fashion and beauty trends, and consequently, the merchandise we sell is subject to changing consumer demands and preferences. Consumer preferences regarding fashion design, quality, sustainability, and price tend to change rapidly. Hence, accurately forecasting the selection and required quantities of such products in future periods is difficult. Accelerated through short-term trends and sentiments on social media, the popularity of products can change significantly between the time products are ordered and the date of sale. In addition, the lead times we must incur in taking delivery of merchandise from many of our brand partners could pose challenges by increasing, in some cases significantly, the time it takes us to respond to changes in product trends, consumer demand and market prices. Our success depends in large part on our ability to gauge, react and adapt to changing consumer demands in a timely manner. To be responsive to shifting customer tastes, we must manage our inventory levels closely, including through identifying market trends and seasonality. If we misjudge, fail to identify, or fail to react swiftly to changes in consumer preferences and market trends, our sales could decrease, and we could see a significant increase in our inventory levels. If we are left with high levels of unsold or returned stock, or if our inventory provisions are inadequate, our storage capacity could be negatively impacted and we could be required to mark down some of our merchandise, which could lower our operating profits and have a significant negative impact on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Conversely, if we underestimate consumer interest in our merchandise, we may experience inventory shortages, unfulfilled orders, increased distribution expenses and lower revenue and profitability than we could otherwise have achieved. Inventory shortages could lead to customer dissatisfaction and adversely impact our reputation and brand image. The success of our buying teams is largely based on leveraging their decision-making, experience, and their relationships with brand partners to outpace the competition. Insufficient controls within the purchasing process may lead to unapproved or incorrect orders and may result in financial disadvantages for the Group due to non-sellable inventory or liquidity risks. In the fashion industry, customer demand can quickly change depending on many factors, including promotional activities of competitors, rapidly changing tastes and preferences, frequent introductions of new products and services, advances in technology and the internet and macroeconomic factors, many of which are beyond our control, especially in light of the COVID-19 pandemic and the latest geopolitical developments and their impact on economic conditions. With this constantly changing environment, our future business strategies, practices, and results may not meet expectations or respond quickly enough to customer demand, and we may face operational difficulties in adjusting to any changes, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition, and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We depend on a reliable and efficient supply chain, which includes our fulfillment and returns centers, transport service providers, third-party carriers that deliver merchandise to our online customers, and stores. Capacity constraints, interruptions or other failures in our supply chain could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: The profitability of our business depends on our ability to successfully process and deliver our customers’ orders. Our ability to process and fill orders accurately and timely depends on the efficient, uninterrupted operation of our main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany, where we store nearly all of our inventory, and our warehouse management IT system. Our main fulfillment center is, therefore, critical to our business. If operations at our fulfillment or returns centers were interrupted due to factors including, but not limited to, natural disasters (such as flooding or fire), labor disruptions (such as labor strikes, shortages of temporary workers or ethical disputes), technical defects, accidents, the COVID-19 pandemic, inappropriate storage of hazardous goods or any other reason, it would have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position. In addition, due to the high level of integration between our fulfillment center and points of sale, any interruption of logistics at our fulfillment center would also have a significant adverse effect on our ability to supply our customers and could result in customer dissatisfaction and harm to our reputation. A number of factors, many of which are beyond our control, could disrupt the operation of our supply chain and jeopardize our ability to receive, process and deliver our customers’ orders. System interruptions in any of our own or externally operated technology platforms and services could delay or prevent our receipt of customer orders, shipments or returns. 34 ----- Our ability to deliver orders to our customers, including pre-orders, within a time frame that meets customer expectations also depends on efficient internal processes as well as on third-party service providers to whom we have outsourced certain processes, such as the handling of bulky goods or returns, and on third-party delivery companies in each of the countries in which we operate. Any disruptions to these processes could also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. We also rely on third-party service providers for the handling of certain processes and on a limited number of third-party carriers, including DHL and Hermes, for the delivery of merchandise to our fulfillment and return centers as well as for delivery to online customers. We are therefore exposed to any failures or shortcomings by these service providers or carriers, including delivery delays or damage, loss, or theft of goods. If we are not able to negotiate acceptable pricing and other terms with these entities, if they significantly increase their charges or they experience performance problems, including as a result of inflationary pressures and the COVID-19 pandemic, it could negatively impact our customer experience. Any breakdown or disruption of the activities of these service providers or carriers resulting from, among other things, inclement weather, natural disasters, transportation interruptions, labor shortages, oil price increases, epidemics or unrest could impair our ability to supply our fulfillment center at current cost levels or at all, make timely deliveries to customers or maintain an appropriate logistics chain and level of inventory, all of which could adversely affect our reputation, business, results of operations and financial condition. The merger, acquisition, insolvency or government regulation or shutdown of any third-party contractors we use in our supply chain could also interrupt order processing, storage, and delivery. Additionally, we may be unable to maintain relationships with our current carriers, and we may at any point be required to contract with other carriers at a potentially greater cost. Finally, we may face price increases by the third-party carriers we use which may result in higher fulfillment expenses we may only partially be able to pass on to our customers. Furthermore, we have incurred costs relating to our COVID-19 measures throughout our European offices, our stores and our main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany. Such costs include bonus and hazard pay, increased health and safety measures such as the temporary introduction of a third shift in our logistics center, the implementation of regular tests and extensive hygienic measures, as well as costs relating to the closure of our outlet in Frankfurt, Germany. Furthermore, the effects of the COVID-19 virus could in the future disrupt our supply chain and distribution and fulfillment capabilities, including shipments of our merchandise to impacted regions or from our main fulfillment center. There is continuing uncertainty around the breadth and duration of business disruptions related to the COVID-19 pandemic including, but not limited to, store closures, as well as its further impact on the global economy and consumer confidence. New variants of COVID-19 continue to emerge, including the Delta variant and more recently, the Omicron variant, which have caused and may continue to cause significant uncertainty. The future impact of other variants that may emerge cannot be predicted at this time and could include temporary or permanent store closures. Such impacts may be affected by numerous factors, including vaccination rates and availability, the effectiveness of current vaccines against the variants and responses by various governments, such as lockdowns and other restrictive measures. In addition, our ability to receive inbound inventory efficiently and ship merchandise to customers may be negatively affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and related response measures, inclement weather, fire, flood, power loss, earthquakes, labor disputes, acts of war or terrorism, trade embargoes and similar factors. For example, strikes at major international shipping ports may in the future impact our supply of inventory from our brand partners, and the escalating trade disputes between the United States, the European Union, China, and certain other regions could lead to increased tariffs on our goods. If the manufacturing, delivery, or supply chain management processes relating to our merchandise are disrupted as a result of these factors or for any reason, we may be delayed in restoring our inventory of the affected products and we may experience a significant increase in our cost of sales. Any failure to adequately manage and improve our supply chain could reduce our transaction volume, increase cancelled orders, undermine customer satisfaction, damage our business reputation, limit our competitiveness, or otherwise materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition, and prospects. Our online platform is available in multiple languages and offers shipping to 27 European countries, with the majority of our revenue currently generated in our core market Germany and the DACH region. As part of our strategy, we are expanding internationally, which could lead to higher shipping and logistics costs that could negatively impact our margins and could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition, and prospects. In addition, our operations, including our supply chain, could be affected by the withdrawal of additional countries from the EU. For example, we have operations in Poland, where we also expect an additional fulfillment center to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023. A withdrawal of Poland from the EU would create significant 35 ----- political and economic uncertainty regarding the future relationship between Poland and the EU and could cause disruptions to, and create uncertainty surrounding, our operations in Poland and the EU. If, in such a case, Poland and the EU are unable to negotiate an agreement governing their future relationship that allows free trade of goods across the borders between Poland and EU member states, there could be significant delivery delays and cost increases for our supply chain. Our operations, including our supply chain, has and could continue to be similarly affected by the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. Sustained conflict and disruption in the region has and, combined with the instability of the general security situation, could continue to lead to interruptions in our supply chain.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our investments to grow our customer base through paid customer acquisition and viral growth and to retain a loyal customer base may not be effective.
Subsubsection Text: Maintaining and growing our loyal customer base is critical to our success and profitability. In an environment characterized by increasing levels of promotions and customer discounts, the growth of our customer base and sales depends on the success of our general marketing activities, our incentive programs for customer referrals from existing customers and our paid customer acquisition activities. We rely on social media to support the positioning of our offering, extending invites to acquire new customers, increase the number of customer visits to our websites, the number of orders and the basket size per order. In particular, we depend heavily on Meta platforms (e.g., Facebook and Instagram), as our most-used paid customer acquisition marketing channel. Changes to the terms and conditions of the relevant providers could limit our ability to communicate through social media. These services may also change their algorithms or interfaces, including without notification, which may reduce our visibility or increase our costs. Our growth and profitability are dependent on our viral customer growth model, with existing customers inviting their friends and families to join our community. In order to build on this structural customer growth, we have recently increased our investments related to brand awareness and customer acquisition in underpenetrated regions and countries, and we expect to continue to invest in attracting new customers. Paid social marketing (performance marketing and social media marketing), which is geared to a critical, selected target group and closely aligned with our brand partners, is our principal instrument to enter new opportunities in existing markets and new markets. Our investments in viral marketing, paid customer acquisition and customer loyalty may prove ineffective. In addition, with the constantly increasing popularity of social media platforms (e.g., Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube, TikTok, Twitch), influencer marketing has become an increasingly applied marketing tool especially in the fashion industry. We also integrate independent influencers into our branding and content strategy by using their endorsements and mentions on their social media channels to enhance our brand awareness. These collaborations with influencers may not achieve the anticipated success, or subject us to reputational damage (for example through misbehavior on the part of an influencer cooperating with us). Critiques on blogs, forums and social media, based on ecological, ethical or many other considerations, and regardless of whether such critique is reasonable or not, may cause damage to our reputation and our product offering and may result in us being required to withdraw certain merchandise. We also use e-mail newsletters, app push notifications and other messaging services in order to promote our platform, inform customers of our product offering and/or the status of their transactions. Changes in how webmail services organize and prioritize e-mails could reduce the number of customers opening our e-mails. For example, several service providers organize incoming e-mails into categories. Such tools and features could result in our e-mails and other messages being shown as “spam”, “junk” or otherwise as lower-priority messages to our customers, which could reduce the likelihood of customers opening or responding positively to them. Certain customers may experience dissatisfaction and cease to use our platform if they perceive themselves to be oversaturated with advertising campaigns or newsletters or otherwise exposed to social media, e-mail or text message “flooding.” Our customers may also lack interest in the content of our e-mail messages, or such messages may fail to be delivered or may be delayed in their delivery for technical reasons. Actions by third parties to block, impose restrictions on, or charge for the delivery of, e-mails, app push notifications and other messages, as well as legal or regulatory changes limiting our right to send such messages or imposing additional requirements on our ability to conduct e-mail marketing, could impair our ability to communicate with our customers. In addition, any malfunction of our communication services could result in erroneous messages being sent and customers no longer wanting to receive any messages from us. Furthermore, our process to obtain consent from users of our apps and visitors to our websites to receive newsletters, app push notifications and other messages from us and to allow us to use their data may be seen as insufficient or invalid. As a result, such individuals or third parties may accuse us of sending unsolicited advertisements and other messages which could result in claims against us. 36 ----- There can be no assurance that our assumptions regarding marketing strategies, required customer acquisition investment and resulting revenue from such customers, including those relating to the effectiveness of our marketing expenditures, will prove to be correct or lead to increased sales. Also, while we attach the highest importance to our brand partner relationships and therefore to brand protection, our paid customer acquisition activities may not be met with approval by all brand partners and lead to an adverse effect on our relationships. Failure to implement our marketing strategies, or their failure to result in increased sales, could have an adverse effect on our liquidity, financial position, and results of operations and on the implementation of our growth strategy.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Operational disruptions at our fulfillment centers could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We currently operate one main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany, where we store most of our inventory. We have three additional warehouses in Poing, Brieselang and Großbeeren (all Germany), respectively. Our main fulfillment center is, therefore, critical to our business. If operations at our fulfillment center were interrupted due to factors including, but not limited to, natural disasters (such as flooding or fire), man-made disruptions (such as labor strikes), technical defects, accidents, epidemics or for any other reason, it would have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position. In addition, although we have outsourced our returns handling to a third-party provider in Poland since 2019, due to the high level of integration between our fulfillment center and points of sale, any interruption of logistics at our fulfillment center would also have a significant adverse effect on our ability to supply our customers and could result in customer dissatisfaction and harm to our reputation. Any disruptions at our sites, either because of problems with our supply of merchandise or for any of the other reasons listed above, could also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we are unable to price our products competitively, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be negatively impacted.
Subsubsection Text: As our business model is focused on selling branded fashion products at reduced prices, the price at which we offer our products is the most important factor for being competitive in our market. Price is of great importance to most customers, and price transparency and comparability continues to increase, particularly as a result of digital technology. The ability of consumers to compare prices on a real-time basis puts additional pressure on us to maintain competitive prices. Our current and potential future competitors may be able to secure more favorable pricing terms from brand partners, adopt more aggressive pricing policies, or otherwise offer similar merchandise at more attractive prices. If we offer products at higher prices than our competitors, our customers may choose to shop with our competitors, which could result in a loss of customers and revenue. We are therefore dependent on the performance of our sourcing and pricing processes, including on our pricing tool, to provide the right pricing recommendations. We currently price our inventory through a combination of manual initial pricing, followed by automatic adjustment through the use of an algorithm, which could limit our ability to price our products at an optimal level. Poor pricing decisions could lead to offering items at prices that are too low or pricing items uncompetitively high. Furthermore, retailers and brands set their own retail prices for consumers, which can include promotional and sales period discounts. Such discounts by these parties may adversely affect the relative value of overstock offered for sale with us. In order to attract buyers to our online platform, the prices for the overstock merchandise we sell may need to be lowered in order to compete with discounted pricing employed by retailers and brands for the items sold directly by them. Our prices also depend in part on our sourcing and logistics costs which in turn depend on the development of prices for certain raw materials, in particular cotton and other textile raw materials, as well as fuel. We are typically impacted by increases in the prices of raw materials and fuel price as well as carrier-charge increases, as our brand partners and third-party service providers attempt to pass along these increases to us. Although we may attempt to pass on cost increases to our customers by increasing selling prices via regular price reviews and adjustments, we may not always be able to do so, for example, if our brand partners attempt to exercise control over our pricing. Moreover, any price increases could adversely affect our sales or our decision to increase discount rates to remain competitive in the market could reduce our profitability. During periods of declining input or fuel prices, customer demand may also require that we sell our products at lower prices or may restrict our ability to increase prices, in spite of the fact that we may use goods that were purchased at higher prices or that we are forced to incur higher shipping costs, thereby negatively impacting our margins. The volatility in our sourcing and logistics costs and our limited ability to pass them on to customers may adversely affect our business and financial condition. 37 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We source the majority of our merchandise on the basis of purchase orders with our brand partners, and the lack of formal supply agreements could impact our ability to maintain these relationships.
Subsubsection Text: Consistent with customary practice in our industry, our relationships with many of our brand partners are not based on formalized supply agreements but, rather, the regular submission of purchase orders or price agreements renegotiated periodically between the parties on order forms. We only enter into long-term agreements with brand partners in exceptional cases. Accordingly, we source most of our merchandise based on individual purchase orders with our brand partners. This informal way of working may result in a less precise definition of the parties’ respective rights and may, in the event of a disagreement between them regarding the terms of the purchase and supply of merchandise, result in disputes or conflicts which may adversely impact our ability to continue sourcing a particular brand or from a particular brand partner.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to certain risks in connection with the quality and timely delivery of our pre-order private label merchandise and our relationships with the manufacturers of such merchandise.
Subsubsection Text: A small share of our sales relates to our private label merchandise, which we source, for example, from brand partners in Turkey, Spain, Portugal, India, and China. These brand partners may also manufacture merchandise for our competitors and their brand partners. Our agreements with the manufacturers of our private label merchandise, which set forth the production and delivery of private label merchandise, are typically based on an order-by-order concept for each private label brand rather than long-term supply agreements. In case an agreement with a private label brand partner is terminated, there can be no assurance that we will find other brand partners that will be able to produce comparable replacement merchandise for us at competitive prices or at all. A small share of our buying activities is with relatively small-scale third-party intermediaries. Particularly goods purchased from such intermediaries have an increased risk of infringing intellectual property rights of third parties. Certain brands have in the past alleged that we have sold merchandise which infringes upon their intellectual property, and as a result, we found out that in certain minor cases the merchandise sold did infringe third party intellectual property rights. In such cases, the recourse that we have against such intermediaries may not be viable, as they tend to have little economical substance. As we sell branded products at reduced prices, counterfeit merchandise may harm our reputation and lead to loss of trust and customers. Since we only have limited control over manufacturers of our private label merchandise, there is no guarantee that this merchandise will continue to meet our specifications. Furthermore, any breach or perceived breach of relevant laws, regulations, permits, or licenses relating to the private label merchandise sold by us, or failure to achieve or maintain particular ethical business practices and standards, including with respect to environmental, social, and corporate governance (“ESG”) matters, could also lead to adverse publicity, which could materially adversely affect the reputation of our private label brands, or even the Group, damage our customer relationships and lead to a decline in our sales. As we are the “responsible person” for our private label merchandise within the context of the applicable regulations on product safety applicable to our merchandise, any quality defect could lead (on the basis of EU law or similar applicable national laws) to customer claims, administrative or criminal proceedings and penalties. We could also face damage to our own private label brands’ reputation. In addition, if the manufacturing, delivery, or supply chain management processes relating to our private label or other merchandise are disrupted for any reason, we may be delayed in restoring our inventory of the affected private label or other products and we may experience a significant increase in our cost of sales.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face certain risks in relation to our e-commerce business.
Subsubsection Text: We face certain risks in relation to our e-commerce business including the functioning of hardware and software, customer acceptance and the integration with our offline business and logistics infrastructure. We generate a majority of our revenue from sales of merchandise over the internet via our e-commerce platform, BestSecret. Our e-commerce operations are subject to numerous risks, including: - reliance on third parties for computer hardware and software, the need to keep up with rapid technological change and the implementation of new systems and platforms; - the risk that our e-commerce platform may become unstable or unavailable due to necessary upgrades or the failure of our computer systems or the related IT support systems or that customer data may be misappropriated as a result of computer viruses, telecommunication failures, electronic break-ins and similar disruptions, or disruption of internet service, whether for technical reasons or for other causes; 38 ----- - customers finding our e-commerce websites difficult to use or online applications are not compatible with certain electronic devices, being less willing to use our websites than we expect, being unwilling to share personal information online or via our mobile applications, or not being confident that they are secure; - the incurrence of unexpected costs in connection with the maintenance and future development of our e-commerce platform; - liability for online content, security breaches and consumer privacy concerns; - lack of ability to honor our usual delivery terms in case of an unexpected or a higher than expected spike in customer orders or for other reasons that may cause negative reputational consequences; - negative online reviews (including social media posts) from dissatisfied customers which may deter other potential customers from using our e-commerce platform and that may also affect our brands’ reputation and sales in our offline stores; - lack of ability to communicate with our customers using e-mail or other means due to failed or delayed delivery of such e-mails for technical reasons, lack of interest by customers or marking as “spam” or “junk”; - dissatisfaction from certain customers using e-mail or other means when exposed to too many advertising campaigns or newsletters and to what they may consider to be e-mail or text message “flooding”; - actions by third parties to block, impose restrictions on or charge for the delivery of e-mails or other messages, as well as legal or regulatory changes limiting our right to send such messages or imposing additional requirements on us in connection with them, could impair our ability to communicate with customers; - liability for online credit card fraud and problems adequately securing our payment systems; and - increased competition from other e-commerce providers. Our failure to respond appropriately to these risks and uncertainties could reduce our revenue (in particular, our revenue from our e-commerce operations) as well as damage our reputation and brands, especially since e-commerce is a significant part of our growth strategy. The realization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our operations may be interrupted or otherwise adversely affected as a result of failures in our IT systems.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends on the continuous and uninterrupted availability of our IT systems, particularly to process customer transactions and to manage inventory levels, purchases and deliveries of our merchandise. Over the past few years, we have developed a sophisticated IT system which supports our apps and websites, customer service, supplier connectivity, communications and the monitoring of customer sales and improved management of inventories. As our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we need to continuously improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure to offer an increasing number of user-enhanced services, features and functionalities, while maintaining or improving the reliability and integrity of our systems and infrastructure. A range of factors beyond our control, such as telecommunication problems, software errors, inadequate capacity at IT centers, fire, power outages or damage, attacks by third parties, computer viruses and the delayed or failed implementation of new computer systems, could interfere with the availability of our IT systems. Any material disruption or slowdown of our systems could cause information, including data related to purchases of merchandise, to be lost or delayed which could result in delays in the delivery of products to customers or lost sales or impair our ability to manage our inventories. Our existing safety systems, data backup, access protection, user management and IT emergency planning may not be sufficient to prevent information loss or disruptions to our IT systems. In addition, if changes in technology cause our IT systems to become obsolete, or if our IT systems are inadequate to handle our growth, our reputation among our customers may be damaged. Any failure to properly guard against the interruption or malfunctioning of our IT systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. 39 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Failure to secure or preserve the value of our brand partners’ brand equity could negatively impact our financial results.
Subsubsection Text: We depend in large part on our relationships with and a supply of merchandise from our brand partners. To maintain these relationships and ensure a supply of merchandise from our brand partners, we must secure and preserve the commercial value that derives from consumer perception of the merchandise produced by our brand partners, _i.e., their brand equity. Such brand equity is based on a variety of factors, including level of public awareness of a brand, quality perceptions regarding the brand and the perception of exclusivity surrounding the brand. The brand equity of our brand partners could diminish significantly due to a number of factors, for example through lowered customer perceptions of brand value or exclusivity due to their brands being offered through off-price online platforms, including our BestSecret online platform. Negative publicity, including, but not limited to, negative online reviews on social media from dissatisfied customers or media reports related to our offering whether or not accurate, can deter other potential customers from using our e-commerce platform, which could in turn lead to a negative impact on the value of the brand equity of our brand partners through their association with our platform. If our brand partners perceive a negative impact on their brand equity as a result of their partnership with us, they may choose to lower the amount of merchandise they make available to us for purchase or terminate their partnership with us entirely, which could have an adverse material effect on the attractiveness of our offering to our customers and consequently on our financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our strategy to continue to expand our business in Germany and internationally may fail or advance at a slower pace than planned.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our online penetration in existing markets and expansion into new markets may be affected if we fail to adapt our offering to local consumer requirements, if we fail to source sufficient merchandise to attract new customers and retain existing customers or if we fail to adequately scale the supporting operational infrastructure. The success of our expansion may also be affected if we fail to correctly estimate customer demand in local markets. This risk may be higher in new markets in which we operate, where our less established position makes it more difficult to assess customer demand and the appeal of our product offering. Our capital and other expenditures may also be higher than expected due to cost overruns, unexpected delay, or other unforeseen factors. Furthermore, the start of the conflict in Ukraine has negatively impacted and could continue to negatively impact our ability to expand in Germany and internationally due to the pressure the conflict has placed and could continue to place on our supply chain and costs. In addition, if we fail to execute our expansion strategy in a discreet manner, our brand partner relationships may deteriorate, and we may lose certain brand partners. If our expansion strategy is not successful or advances at a slower pace than planned, our competitive position and our profitability and growth may be negatively affected. In addition, any failure by us to anticipate or respond to market demand, control our operating costs, or otherwise effectively address any challenges that arise as we attempt to implement our strategy, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to manage our growing business activities effectively.
Subsubsection Text: Our business has grown significantly over the last decade, and we plan to continue to expand our business. Our historical growth may not be indicative of our future performance. As we implement our growth strategy, operating complexity will increase and will require a continuous expansion and improvement of our operating capabilities in addition to further training and management of our employees. Developing and refining the appropriate processes necessitated by our growth and our increasingly complex group structure, such as internal management, accounting and book-keeping processes, organizational compliance and risk monitoring structures, places high demands on us and our management, as well as on our operational and financial infrastructure, with no assurance that profitability will increase accordingly. As our operations grow further, we will need to continue to improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure to deal with the greater scale and complexity of operations. We will also need to be able to purchase more off-price products that we can offer and are therefore dependent on sufficient overproduction from brand partners who are willing to sell their products to us. Any delay in improving these processes or reaching an appropriate level of staffing may result in business and administrative oversights and errors, which may also lead to higher operating expenses. We cannot assure you we will be able to achieve any of the foregoing. If we are unable to achieve any or all of the foregoing, we could fail to take full or partial advantage of growth opportunities available to us, and as a result, our business would grow at a slower rate than may otherwise be possible. In addition, our growth could make it difficult for us to adequately predict the expenditures we will need to make in the future. This growth could also impact the operational flexibility of the 40 ----- supply chain organization and impair our ability to react promptly to changing customer demands and new market trends. If we do not make the necessary capital or other expenditures to accommodate our future growth, we may not be successful in our growth strategy. Continued growth may also strain our ability to maintain reliable service levels for our customers, may impede our efforts to attract, train, motivate and retain employees, or complicate our plans to develop and improve our operational, financial and management controls. Specifically, in certain regions, continued growth could result in our business, including fulfillment services sourced from third parties, being unable to accommodate the number of customers or orders, e.g., if our service providers’ fulfillment centers begin to operate at or near capacity. Due to the increasing levels of utilization of our existing fulfillment and returns centers, we are currently planning a new fulfillment center in Sulechów, Poland to provide us with additional flexibility and to address further future growth. Any unexpected delays in the opening of the new fulfillment center, including as a result of delays in or failure to obtain financing to fund our expansion, could harm our ability to scale the business as planned and could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our growing business will also lead to an increase in logistical complexity as well as shipping and fulfillment center costs. Increased logistical complexity contains the risk that it will be more challenging to maintain our operations at the current level and that more unforeseen interruptions and issues could arise that in turn lead to higher shipping and fulfillment center costs, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. We may be unable to accurately anticipate all the demands that our expanding operations will impose on our business, personnel, systems and controls and procedures, and the failure to appropriately address such demands, or the realization of any of the above-mentioned risks, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our compliance management system and internal controls may not be sufficient to adequately protect us from all legal or financial risks, especially with regards to our business in certain countries where corruption and money laundering may be considered widespread.
Subsubsection Text: To protect us against legal risks and other potential harm, we established a group-wide, centralized compliance management system that comprises several specific compliance programs (e.g., anti-corruption, anti-money laundering, fraud prevention and conflict of interest, economic sanctions compliance and antitrust as well as human rights), including a group-wide Code of Conduct which outlines the general rules of behavior for our management and employees as well as our business ethics. Our central compliance function is carried out by our legal department and our managing directors and is complemented by external law firms. Direct reporting lines to the management board and the advisory board are set up. Yet, these codes, guidelines and policies and the oversight of our internal compliance and legal departments might not be sufficient to prevent all unauthorized practices, legal infringements, corruption, and fraud—especially regarding purchasing practices—or other adverse consequences of non-compliance within our organization or by or on behalf of our employees or third parties. Any compliance failure could harm our reputation and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. To comply with legal requirements as well as to achieve our corporate goals efficiently and effectively, as an integrated part of the Corporate Governance structure, we established a formally documented group-wide risk management system. Having a well-defined and uniform Risk Management System in place allows us to recognize, assess, manage and monitor risks that might potentially threaten our operations now and in the future. Through early detection of risks-related issues and implementation of suitable countermeasures we minimize our risk exposure. Our central risk management is carried out by the risk manager, who represents the link between the risk owners, managing directors and the advisory board, and continuously develops and improves our Risk Management System to ensure its completeness and correctness. However, as we operate in a very dynamic environment, our risk management system and periodical risk assessment might not be sufficient to ensure that all potential events impacting our organization are timely identified and promptly mitigated, also due to risks characteristic that their probability of occurrence and potential impact on organization cannot be determined with certainty. To identify, monitor and control internal risks related to our business processes we established a group-wide internal control system. Within dedicated risk-control-matrixes we document the risks and corresponding controls for all relevant business processes with a particular focus on those processes located at the interface with external parties, such as merchandise buying. Still, our current internal controls, prevention (such as our anti-corruption policy) and training programs may prove to be insufficient. Our employees, agents or authorized persons may have been or could be engaged in activities for which we could be held liable on different legal grounds. We 41 ----- conduct business in, and may expand our business to, certain countries where corruption may be considered to be widespread. As a result, we are exposed to the risk that our employees, agents or other authorized persons could make payments or grant hidden benefits in violation of anti-corruption laws and regulations, especially in response to demands or attempts by individuals or entities to procure an illicit monetary benefit. Most laws and regulations promulgated against corruption and money laundering require us to implement certain controls, procedures, and internal regulations in order to ensure that the operations of a given entity do not involve corruption, illegal payments, or money-laundering. Although we engage in know-your-customer activities, the great diversity and complexity of these local laws and regulations and the expansive nature of the business conducted by us in various countries and markets create a risk that we may be deemed liable for violations of local laws and regulations. We are also subject to regulations concerning consumer protection, data protection, unsolicited commercial communications, general terms and conditions of contract, tax, child protection and telecommunications. Any violation or breach of these laws and regulations could affect our overall reputation and, depending on the case, expose us to administrative, criminal or civil proceedings, which could result in criminal and administrative fines and sanctions, confiscations and asset forfeitures, including possible prohibitions on maintaining business relationships with brand partners, fashion or lifestyle brands or customers in certain countries, which could have material adverse effects on the implementation of our business strategy as well as on our financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to numerous laws and regulations with respect to data protection and failure to comply with such laws and regulations may result in litigation and administrative or arbitration proceedings and/or significantly damage our relationship with our customers.
Subsubsection Text: We process sensitive customer data as part of our members-only business model. A fundamental requirement for online commerce and communications is the secure handling and transmission of confidential information, including credit card information, over public networks. We cannot exclude that advances in computer capabilities, new discoveries in the field of cryptography or other developments will not compromise or breach the systems we use to protect transactional and personal data. Both local and international laws and regulations govern our collection, use, retention, sharing and security of this personal data, including the GDPR which is effective since May 25, 2018. We as a data controller must implement specific technical and organizational measures to protect the personal data we collect depending on the amount of and potential risk for the personal data processed. In order to comply with the GDPR, we have also implemented a data protection organization. Among others, we have installed an external data protection officer. This officer monitors all measures associated with data protection, including group-wide training for existing and new employees. A breach of the GDPR or a failure to comply with other applicable data protection laws or regulations could have an adverse impact on our reputation and could lead to us becoming subject to governmental investigations, fines, and private claims for compensation from individuals whose personal data was involved. In the event of such a personal data breach, we could be required to notify applicable government authorities (within a certain time period) and/or potential victims if the breach in question may pose a high risk to the rights of these victims. This could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position (e.g., the GDPR provides severe fines in case of infringements of up to €20 million or 4% of global turnover on a group basis, whichever is greater and depending on the respective breach for non-compliance with GDPR provisions). The need to comply with data protection legislation is a significant controlling, operational and reputational risk which can affect us in a number of ways including, for example, making it more difficult to maintain and expand our marketing data and also through potential litigation relating to the alleged misuse of personal data. While we have taken out cyber-security insurance, it cannot be certain that our insurance coverage concerning this and other risks will be adequate for liabilities that we might actually incur or that such insurance will continue to be available to us on economically reasonable terms, or at all. New and more stringent data protection laws, regulations or developments and changes in consumer behavior could interfere with our strategies to use privacy-related information for our marketing efforts and could also have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations. Current case law may also change our strategies. For example, the recent “Schrems II” ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union of July 16, 2020, provides that special care and safeguards must be taken when transferring personal data to countries outside the EU/EEA. This decision has greatly increased the legal requirements imposed on data exporters for transfers of personal data from EU-countries to non-EU countries, 42 ----- which are deemed to have an inadequate data protection level compared to the standards imposed in the EEA (including, amongst others, the United States). Ensuring compliance with changing and/or stricter standards requires resources to continuously review and, as necessary, replace, amend, or supplement the international data transfer mechanisms which we currently rely on, including corporate binding rules, standard contractual clauses, and adequate data processing agreements with our business partners. The resulting mechanisms and procedures may increase the expenses associated with our overall compliance with personal data protection requirements or even require us to discontinue using certain tools that are relevant to our business. Any non-compliance, including as a result of our use of Google Analytics and Amazon Web Services, could result in potentially significant regulatory and/or governmental investigations and/or actions, litigation, fines, sanctions, and damage to our reputation. Furthermore, existing, and future decisions by local governmental regulators may also impact the application of the GDPR. For example, in January 2022, the Austrian Data Protection Authority issued a decision that a company’s use of Google Analytics contravenes the GDPR with regard to potential data transfers to the US. Complying with such decisions could impose further costs on us and limit our ability to use data analytics software to support our operations. Additionally, significant modifications in other data protection laws or regulations in countries in which we operate may consequently lead to us incurring higher costs or having to change our business practices. Compliance will become more complex and involve higher costs and the increasing risk of noncompliance may give rise to civil liability, administrative orders (including injunctive relief), fines or even criminal charges. Unauthorized data disclosure could occur through cyber security breaches as a result of human error, external hacking, malware infection, malicious or accidental user activity, internal security breaches or physical security breaches due to unauthorized personnel gaining physical access. If we or any third-party service providers on which we may rely fail to transmit customer information in a secure manner, or if any such loss of personal customer data were otherwise to occur, we could face liability under data protection laws. Any such disclosure could cause consumers to lose confidence in the security of our websites and deter future purchases. Any failure to comply with local and international laws governing personal data or to protect our data from being misappropriated could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face a risk of theft or misappropriation of funds and products in our stores, our centralized fulfillment center.
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of our business, we have been in the past and in the future may be exposed to a risk of theft of merchandise in our stores. Merchandise has and may in the future continue to also be misappropriated during transportation or at our fulfillment center and those of our logistic partners. In addition, we have and may in the future continue to experience a misappropriation of funds in our stores or at other levels of our business. Moreover, we have a customer friendly return policy. It cannot be excluded that, in the future, a growing number of customers may abuse our returns policy and, for example, return merchandise bought from other retailers.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our user metrics and other estimates are subject to inherent challenges in measurement, and inaccuracies in those metrics could have an adverse impact on our business, results of operations, and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We regularly review metrics, including but not limited to active users, new customers and average order value, frequency, and quantity, to evaluate growth trends, measure our performance, and make strategic decisions. These metrics are calculated using internal systems and tools that are not independently verified by any third party and the metrics have not been validated by an independent third party. Our internal systems and tools have a number of limitations, and our methodologies for tracking these metrics may change over time, which could result in unexpected changes to our metrics, including the metrics we publicly disclose on an ongoing basis. If the internal systems and tools we use to track these metrics undercount or over count performance or contain algorithmic or other technical errors, the data we present may not be accurate. While these numbers are based on what we believe to be reasonable estimates of our user base for the applicable period of measurement, there are inherent challenges in measuring how our platform is used. Errors or inaccuracies in our metrics or data could result in incorrect business decisions and inefficiencies. For example, there are individuals who have multiple accounts on our platform. A user is separately identified on our platform by a unique e-mail address; a single person could have multiple accounts and can count as multiple distinct users. If a significant understatement or overstatement of active users were to occur, we may expend 43 ----- resources to implement unnecessary business measures or fail to take required actions to attract enough users to satisfy our growth strategies. Further, certain of the other information we collect from users, including personal data are self-reported and may differ from their actual data. Age and other demographic information may be inaccurate if our users provide us with incorrect or incomplete information regarding their age or other attributes or choose not to report this information. If we discover material inaccuracies in our user demographic metrics, we may inefficiently allocate our marketing budget or resources, which could seriously harm our business.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in customer return rates might increase our costs and harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: We have established return policies that permit our customers to return products within designated timeframes ranging from 14 to 30 days, depending on their membership status (30 days for Diamond customers, 21 days for Gold and 14 days for all others). Granting return rights is an important element for converting app and website visitors into customers, by providing our customers with the certainty that they will only be required to pay for those products that they want to keep. Moreover, we have a customer-friendly returns policy. It is possible that, in the future, a growing number of customers may abuse our returns policy and, for example, buy merchandise just to wear it once at a party and then return it, claiming it had arrived used. Further, we generally experience a higher return rate from customers who pay for our merchandise with invoices (in lieu of using standard payment platforms). Our failure to prevent abuse of our returns policy or to otherwise manage our returns policy could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position. Certain of our online customers, including online customers in Germany, have statutory rights with respect to the return of merchandise. We have in the past and could in the future experience a significant increase in returns— for example, due to customer dissatisfaction with our products or customer service, changes in customer behavior, decrease in purchasing power due to inflationary pressures or the abuse of our liberal return policy by persons not actually willing to purchase our products. In this case, we incur costs associated with returned goods, including costs associated with return processing and delivery, but may not receive revenue from returns or proceeds from sales of returned goods may not cover all costs incurred. There is no guarantee that we will be able to utilize returned goods in a cost-efficient manner—for example, by reselling them on our apps and websites. In addition, we bear the risk for damage or loss of the merchandise. Thus, any increase in returns would increase our costs with no corresponding increase in revenue. Continued growth is likely to increase the absolute number of returns, which may force us to allocate additional resources to the handling of such returns and may further complicate our operations. Furthermore, any modification of our return policies may result in customer dissatisfaction, which could harm our reputation, or lead to an increase in the number of returns, which could adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Environmental, social and governance matters may impact our business and reputation.
Subsubsection Text: There has been increased focus, by consumers, investors, employees, and other stakeholders, as well as by governmental and non-governmental organizations, on environmental, social and governance matters (“ESG”) generally and regarding the fashion industry specifically. Any failure by us to meet our ESG commitments or targets, or loss of confidence, or inability to meet expectations with our ESG commitments on the part of customers, investors, employees, brand partners, and other stakeholders as it relates to our ESG initiatives could negatively impact our brand, our brand partner relationships, and the demand for our offerings. These impacts could be difficult and costly to overcome, even if such concerns were based on inaccurate or misleading information. Furthermore, while we believe we have an inherently sustainable business model (as most of the articles we sell are overstock and our model aims to ensure that every piece of fashion that has been produced and is fit-to-wear finds an owner), it is possible that our model will not be perceived as sustainable by customers, investors, employees, brand partners, and other stakeholders. If their perceptions of the sustainability of our model are negative, this could also negatively impact our business and reputation. In addition, achieving our ESG initiatives may result in increased costs in our supply chain, fulfillment, and/or corporate business operations. Standards regarding environmental, social, and governance initiatives could change and become more onerous for both for us and our third-party brand partners to meet successfully. Evolving data and research could undermine or refute our current claims and beliefs that we have made in reliance on current research, which could also result in additional costs or a decrease in revenue, and negative market perception that could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition. 44 ----- A variety of organizations measure the performance of companies on such ESG topics, and the results of these assessments are widely publicized. In addition, investment in funds that specialize in companies that perform well in such assessments are increasingly popular, and major institutional investors have publicly emphasized the importance of such ESG measures to their investment decisions. Topics taken into account in such assessments include, among others, a company’s efforts and impacts on climate change and human rights, ethics and compliance with law and the role of a company’s board of directors in supervising various sustainability issues. In light of investors’ increased focus on ESG matters, there can be no certainty that we will manage such issues successfully, or that we will successfully meet society’s ESG expectations or achieve our financial goals. As part of our commitment to ESG matters, we are planning to introduce specific, quantifiable key performance indicators. If we fail to meet the targets of these or other key performance indicators, we may suffer reputational damage, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Dissatisfaction with our convenience proposition could negatively affect our customer retention and the implementation of our growth strategy.
Subsubsection Text: A satisfied, loyal customer base is crucial for our ongoing expansion. Based on our members-only business model, attracting new customers depends in part on word-of-mouth and the recommendations of existing customers to expand our customer base. We therefore must ensure that existing customers are satisfied with our convenience proposition, including content creation, usability of our online platform and app, check-out process, payment options, packaging and shipping and customer service, so that those customers continue to recommend us. Should our efforts to satisfy existing customers be unsuccessful, we may fail to continue expanding our business or may be obliged to incur significant marketing and development expenditure to attract new customers. For example, reliable customer support is vital to ensure that customer complaints are processed within appropriate timeframes and under satisfactory conditions. Providing this support requires that our customer support personnel have fashion, retail, technical, and other necessary knowledge and expertise, making it difficult for us to hire qualified personnel and scale our support operations. The demand on our customer service organization will increase as we expand our business and pursue new customers, and such increased support could require us to devote significant development services and support personnel to our customer service teams, which could strain our team and infrastructure and reduce our profit margins. Any absence of a response or an unsatisfactory response to customer queries or complaints, whether founded or perceived as such, may have a detrimental impact on customer loyalty and satisfaction as well as our reputation, particularly if customers make negative comments on blogs, social media, or through online ratings and reviews. We may not be able to verify or adequately respond to such negative comments, ratings or reviews. An inability to retain customers and earn their loyalty, or to identify, follow up and respond to customer complaints and online comments due to customer service failings, may have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks associated to the payment options we offer.
Subsubsection Text: We currently offer different payment methods tailored to meet our customers’ payment preferences, including credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and purchase by invoice. We face the risk of operational failures during the check-out process in our e-commerce platform as well as our retail stores relating to the complexity of certain payment methods. Such difficulties could adversely affect our conversion rate which is the proportion of site visitors that actually complete the purchasing process. We may also become subject to additional or changing regulations regarding certain payment methods, such as the operating rules and certification requirements of payment scheme associations and rules governing electronic funds transfers, which apply to payment cards, whether in general or in a particular country in which we operate. We may also become subject to more stringent or complex compliance requirements, for example with respect to our vouchers. For the processing of all our current payment methods we pay different fees to our payment method providers. It is possible that some of these fees would increase over time, causing our expenses to rise. In the case of invoice payments, even though the default risk currently lies with our service provider, a high non-payment rate will lead to either increased costs for us or a lowered acceptance rate for customers using this payment method. Furthermore, different payment options have different costs to us (e.g., PayPal is much more expensive than direct debit) and should customers shift their preferences in favor of the more expensive payment methods, then our expenses would rise accordingly. Furthermore, various types of fraud committed through payments may increase our overall cost. These types of fraud vary, and range from account take-overs, usage of stolen credit cards, fake identities, fake bank accounts, to “almost legal fraud” like voucher abusing or the creation of multiple accounts to take advantage of our loyalty system. In case of excessive fraud events relating to credit card transactions, in addition to the direct losses, we 45 ----- could enter the card schemes’ chargeback monitoring programs, where we could incur extra fees and even lose the right to accept cards altogether. For online payments, primary liability for fraud generally lies with the party with the lowest security standards, which, in most cases, is the merchant. While strong authentication methods such as two-factor authentication, can help us alleviate some of this risk, we consciously elect to forego the strongest authentication methods because the added hurdle for the customer would detract from a seamless customer experience. Further, some payment methods, such as unsecured direct debits, have by design no authorization mechanism and thus we bear significant risk. Failure to adequately balance a seamless and streamlined customer experience with adequate security and anti-fraud protections could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We might be exposed to tax risks or tax liabilities resulting from deviating interpretations of applicable tax laws or tax audits or a challenge of the transfer pricing model by the tax authorities.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to routine tax field audit (Außenprüfung) by local tax authorities (i.e., _Finanzamt Abt. _Körperschaften) in Munich. This audit for the years 2014 to 2017 commenced in November 2020 and was_ formally completed in May 2022 by final assessments. The audit included all German entities of the BestSecret Group, and included the acquisition by PrestigeBidCo GmbH in the 2016-2017 period and yielded payments due covered by provisions. Furthermore, tax audits for periods or jurisdictions not yet subject to a tax audit may exceed the taxes already paid by us or reflected in our Consolidated Financial Statements. As a result, we may be required to make additional tax payments with respect to previous periods. Moreover, the competent tax authorities could revise their original tax assessments. Any tax assessments that deviate from our expectations could lead to an increase in our tax burden. In addition, we may be required to pay interest on these additional taxes as well as late filing penalties.
