Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the off-price market with a focus on mid-market to luxury fashion in Europe. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio of around 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a discreet and controlled channel and protecting their brand equity. With a heritage going back nearly 100 years, we have evolved from an offline retail business to a tech-driven online platform. We offer a wide range of midmarket to luxury fashion brands at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80%, providing a permanent assortment of approximately 250,000 items at any moment in time. Our online offering is available in multiple languages and in 27 European countries. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we generated revenue of 78 ----- €996.3 million, an Adjusted EBITDA of €131.4 million and an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.2%. Our online revenue, which accounted for 91.7% of total revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, grew at a CAGR of 41.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022. While 70.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 was generated in Germany, our international business outside of Germany continues to gain in importance relative to our Germany business and experienced strong revenue growth of 86.3% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 (with a CAGR of 62.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Growth of the European online fashion market and the off-price sector
Subsubsection Text: Our target market is currently experiencing favorable structural trends. We operate in the European online fashion market for mid-market to luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price sector. We have also expanded into the discounted in-season and end-of-season sector. The overall European fashion market (excluding the U.K. and Russia) amounted to €310 billion in revenue in the year ended December 31, 2021 based on analysis prepared by a leading international consultancy firm and the Company. We operate in the dedicated online off-price sector and discounted in-season and end-of-season sector, which amounted to €44 billion in revenue across Europe (excluding the U.K. and Russia) in the year ended December 31, 2021 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 12% from 2021 to 2025 based on analysis prepared by a leading international consultancy firm and the Company. In recent years, we have transformed into a primarily online platform for off-price premium products. Revenue from our online operations nearly doubled between the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2021 as a result of continued customer growth, strong international business development and an accelerated shift towards e-commerce during the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of this growth, our online sales represented 93.0% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021, as compared to 77% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019. From January 1, 2019 to December 31, 2021, our number of active online customers increased at a CAGR of 35%. We plan to maintain a limited physical presence of premium and outlet stores in strategic locations designed primarily to support our online platform, with offline revenue expected to remain a limited percentage of our total revenue. In the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, governments across Europe imposed measures that resulted in the temporary closure of stores as well as strict social distancing rules and hygiene regulations between periods of closure. These closures had an adverse impact on our customer sales at offline stores, including at our retail stores in Dresden, Munich, Dornach and Vienna. The German offline retail sector decreased by 30% and 12% during the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, compared to the previous year due to government-enforced store closures, the ongoing consumer shift away from offline platforms to online platforms, and low frequency in customer store visits (Textilwirtschaft). In contrast, the German online fashion retail sector increased by 21% and 16% in the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, compared to the previous year. The European online fashion market (excluding the U.K., Russia and Turkey) achieved revenue of €107 billion and €119 billion in the year ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, which was an increase of 29% and 11%, respectively, over the previous year (Statista). While we believe that our business model is resilient to minor general economic effects, it is possible that unfavorable macroeconomic events in Germany, and more broadly in Europe, may have a negative effect on the growth of the European online fashion market and impact our customers and our results of operations. These include factors that may affect consumer spending such as unemployment levels, inflation, wage rates, availability of consumer credit and consumer confidence. For example, recent geopolitical tensions resulting from the Russian invasion of Ukraine have destabilized the global economy and will potentially have a wide range of supply chain implications, including increases in the costs of merchandise and disruption in freight transport. 79 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our ability to secure an attractive variety and quantity of products
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations and profitability depend, to a considerable extent, on our ability to source and sell a desirable and fresh mix of merchandise at attractive prices. We need to continuously source a variety and quantity of merchandise from sought-after brands in a cost-effective manner. Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model creates the opportunity for our suppliers to ensure that their overstock is sold in a discreet and controlled environment, protecting their retail pricing strategies and the desirability of their brands while allowing them to maximize value for their overstock. Our model allows us to clearly distinguish ourselves from other fashion clearance channels such as online shopping clubs, factory outlet centers or other retail wholesalers has made us an attractive and preferred partner and facilitates our early access to high-quality inventory at favorable prices. Developments in the retail fashion industry, combined with the seasonal nature of our suppliers’ industry, may impact the timing of our merchandise procurement and the prices at which we can procure such merchandise. For example, favorable economic conditions in the fashion industry typically lead to increases in production volumes by our suppliers and, consequently, may result in greater availability of overstock merchandise in the market and an opportunity to source such excess overstock merchandise at better prices. In contrast, extended periods of financial uncertainty or decreases in consumer spending may cause our suppliers to reduce their production, thereby limiting the amount of merchandise on the market and negatively affecting the prices at which we can purchase overstock merchandise. Sufficient availability of overstock in the market can be adversely affected by supply chain disruptions, changes to the distribution plans of our brand partners or an overall decline in the fashion market. For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine in late February 2022 has and will potentially continue to have a wide range of supply chain implications, including increases in cost and disruption in freight transport. Similarly, the lockdowns and the temporary port closures in China due to the COVID-19 pandemic have and will potentially continue to lead to lower availability of overstock because merchandise is not able to be produced or is stuck in transit. See “Risk _Factors—_ _Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Our business depends on our ability to continuously source and present a variety and quantity of attractive products from various popular brands at attractive prices that will satisfy our customers’ preferences and demands.”_ In addition, weather conditions can impact the timing and availability of merchandise. A mild autumn or a cold spring may negatively impact the sale of winter and summer merchandise, respectively, by our suppliers. This may lead to the earlier availability of merchandise but may also result in our need to lower prices to follow price reductions by our suppliers online and in their high street retail locations. We have the ability to purchase large quantities of merchandise, including mixed lots, which are lots that do not contain a typical distribution of sizes and colors, increasing our value as counterparty to our suppliers. As a result, we are often the first choice of our suppliers, reinforcing our customer proposition by giving us preferential access to desirable merchandise. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our cost of sales was 53.1% of our revenue, due to measured price reductions to support sales during market uncertainties resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, a lower spring/summer merchandise level and a late onset of fall/winter season at the end of the three months ended September 30, 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2021, cost of sales was higher, at 54.4% of our revenue, due to the improved customer proposition with a larger and more attractive merchandise offering. For the three months ended March 31, 2022, cost of sales was at 57.0% of our revenue, due to overall market conditions and business growth as well as a shift to more premium and luxury brands, inflation, supply chain shortage and low overstock availability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our pricing strategy is to offer products to our customers at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80% of the recommended retail price. Some of the various factors which influence our pricing strategy are beyond our control, including market conditions, overstock availability, and demand. For example, inflationary pressure may impact consumer purchasing power while geopolitical uncertainty and price volatility could lead to a decrease in consumer confidence and spending. Pricing of our products more broadly has a direct impact on our revenue and profitability margin. An effective pricing strategy ensures optimal timing and pricing levels for a product as it moves through the different markdown stages, thereby maximizing its revenue and profit contribution. Conversely, if we fail to manage our pricing strategy adequately, we may lose sales and forfeit profitability. An effective markdown strategy improves the quality of our inventory by ensuring efficient stock turnover. Continuous improvements of our pricing strategy and our pricing-related technology, including a machine learning program for automatic pricing, have contributed 80 ----- to our revenue growth from the year ended December 31, 2019 to March 31, 2022 and, we believe, help us to maintain healthy EBITDA margins even in challenging market conditions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our closed membership model and our loyalty program – the VIP Program – are designed to trigger invitations (and therefore viral new customer acquisition) by rewarding customers for successfully inviting other members. Our “viral engine” model, in which existing customers invite new customers, generates substantial topline growth every year. New viral customers (customers who have been invited by existing customers) are the primary drivers of our year-on-year structural revenue growth and an important driver for our expansion. Our online business has grown at a CAGR of over 22% from the year ended December 31, 2016 to the year ended December 31, 2020. Moreover, the viral engine is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue being spent annually on viral engine-related expenses (e.g., commission vouchers). To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the second quarter of 2021. Our paid marketing efforts allow us to invite potential new members to join our closed membership model so that they can drive viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral engine. Our paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer demographics and regions to drive our non-viral growth, especially in areas with currently low penetration (such as Northern Germany and international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly favorable marketing efficiency ratio (defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy divided by marketing spend) and has maintained short payback periods while scaling marketing investment. As a result of our paid marketing strategy, which has included a 2.0x increased marketing spend as a percentage of revenue in the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2022, we experienced a significant increase in the number of total new customers in the year ended December 31, 2021. The customer base we gain from our paid marketing strategy is supported by subsequent viral growth in the customer base, resulting in strong marketing efficiency with €6.40 in incremental revenue per €1.00 in marketing spend in the year ended December 31, 2021. See “Our Business—Marketing—Paid customer acquisition.” Our efficient marketing efforts allow us to scale our marketing significantly and maintain short payback periods: (1) Payback period as period after first order of a new customer when CAC equals LTV. LTV (lifetime value) defined as cumulative PCII per customer since first order. PCII defined as gross profit minus fulfillment, payment and customer care costs. CAC (customer acquisition costs) defined as total marketing expenses divided by total number of new customers. The expenses we incur for our viral customer growth model, such as commission vouchers earned by customers for successfully inviting other members, are reflected as sales deductions within revenue. The expenses of marketing activities, including our paid customer acquisition strategy, are included in our selling and distribution expenses. In the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, we incurred marketing expenses of €10.8 million, €9.4 million and €49.0 million, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: A variety of payment options is an important aspect of the shopping experience for our customers. We offer different payment methods tailored to meet our members’ payment preferences, both in our offline retail stores and our online platform, including credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and pay-by-invoice 81 ----- (“buy-now-pay-later”). We are also focusing on making more local payments methods available to our customers. Furthermore, we tailor our payment solutions by customer type and offer certain payment options, such as pay-by-invoice, only to customers who have a sufficient purchase history with us. Customers’ choices of payment method can have a significant effect on our profitability. For example, revenue can vary by up to 2% based on the payment methods available in Germany. In addition, certain payment options can have better order economics than others, for example through lower return rates. On an ongoing basis, we plan to invest more into understanding the effects of payment options and encouraging our customers to choose certain payment options over others.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our fulfillment expenses, which are included in the selling and distribution expenses, comprise, among others, content creation, warehousing, handling and packaging, shipping costs, payment costs, customer service and return costs. Our fulfillment expenses are driven by a number of factors, in particular the revenue share of our online operations, the share of international shipping, the effectiveness of our fulfillment centers, capacity utilization, as well as shipping and last-mile delivery costs for third-party carriers who handle the delivery of our products. We primarily incur fulfillment expenses when we ship online orders from our fulfillment center. In the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, we incurred fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €88.3 million (15.5% of our revenue), €104.4 million (17.0% of our revenue) and €162.3 million (17.2% of our revenue), respectively. The movement in our fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) to revenue) in these periods was driven by the accelerated shift in our business towards online retail. Offline retail has a much lower fulfillment expenses ratio than online and, consequently, the decrease in the revenue share of our offline retail business has resulted in this structural increase in our fulfillment expenses ratio. Similarly, our shipping costs have increased as a result of the growing share of our international business. This increase in fulfillment expenses has been offset by positive impacts on our fulfillment expenses ratio from pandemic-related lower return rates in the year ended December 31, 2020, and for the first six months of 2021, as well as increased shipping efficiencies. We expect growth in our business to lead to an increase in the complexity of our logistics and, as a result, higher fulfillment expenses. For example, we expect an increase in our shipping costs per item as a result of the growing international share of our business. We also expect an increase in fulfillment center costs due to continued reliance on interim storage solutions first implemented during the six months ended December 31, 2021, and ramp-up effects of our second fulfillment center in Poland, which we expect to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023. We aim to partially offset these increases with targeted higher sales and the associated higher distribution volume of our products, optimized fulfillment expenses per item from economies of scale, and volume discounts despite price increases by some of our last-mile carriers. We expect that, combined with increased automation as well as process optimization, the resulting offsetting effect will decrease our fulfillment expenses base per item. Orders placed through our marketplace model, in which third-party brands sell their products through our platform, are mainly fulfilled by third-party sellers. As we scale our marketplace offering, we expect to grow our profitability margin as we receive revenue from marketplace sales while our fulfillment expenses with respect to those sales remain flat.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our result of operations and cash flows are influenced by our investments in technology and fulfillment center infrastructure. Our business depends significantly on our ability to process transactions on secure information systems and to store, retrieve, process and manage information. In the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, we invested €13.4 million, €10.5 million and €24.2 million, respectively, and in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and March 31, 2022, we invested € 4.4 million and € 7.3 million, respectively, in technology-related capital expenditures to strengthen our technological capabilities and in-house excellence. Our primary front-office technology systems are used to market products to end customers, to manage, track and deliver orders, and to monitor stock and interface with suppliers and other business relations. We have invested significantly in the overall user-experience of our customer-facing systems, as well as in marketing and analytics capabilities to boost customer acquisition, increase sales conversion, and manage churn. We updated our online 82 ----- platform to support multiple currencies and to be available in multiple languages. We also expanded the platform’s payment capabilities to provide better and more flexible options for different customer needs. In addition, we made investments in the scalability of the technology architecture across systems and processes, to support future growth of the business and to manage orders more efficiently. We are also investing in a revamp of our technology systems. We operate a modern fulfillment center in Poing, Germany, near Munich. By investing €15.6 million and €21.9 million in the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020, respectively, the facility was expanded by approximately 60% to support our growing business. The extended site now has a footprint of 48,000 square meters and can hold up to 15 million items of inventory. The site also features multi-channel processes and supplies our retail stores. We are in the process of launching our second fulfillment center in Poland, which we expect to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023. We anticipate that once this new fulfillment center is fully ramped up in 2024, it will approximately triple our current storage capacity at lower operating expense per item than our existing network.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Allowing our customers to easily receive, try on, and if required, return products free of charge is an important part of our value proposition to our customers, contributing to customer satisfaction, supporting customer conversion (from browsing to purchasing) and increasing customer lifetime value. A number of factors influence our return rates, such as products not matching their online description, issues with product quality, unexpected variations in sizes, or wrong items being shipped. In the year ended December 31, 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic also lowered our return rates, with a (temporary) shift in consumer focus to categories with structurally lower return rates, such as casual wear or kids clothing. Return rates also marginally decreased likely due to customers being less comfortable leaving their homes to return items. With the easing of pandemic-related restrictions and customers growing accustomed to changed circumstances, return rates have trended back towards pre-pandemic levels. We continuously seek to optimize our return rates and minimize the costs associated with our free return policy by focusing on the accuracy of our product descriptions, including size recommendations, and improving the visualizations of our products on our apps and websites, avoiding returns where possible. For example, we are developing technology which will enable us to further improve size recommendations. Furthermore, we focus on providing an efficient and reliable fulfillment process to make sure the right items are shipped and arrive in a timely fashion. In accordance with IFRS, we use our historical return rates to anticipate future returns and to deduct such anticipated returns from our revenue and cost of materials. If actual return rates turn out to be higher, we lose the corresponding share of revenue and profits. Approximately 99% of the products returned are recorded as inventory and are available for sale again having undergone a quality assessment to ensure the return products are in good order. We provision in our accounts for the expected loss margin from returns and approximately 1% of return products are damaged or otherwise not fit for sale.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the European online fashion market for mid-market to luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season sectors, which currently present several highly attractive market dynamics to participants. Our unique proposition provides us with the opportunity to continuously capture market share and participate in the structural growth momentum of our market. Our strategy for expansion into new international markets and to increase penetration in our existing markets is to: (1) identify and prioritize future growth markets, (2) localize our offering for specific markets, (3) use performance marketing campaigns to establish a customer base, and (4) achieve a viral status which in turn yields cyclical growth. We have diversified our geographic revenue streams, with the proportion of our revenue derived from our International segment steadily increasing, and amounting to 18.7%, 22.7% and 28.4% of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, and 25.7% and 32.8% in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and March 31, 2022, respectively. Our International segment revenue experienced a CAGR of 58% between the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2021, compared to a CAGR of 21% in our Germany segment revenue for the same period. The following chart demonstrates the accelerated top line and strong earnings that have resulted from our internalization strategy on a quarter over quarter basis. 83 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our core wholesale model through which we sell our own inventory of branded fashion merchandise at attractive discounts, we introduced a new marketplace model in the year ended December 31, 2021. Through our marketplace model, we offer third-party fashion brands the option to market their products on our BestSecret online platform without holding these products in our own inventory. We expect to achieve full scale operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022. We have already gained significant traction with our marketplace offering, with customers placing an increasing number of orders on a monthly basis since its inception. The new marketplace is one of the core pillars of our growth strategy. Our marketplace model has helped us expand into the market for discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion and we are well-positioned to provide our customers with a wider product assortment, which we expect to drive incremental revenue. We also expect the additional products to be from affordable luxury or luxury brands, who tend to prefer marketplace models that give them more control over merchandise presentation and prices. The expanded product selection could potentially contribute to an increase in order size and a reduction in the likelihood of products being out of stock, as we attract more sellers who hold their own stock in existing product categories. We believe that these features will further support our position as the go-to destination for online off-price fashion, increasing customer satisfaction and loyalty. Furthermore, we anticipate that the marketplace model will increase our profitability through commissions and marketing fees with attractive economics, while having limited inventory and working capital impact. We expect warehousing and fulfillment will typically remain in the hands of third-party suppliers. Our marketplace suppliers are also able to rely on us for fulfillment at their option, which will allow us to benefit from incremental commissions on third-party sales.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our business is seasonal, which is typical for retailers in the fashion industry. For example, we typically experience an increase in sales in the fourth quarter of the year due to several special sales events (e.g., Black Friday sale, Cyber Week sale and the Christmas shopping season). In the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue in the fourth quarter accounted for 34.2% of our total revenue for the year. In the three months ended December 31, 2020, and December 31, 2021, we experienced exceptional revenue growth due to the structural shift towards online shopping due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As the fashion market reaches an equilibrium between the online and offline sectors, we expect our fourth quarter revenue to grow at a slower rate. As a result of our seasonality of sales, any factors that harm our operating results during the fourth quarter of a year, including unfavorable economic conditions or uncertainties caused by the COVID-19 pandemic affecting consumer spending levels or inclement weather that deters customers from buying online or visiting our stores, could have a disproportionate effect on our results of operations for the full year. Our growth rate fluctuates from quarter to quarter, and we expect that it will continue to do so because of a variety of factors, including the timing and success of our international marketing activities, the share of sales driven by promotional activities, the launch of new categories and product types, seasonality and economic cycles that influence retail apparel purchase trends. Furthermore, our pricing is influenced by the seasonality of our industry and the impact of weather patterns and conditions. For example, if a fall/winter season is unusually warm, we may fail to sell some of the merchandise for the season, resulting in pricing pressure on the same merchandise in the following fall/winter season. 84 ----- In addition, our Operating Net Working Capital is affected by seasonal trading patterns. Our Operating Net Working Capital typically reaches a peak from June to September, with a minimum position in January after the Christmas season has passed.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations and the operating metrics discussed in this section have been, and may continue to be, affected by the key factors set forth below as well as certain historical and future events and actions. As many of these factors are beyond our control and certain of these factors have historically been volatile, past performance will not necessarily be indicative of future performance and it is difficult to predict future performance with any degree of certainty. See “Risk Factors.” We consider the following factors to be the principal drivers of our results of operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: We generate our revenue primarily from the sale of fashion merchandise on our BestSecret online platform and to a lesser extent from sales in our retail stores. Revenue is recognized upon delivery of the goods to the customer. Revenue is recorded net of sales deductions, taxes and duties. For transactions with a statutory 14-day or longer refund policy, the Issuer calculates the amount of the expected returns as of the reporting date based on historical return rates under consideration of the actual returns until the date of preparing the consolidated financial statements. We present the expected returns of goods on a gross basis and reduce revenue by the full number of sales that are estimated to be returned. The sale of goods that is recorded in full upon delivery of the goods is then corrected by the estimated number of returns. Commission vouchers earned by customers for successfully inviting other members represent a payment to customers and therefore a revenue reduction when redeemed by the customer. Revenue also includes revenue received from shipping fees charged to customers when merchandise is purchased online, and commissions received from our marketplace sales. Revenue is recognized within our two operating segments, Germany and International.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: Our cost of sales comprises primarily cost of goods sold, expenses for inbound logistics, allowances on inventories and other costs in connection with sales. Cost of goods sold equals expenses for goods sold less discounts and rebates granted by suppliers. Expenses for inbound logistics include all expenses incurred before the inventories are stored in the fulfillment centers and consist mainly of customs and incoming goods transport expenses. Allowances of inventories reflect write-downs of inventories to the net realizable value to account for risks from reduced demand or quality of the goods. Other cost of sales also covers cost for the storage of goods and expenses for depreciation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: Our selling and distribution expenses comprise marketing expenses, sales expenses and fulfillment expenses as well as amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses. Sales expenses primarily include payment costs and personnel expenses as well as incidental rental costs of the stores. Fulfillment expenses mainly consist of expenses for outbound and return logistics including personnel costs associated with these processes, delivery costs and deprecation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: Our administrative expenses comprise technology expenses and general administrative expenses. Administrative expenses largely consist of personnel expenses. The non-personnel costs primarily contain depreciation, licenses for software and maintenance fees as well as consultancy fees and sundry general administrative expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: Our other operating income mainly comprises compensations for damages, foreign exchange rate gains, rental income from sublease and sundry other operating income. COVID-19 related lockdown revenue compensation is also recognized in other operating income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses mainly consist of bad debt losses, foreign exchange rate losses, expenses relating to other periods and sundry other operating expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income
Subsubsection Text: Our financial income includes interest income on subleases, on tax refunds and sundry interest income. 85 -----

Subsubsection Text: Our financial expenses primarily include interest expenses on the Existing Notes. Interest expenses on any drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility as well as commitment fees related to the availability of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility also are reported in this position as well as interest on lease liabilities and interest expenses from the compounding of non-current provisions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Our revenue increased by €53.4 million, or 29.1%, from €183.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €236.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase was primarily driven by a continued expansion in our customer base, good order economics and an outstanding international business. _Cost of sales_ Our cost of sales increased by €34.7 million, or 34.6%, from €100.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, to €135.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to overall market conditions and business growth as well as a shift to more premium and luxury brands. Cost of sales as a percentage of revenue increased by 2.3% points from 54.7% for the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to the 57.0% for the three months ended March 31, 2022. _Selling and distribution expenses_ Our selling and distribution expenses increased by €17.2 million, or 28.6%, from €60.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, to €77.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to a higher order volume in the period which resulted in increased shipping costs as well as high logistics costs relating to personnel expenses. Selling and distribution expenses as a percentage of revenue remained stable from 32.8% for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to 32.7% for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) to revenue) was 18.0% for the three months ended March 31, 2022 (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: 17.9%). For the three months ended March 31, 2022, the selling and distribution expenses 86 ----- consisted mainly of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €42.7 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €32.8 million), marketing expenses of €9.3 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €3.6 million), sales expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €7.7 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €5.5 million) and amortization and depreciation expenses of €17.6 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €18.2 million). _Administrative expenses_ Our administrative expenses increased by €8.1 million, or 50.3%, from €16.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €24.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to higher personnel expenses as a result of an increased number of employees, additional technology expenses related to IT licenses and maintenance as a result of continuous IT upgrades and higher consultancy fees. In the three months ended March 31, 2022, administrative expenses consist of technology expenses of €7.8 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €3.6 million), general and administrative expenses of €14.6 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €11.2 million) and amortization and depreciation expenses of €1.8 million (for the three months ended March 31, 2021: €1.3 million). _Other operating income_ Our other operating income increased by €0.5 million from €0.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €1.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Changes to other operating income in the period mainly resulted from the reversal of provisions, compensations for damages and income from foreign exchange gains and non-period income. _Other operating expenses_ Our other operating expenses increased by €0.7 million from €0.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €1.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Changes to other operating expenses mainly consist of donations to humanitarian organizations and foreign exchange losses. _Financial expenses_ Our financial expenses increased by €0.2 million, or 3.0%, from €6.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €6.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Financial expenses mainly consist of interest on the Existing Notes and lease liabilities under IFRS16. _Income taxes_ Our income taxes changed by €2.0 million from €0.6 million tax expenses for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €1.4 million tax income for the three months ended March 31, 2022. This development is primarily due to lower taxable income. _Net income/(net loss) for the period_ Our net income amounted to €0.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to a net loss of €4.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022, representing a decrease of €4.9 million.

Subsubsection Text: The following table sets forth our results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020, and the changes in percentages: 89 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Our revenue increased by €327.1 million, or 53.1%, from €615.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €942.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was primarily driven by continued strong online customer growth, achieved both via the referral based viral increase and paid customer acquisition. This favorable development was complemented by strong order economics and an improved customer proposition including a more attractive brand portfolio, more convenient payment solutions and faster delivery times. Our strong revenue growth was driven by growth in both our Germany and International segments, an expansion of our customer base from 2020, continued high customer loyalty resulting in an outstanding revenue retention, and strong order economics. Our revenue growth was slightly offset by revenue declines in our offline retail stores due to the government-imposed COVID-19-related temporary store closures in Germany and Austria during 2021. _Cost of sales_ Our cost of sales increased by €185.5 million, or 56.7%, from €327.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €512.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 corresponding to 54.4% (2020: 53.1%) of revenue. This development is attributable to and in line with the strong business growth and the improved customer proposition with a larger and more attractive merchandise offering. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets of €1.5 million (2020: €0.9 million) and personnel expenses of €6.0 million (2020: €3.8 million) are reported in cost of sales for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Selling and distribution expenses_ Our selling and distribution expenses increased by €62.3 million, or 24.3%, from €256.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €318.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was primarily driven by higher business volumes, resulting in higher fulfillment expenses such as shipping costs and personnel expenses in logistics. Selling and distribution expenses as a percentage of revenue decreased from 41.7% for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 33.8% for the year ended December 31, 2021. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our selling and distribution expenses consisted of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €162.3 million (2020: €104.4 million), marketing expenses of €49.0 million (2020: €9.4 million), sales expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €28.9 million (2020: €27.5 million) and amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses of €78.6 million (2020: €115.2 million). The fulfilment expenses increased by €57.9 million which was mainly due to higher business volume resulting in higher shipping costs and higher personnel costs in logistics. As a result, the fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) to revenue) came to 17.2% in the year ended December 31, 2021 (2020: 17.0%). In the year ended December 31, 2021, marketing expenses equaled 5.2% (2020: 1.5%) of revenue. This increase in marketing expenses was mainly due to investments in paid customer acquisition through targeted online marketing campaigns. Sales expenses increased to €28.9 million (2020: €27.5 million) due to higher costs for payment service providers. Personnel expenses for the stores decreased by €3.5 million to €11.5 million (2020: €15.0 million) which was partly attributable to receipt of government grants for short-term workers in our stores in Germany and Austria during COVID-19. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets as well as impairment of goodwill and intangible assets, amortization and impairment of purchase price allocation assets decreased to €78.6 million (2020: €115.2 million), and primarily comprised amortization of brand names and customer base of €58.7 million (2020: €47.5 million). The decrease was mainly due to impairment losses on goodwill in the amount of €50.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, related to our stationary retail stores due to the accelerated shift towards online shopping caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. 88 ----- _Administrative expenses_ Our administrative expenses increased by €17.9 million, or 29.2%, from €61.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €79.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase in administrative expenses was primarily driven by higher personnel and technology expenses as well as costs relating to COVID-19, including health and safety measures. In the year ended December 31, 2021, our administrative expenses consisted of technology expenses of €21.3 million (2020: €12.3 million), general and administrative expenses of €51.7 million (2020: €41.1 million) and depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets as well as impairment of goodwill and intangible assets of €6.1 million (2020: €7.8 million). The increase in technology expenses by €9.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the year ended December 31, 2020, which was mainly attributable to higher personnel costs as well as higher costs for IT licenses and maintenance. Compared to the year ended December 31, 2020, the general and administrative expenses increased by €10.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 due to higher personnel and recruiting costs. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets as well as impairment of goodwill and intangible assets decreased by €1.7 million since the year ended December 31, 2020 contained impairment losses on software no longer used in the amount of €2.8 million. _Other operating income_ Our other operating income increased by €0.2 million, or 7.7%, from €2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 and to €2.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Other operating income mainly comprises income from exchange rate gains and compensation for damages. _Other operating expenses_ Our other operating expenses increased by €0.8 million, or 28.6%, from €2.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €3.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was primarily due to foreign exchange rate losses. _Financial income_ Our financial income decreased by €0.2 million from €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to nil for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Financial expenses_ Our financial expenses increased by €0.3 million, or 1.2%, from €25.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €26.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 due to higher interest expenses in connection with lease accounting under IFRS 16. Financial expenses mainly consist of interest on the Existing Notes and lease liabilities under IFRS 16. _Income taxes_ Our income taxes changed by €2.6 million from €1.0 million tax income for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €1.6 million tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2021 due to higher taxable income as a result of increasing business volumes. _Net income/(net loss) for the period_ Our net loss for the period amounted to €53.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the net income of €3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, representing an increase of €57.6 million. The increase in net income was attributable to the growth of our online business in the year ended December 31, 2021. The result of the year ended December 31, 2020 includes impairment losses of €50.8 million on goodwill related to our stationary retail stores.

Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Our revenue increased by €44.5 million, or 7.8%, from €571.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €615.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Revenue growth was driven by the structural shift towards online shopping due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The increased online business was offset by a decrease in revenue from offline (brick-and-mortar) business at our premium stores and our outlet stores of 33% mainly due to the government-imposed COVID-19-related temporary store closures in spring and winter 2020. _Cost of sales_ Our cost of sales increased by €31.1 million, or 10.5%, from €296.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €327.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due to overall business growth and to targeted online marketing campaigns following the outbreak of COVID-19. Cost of sales as a percentage of revenue were 53.1% for the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to 51.8% for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to our targeted online campaigns in spring 2020 that used discounts and vouchers with the deliberate aim of maintaining top-line growth and generating cash, a lower spring/summer merchandise level due to a customer shift to prudent buying during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as a late onset of fall/winter season in the year ended December 31, 2020. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets of €0.9 million (2019: €1.0 million) and personnel expenses of €3.8 million (2019: €3.1 million) are reported in cost of sales for the year ended December 31, 2020. _Selling and distribution expenses_ Our selling and distribution expenses increased by €63.1 million, or 32.6%, from €193.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €256.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was mainly due to impairment losses on goodwill, higher business volume resulting in higher shipping and payment service provider costs as well as an increase in health and safety measures, such as the introduction of a third shift in our fulfillment center. For the reasons described above, selling and distribution expenses as a percentage of revenue increased from 33.9% for the year ended December 31, 2019 to 41.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our selling and distribution expenses consisted of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €104.4 million (2019: €88.3 million), marketing expenses of €9.4 million (2019: €10.8 million), sales expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) of €27.5 million (2019: €33.0 million) and amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses of €115.2 million (2019: €61.3 million). The fulfilment expenses increased by €16.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019 which was mainly due to higher business volume resulting in higher shipping costs as well as health and safety measures, such as the introduction of a third shift in our fulfillment center. As a result, the fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses (excluding amortization and depreciation expenses) to revenue) came to 17.0% in the year ended December 31, 2020 (2019: 15.5%). In the year ended December 31, 2020, marketing expenses equaled 1.5% (2019: 1.9%) of our revenue. The decrease in marketing expenses was mainly due to a range of cost-cutting measures. Compared to 90 ----- the year ended December 31, 2019, sales expenses decreased by €5.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly attributable to a decrease of personnel expenses for the stores in the amount of €6.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 due to receipt of government grants for short-term workers in our stores in Germany and Austria during COVID-19. This effect was partly offset by an increase of payment costs in the amount of €1.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 due to higher business volume. In the year ended December 31, 2020, depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets as well as impairment of goodwill and intangible assets, amortization and impairment of purchase price allocation assets increased to €115.2 million (2019: €61.3 million), and primarily comprised impairment of goodwill in the amount of €50.8 million (2019: nil) and amortization of brand names and customer base of €47.5 million (2019: €47.5 million). The impairment losses on goodwill related to our stationary retail stores due to the accelerated shift towards online shopping caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. _Administrative expenses_ Our administrative expenses increased by €9.6 million, or 18.6%, from €51.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €61.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase of administrative expenses was primarily driven by higher personnel expenses, costs incurred for IT licenses and maintenance, costs relating to COVID-19 and health and safety as well as higher consultancy fees. In the year ended December 31, 2020, our administrative expenses consist of technology expenses of €12.3 million (2019: €10.4 million), general and administrative expenses of €41.1 million (2019: €37.1 million) and depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets of €7.8 million (2019: €4.1 million). For the year ended December 31, 2020, depreciation, amortization and impairment expenses contain impairment losses of €2.8 million on software no longer used. _Other operating income_ Our other operating income increased by €1.1 million, or 73.3%, from €1.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €2.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was mainly attributable to COVID-19-related revenue compensation in Austria, and income from exchange rate gains. _Other operating expenses_ Our other operating expenses decreased by €0.7 million from €3.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €2.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease was mainly attributable to lower credit losses. _Financial income_ Our financial income increased by €0.2 million from nil for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 due to interest received on tax refunds. _Financial expenses_ Our financial expenses increased by €1.6 million, or 6.6%, from €24.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €25.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Financial expenses mainly consist of interest on the Existing Notes and lease liabilities under IFRS 16. _Income taxes_ Our income taxes changed by €1.2 million from €0.2 million tax expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €1.0 million tax income for the year ended December 31, 2020. This development is primarily due to increased release of deferred tax liabilities in connection with a shortening of the useful life for the customer base of “Schustermann & Borenstein” as a result of our rebranding, as well as changes in the valuation of goods. _Net income/(net loss) for the year_ Our loss for the period amounted to €53.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the net income of €3.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a decrease of €57.5 million. The decrease was primarily due to impairment of goodwill and intangible assets in the amount of €50.8 million (2019: nil) related to our offline retail stores due to the accelerated shift towards online shopping caused mainly by the COVID-19 pandemic. One-time expenses in connection with COVID-19, restructuring measures, as well as a lower gross margin, also contributed to the decline in earnings. 91 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: To reflect the structural shift in our business towards e-commerce, we have realigned our operating segments for the year ended December 31, 2021 to Germany and International in the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, which are also our reportable segments going forward. Presentation of segment reporting information for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 has been retroactively adjusted to reflect this change in the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. We measure the performance of our segments on the basis of revenue and Adjusted EBITDA. The following table sets forth the operating performance of our segments for the periods indicated.

The increase in Germany revenue was driven by a continued expansion in our customer base and good order economics. Germany revenue increased by €199.6 million, or 42.0%, from €475.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €675.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. For the year ended December 31, 2021, 71.6% of our revenue was generated in Germany, a decrease from 77.3% in the year ended December 31, 2020, confirming the continuing internationalization trend. The increase in Germany revenue was primarily driven by strong online performance, offset by the significant decrease in revenue in our offline retail stores due to government-imposed, COVID-19-related temporary closures. Our online revenue in Germany increased by €221.2 million, or 54.4%, from €406.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €628.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Online growth was driven by an expansion of our customer base from 2020, continued high customer loyalty, and strong order economics. Our German offline retail business revenue decreased by €21.6 million, or 31.3%, from €69.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €47.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease is mainly attributable to the governmentimposed, COVID-19-related temporary closures and the acceleration of the structural shift to online retail. Germany revenue increased by €11.6 million, or 2.5%, from €464.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €475.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. For the year ended December 31, 2020, 77.3% of our revenue was generated in Germany, a decrease from 81.3% in the year ended December 31, 2019, confirming the continuing internationalization trend. Our online revenue in Germany increased by €47.8 million, or 13.3%, from €359.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €406.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The growth of the e-commerce business was driven by the combination of customer membership, continued new customer growth and a lower return rate during COVID-19. Our German offline retail business revenue decreased 92 ----- by €36.2 million, or 34.4%, from €105.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €69.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease is mainly attributable to the government imposed temporary closure of the stores from mid-March 2020 to early May 2020, a slow recovery thereafter due to continuing social distancing measures and a further government imposed temporary closure of the stores from mid-December 2020 onwards. _Germany Adjusted EBITDA_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _International revenue_ International revenue increased by €30.5 million from €47.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €77.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase in International revenue was primarily due to strong customer growth. We also further advanced our revenue diversification with International revenue accounting for 33% of Group revenue for the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to 26% for the three months ended March 31, 2022. International revenue increased by €127.4 million from €140.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €267.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase in International revenue was primarily due to a further expansion of our online international business volume. Our International offline retail business revenue decreased by €0.2 million, or 1.1%, from €18.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €18.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was mainly attributable to government-imposed, measures relating to COVID-19 that resulted in the temporary closure of our offline Vienna store. International revenue increased by €33.0 million, or 30.8%, from €107.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €140.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 due to a further expansion of our online international business volume. Our International offline retail business revenue decreased by €7.0 million, or 27.6%, from €25.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €18.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly attributable to the government-imposed, COVID-19 related temporary closure of the Vienna store. _International Adjusted EBITDA_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents costs for consulting fees in connection with strategy projects and other process optimizations as well as severance payments and headhunter services. (b) Represents (i) expenses incurred in connection with new store openings and extensions, comprised of marketing expenses, agency fees, recruiting, legal and consultancy expenses and additional personnel expenses, (ii) expenses in connection with warehouse expansions, (iii) expenses in connection with additional storage requirements and in connection with the reorganization of processes for the outsourcing of returns and bulky goods and (v) expenses for an additional fulfillment center which is currently being planned. (c) Represents costs incurred in connection with the continuous enterprise resource planning (ERP) optimization, the implementation of a human resources tool and a merchandise management system, the implementation of our marketplace as well as other financial reporting advancements and process optimizations. (d) Represents costs relating to COVID-19 measures, including bonus payment, hazard pay, extensive hygienic measures and regular tests and other costs for the BestSecret Group stationary retail business during closing periods as well as expenses incurred in connection with geopolitical tensions, in the three months ended March 31, 2022 resulting from the conflict in Ukraine such as costs for donations in kind. Germany Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €7.2 million from €26.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €18.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The decrease in Germany Adjusted EBITDA was mainly attributable to lower overstock availability, the return rate trending back up towards pre-COVID levels and higher marketing expenses to grow our customer base in line with our new strategy. In addition, we continued to invest in our personnel teams in order to support business growth. Adjustments in Germany decreased primarily due to lower expenses resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. Germany Adjusted EBITDA margin decreased by 7.3% points from an exceptionally high 19.1% for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to 11.8% for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Germany Adjusted EBITDA increased by €23.6 million from €91.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €115.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase in Germany Adjusted EBITDA was primarily due to the continued growth in online revenue reflecting the accelerated structural shift towards e-commerce as a result of COVID-19. Germany Adjusted EBITDA margin decreased by 2.2% points from 19.2% for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 17.0% for the year ended December 31, 2021 as a result of increased paid customer acquisition activities. Germany Adjusted EBITDA increased by €2.8 million from €88.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €91.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase in Germany Adjusted EBITDA was primarily due to the online revenue growth. The costs incurred in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic by the offline retail business are part of the adjustments included in the calculation of Adjusted EBITDA, so did not impact our Adjusted EBITDA results. Germany Adjusted EBITDA margin slightly increased by 0.1% points from 19.1% for the year ended December 31, 2019 to 19.2% for the year ended December 31, 2020. 93 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

(c) Represents costs incurred in connection with the continuous enterprise resource planning (ERP) optimization, the implementation of a human resources tool and a merchandise management system, the implementation of our marketplace as well as other financial reporting advancements and process optimizations. (d) Represents costs relating to COVID-19 measures, including bonus payment, hazard pay, extensive hygienic measures and regular tests and other costs for the BestSecret Group stationary retail business during closing periods as well as expenses incurred in connection with geopolitical tensions, in the three months ended March 31, 2022 resulting from the conflict in Ukraine such as costs for donations in kind. International Adjusted EBITDA decreased slightly by €0.1 million from €5.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to €5.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. International Adjusted EBITDA margin decreased by 4.6% points from 11.4% for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to 6.8% for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily due to increased paid customer acquisition activities. 94 ----- International Adjusted EBITDA increased by €7.3 million from €16.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €23.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase in International Adjusted EBITDA was primarily due to further international expansion and the expanded customer base. International Adjusted EBITDA margin decreased by 2.8% points from 11.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 8.8% for the year ended December 31, 2021 as a result of increased paid customer acquisition activities. See “Internationalization––Results of Operations.” International Adjusted EBITDA increased by €5.0 million from €11.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €16.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase in International Adjusted EBITDA was primarily due to further international expansion and the expanded customer base. The costs incurred in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic by the offline retail business as well as the revenue compensation in Austria are part of the adjustments included in the calculation of Adjusted EBITDA, so did not impact our Adjusted EBITDA results. International Adjusted EBITDA margin increased by 1.0% points from 10.6% for the year ended December 31, 2019 to 11.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020 as a result of lower marketing expenses and scaling effects in overhead expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our main sources of liquidity are our net cash flows from operating activities and long-term financing, including the Notes and the New Revolving Credit Facility. Our business model is focused on ensuring adequate liquidity to allow for flexibility with regard to the purchase of merchandise, including opportunistic mixed lot purchases. Given our positive liquidity situation, we are able to procure merchandise through our operating cash generation, providing us with flexibility which we believe particularly appeals to our suppliers. Our ability to generate cash from our operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the section titled “Risk Factors.” Although we believe that our expected net cash flows from operating activities, together with the borrowings that will be available under the Notes and New Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient net cash flows from operating activities or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Related to our Financial Profile—We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to service our indebtedness and may be forced to take other actions to meet our obligations under our indebtedness, which may not be successful.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We calculate Capital Expenditure as the sum of (i) purchase of property, plant and equipment, (ii) purchase of intangible assets and (iii) capitalized development costs, each as shown in the consolidated statements of cash flows in the Consolidated Financial Statements and as shown in the table below for the periods indicated. 96 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Consolidated statement of cash flows financial Information for the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020 has been taken from the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial, due to revised presentation of certain amounts in the Group’s consolidated statement of cash flows in the year ended December 31, 2021. For more information see Note 2.4 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. 95 ----- _Net cash flows from operating activities_ Our net cash flows from operating activities changed by €52.3 million from net cash inflows of €8.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to net cash outflows of €44.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The decrease in net cash flows from operating activities was mainly affected by a decrease of refund liabilities and trade and other payables due to a seasonal stock purchasing pattern and increased business volume for the three months ended March 31, 2022. Our net cash flows from operating activities decreased by €6.7 million from net cash inflows of €95.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to net cash inflows of €89.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease in net cash inflows from operating activities was primarily due to an increase in inventory held due to strong business growth and a reversal of the strict cash management policy for the procurement of goods that was in place during 2020. Our net cash flows from operating activities increased by €12.6 million from net cash inflows of €83.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to net cash inflows of €95.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The net cash flows from operating activities were positively affected by a strong year-end business resulting in positive cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2020. _Net cash flows from investing activities_ Our net cash flows from investing activities decreased by €4.7 million from net cash outflows of €4.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to net cash outflows of €9.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The increase in net cash outflows from investing activities was primarily due to an increase in cash outflows from investments in development IT. Our net cash flows from investing activities increased by €5.6 million from net cash outflows of €33.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to net cash outflows of €28.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase in net cash outflows from investing activities was primarily due to investment in the expansion of our fulfillment center in the year ended December 31, 2020, which was partly offset by an increase in development expenditures for the year ended December 31, 2021. Our net cash flows from investing activities decreased by €2.8 million from net cash outflows of €36.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to net cash outflows of €33.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The net cash outflows for investing activities were mainly for the expansion of our fulfillment center, investments in IT and other technology to advance our user experience, the upgrade of our technology infrastructure, as well as project support at the fulfillment center, while all other capital expenditure was successfully scaled back due to the uncertainties of the pandemic. _Net cash flows from financing activities_ Our net cash flows from financing activities decreased by €0.9 million from net cash outflows of €3.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 to net cash outflows of €4.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2022. The net cash flows from financing activities were impacted by higher payments for leases in the year ended December 31, 2021. Our net cash flows from financing activities decreased by €1.3 million from net cash outflows of €29.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to net cash outflows of €30.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase in net cash outflows from financing activities was primarily due to increase of payments in connection with lease liabilities. Our net cash flows from financing activities decreased by €1.5 million from net cash outflows of €27.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to net cash outflows of €29.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase in net cash outflows from financing activities was primarily due to a higher amount of interest paid for lease contracts.

Our Operating Net Working Capital shows seasonal patterns with investments in inventory generally reaching a peak in August and September due to purchase of winter merchandise. Our Capital Expenditure decreased by €5.3 million, from €34.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €28.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 due to lower levels of investment activity relating to the fulfillment center expansion. Our IT department enables us to develop key components of the software (homepage and app) used by the Group. This gives us a strategic advantage and enables us to align the software with the operating processes. 97 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures on Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the risk that the fair value or the future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market prices. Market risk comprises three types of risk: interest rate risk, currency risk and other price risk, such as equity price risk. Based on the position as of December 31, 2021, there is no sensitivity of equity. _Interest Rate Risk_ Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. As of December 31, 2021, there are no financial instruments affected by floating interest rates. We do not enter into interest rate derivatives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures on Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligations under a financial instrument or customer contract, leading to a financial loss. We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities (primarily trade and other receivables) and from our financing activities, including deposits with banks and financial institutions. Due to the introduction of non-recourse factoring, there is no significant exposure to credit risk from transactions with customers. There were no significant credit risks or concentration of risk arising from the delivery of goods to major customers as of December 31, 2021. We do not hold collateral as security. _Financial instruments and cash deposits_ Credit risk from balances with banks and financial institutions is managed by our treasury department in accordance with our Group policy. Investments of surplus funds are made only with approved counterparties and within credit limits assigned to each counterparty. The limits are set to minimize the concentration of risks and therefore mitigate financial loss through a counterparty’s potential failure to make payments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures on Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to a number of risks arising from our normal business activities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We provide sufficient liquidity for each individual entity by cash pooling. Our objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of bank overdrafts and bank loans. As of December 31, 2021, roughly 10% (December 31, 2020: 10%) of the undiscounted cash outflows from financial liabilities are due in less than one year. We assessed the concentration of risk with respect to refinancing our debt and concluded it to be low. We have access to a sufficient variety of sources of funding, and debt maturing within 12 months can be rolled over with existing lenders. We have access to a short-term loan of €110.0 million.
