We expect the New Revolving Credit Facility to be undrawn as of the Issue Date. 99 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements in conformity with IFRS requires management to make judgements, assumptions and estimates that have effects on the amounts carried and the related disclosures. Although these estimates are based on the current events and measures to the best of management’s knowledge, there may be deviations between estimated and actual results. Significant estimates and assumptions have been used for the following matters in particular: - Impairment of non-financial assets (including forecasts and COVID-19 impact) - Determination and assessment of the realizability of deferred tax assets on unused tax losses and income taxes - The determination of provisions for restoration expenses and other provisions - Assumptions for the calculation of returns and unredeemed coupons - Inventory valuation - Segment reporting - Assessment of the necessity and amount of allowances on receivables - Interest rate in connection with IFRS 16 - Assumptions with regard to making use of termination or extension options in connection with IFRS 16 - Assumptions with regard to useful life of our customer base due to the structural shift towards e-commerce These key forward-looking assumptions and estimates, which involve a significant risk of changing the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities within the next fiscal year, are discussed below. _Impairment of non-financial assets (including forecasts and COVID-19 impact)_ All non-financial assets that fall within the scope of IAS 36 are tested for impairment if there are indicators that the asset may be impaired. Regardless of indicators of impairment, goodwill acquired in business combinations is tested for impairment once a year at the level of the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs. 100 ----- This assessment implies significant judgment and estimates, in particular in light of the uncertainties in connection with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic precipitated the shift to the online market business in general, and this was taken into account in the impairment testing for goodwill and the review of useful lives for the intangible assets recognized using the purchase method in compliance with IFRS 3. Impairment exists when the carrying value of an asset or cash-generating unit exceeds its recoverable amount. This is the higher of its fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use. The recoverable amount is sensitive to the discount rate used for the DCF model that is the basis for the calculation of the fair value less costs of disposal used as well as the expected future cash flows and the growth rate used for extrapolation purposes. These estimates are most relevant to goodwill. The key assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount for the goodwill, including a sensitivity analysis, are disclosed and further explained in Note 5.1 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements / Note 5.2 of the 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. _Assessment of realizability of deferred tax assets on unused tax losses and income taxes_ Uncertainties exist with respect to the interpretation of complex tax regulations and the amount and timing of future taxable income. Different interpretations of tax laws may result in additional tax payments for prior years. Various factors such as past experience with tax field audits and different treatment of tax regulations by tax authorities are considered. Deferred tax assets are recognized to the extent that it is probable that they will be recovered, which is dependent on the generation of sufficient future taxable profit. Assumptions about the generation of future taxable profits depend on management’s estimates of future cash flows. These judgments and estimates are subject to risks and uncertainty. Consequently, there is a possibility that changes in circumstances will alter expectations, which may impact the amount of deferred tax assets recognized at the reporting date. In such circumstances, some or all of the carrying amount of recognized deferred tax assets and liabilities may require adjustment, resulting in a corresponding credit or charge to the income statement. _Determination of provisions for restorations expenses and other provisions_ The determination of provisions for restoration expenses requires assumptions and estimates regarding the discount rates, expected costs and timing of these costs. If the interest effect resulting from the discounting is significant, provisions are discounted at a pre-tax interest rate that reflects the risks specific to the liability. Provisions mainly comprise provisions for restoration expenses and provisions for restructuring. Whether a present obligation is probable or not requires judgment. The nature and type of risks for these provisions differ, and management’s judgment is applied regarding the nature and extent of obligations in deciding if an outflow of resources is probable or not. As of December 31, 2021, long-term provisions were discounted at an interest rate of 7.5%. In the case of discounting, timing-related interest effects are recognized as financial expenses. _Calculation of returns and unredeemed gift vouchers Returns_ For transactions with a statutory 14-day or longer refund policy, we calculate the amount of the expected returns as of the reporting date based on historical return rates under consideration of the actual returns until the date of preparing the Consolidated Financial Statements, which are taken into account in order to reduce revenue. As of December 31, 2021, deferred sales recognized as refund liability amounted to €39.7 million compared to €19.6 million as of March 31, 2022. The right to recover possession of expected returns is reported under other current non-financial assets. _Unredeemed gift vouchers_ The acquiring customer has a claim from the sale of vouchers for fulfillment up to a period of three years. If vouchers sold are not redeemed within this period, we realize the revenue from the voucher sale. Liabilities from the sale of gift vouchers are recognized under other liabilities and amounted as of December 31, 2021, to €2.0 million compared to €1.7 million as of March 31, 2022. 101 ----- _Inventory valuation_ Inventories are measured at the lower of cost and net realizable value. Net realizable value is the estimated selling price in the ordinary course of business less the estimated necessary costs to make the sale. Estimates are necessary to determine the sales proceeds that can be achieved in the normal course of business. _Segment reporting_ IFRS 8 requires that operating segments be defined on the basis of the internal reports of corporate divisions that are regularly reviewed by our chief operating decision maker (the “CODM”) for the purpose of making decisions about the allocation of resources and assessing the financial performance of the respective segments. Before the year ended December 31, 2021, we have reported in two segments: “Online” and “Stationary retail business”. In recent years, we have been able to leverage the accelerated structural shift to e-commerce and set a clear focus on online business. This transition has resulted in a change in the internal organizational setup, the management structure, and the internal reporting lines. As the internal organizational and management structure and the internal reports submitted to the CODM form the basis for determining our segment reporting format, we have therefore realigned our segment reporting. For the year ended December 31, 2021 and thereafter, our segments will be “Germany” and “International”. Primary emphasis is placed on the key performance indicators revenue and adjusted EBITDA. _Assessment of the necessity and amount of allowances on receivables_ The determination of the necessity and amount of valuation allowances on receivables requires assumptions and estimates regarding the credit risk and underlying time intervals. In the case of a return debit, we inform the customer and defines a period for payment. When the defined time period has elapsed, written warnings are sent to the customers. We use a provision matrix to calculate expected credit losses for receivables. The provision rates are based on days past due and our historical default rates. The default rates are evaluated based on expectations as to the collectability of the receivables. _Interest rate in connection with IFRS 16_ The interest rate in connection with IFRS 16 was determined considering our debt structure and the useful life of the leased assets. To measure lease liabilities, we use the incremental borrowing rate. We estimate the incremental borrowing rate by using observable input factors. _Assumptions with regard to making use of termination or extension options in connection with IFRS 16_ The lease term of an asset is determined by considering options to terminate or extend the lease that are reasonably certain to be exercised. The possibility of the use of termination or extension options is appreciated by considering the overall business development as well as the term of existing leases. _Assumptions with regard to useful life of the Group’s customer base_ The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the structural shift towards e-commerce. Our testing of the useful lives of the Group’s customer base at the end of 2020 resulted in the for prospective adjustment of the remaining useful life of the “Schustermann & Borenstein” customer base from 10 years to 5 years starting in the 2021 reporting period onwards. This change in estimate of useful life has resulted in an increase of the annual amortization of €6.6 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method according to IFRS 3. The cost of an acquisition is measured as the aggregate of the consideration transferred measured at acquisition date fair value and the amount of any non-controlling interests in the acquiree. For each business combination, we elect whether to measure the non-controlling interests in the acquiree at fair value or at the proportionate share of the acquiree’s identifiable net assets. Acquisition-related costs are expensed as incurred and included in administrative expenses. When we acquire a business, we assess the financial assets and liabilities assumed for appropriate classification and designation in accordance with the contractual terms, economic circumstances and pertinent conditions as at the acquisition date. 102 ----- Goodwill is initially measured at cost, being the excess of the aggregate of the consideration transferred and the amount recognized for non-controlling interests over the net identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed. After initial recognition, goodwill is measured at cost less any accumulated impairment losses. For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill acquired in a business combination is, from the acquisition date, allocated to each of our cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from the combination, irrespective of whether other assets or liabilities of the acquiree are assigned to those units. In case of any structural changes of the respective cashgenerating units within the Group, an impairment review and potential reallocation of the goodwill according to IAS 36 is performed. As of March 31, 2022, our goodwill amounted to €203.5 million. No impairment was recognized in the three months ended March 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We apply measurement techniques that are appropriate under the respective circumstances and for which sufficient data is available for fair value measurement. In the process, observable market inputs are to be preferred to non-observable inputs. Assets and liabilities measured or presented at fair value in the Consolidated Financial Statements are classified on the basis of the following fair value hierarchy. The classification uses the input parameters of the lowest category that is material to the fair value measurement. - Level 1: Quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities - Level 2: Inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the assets or liabilities, either directly or indirectly - Level 3: Unobservable inputs for the assets and liabilities

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue is recognized according to IFRS 15 at an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring goods to customers, net of taxes and duties, and taking into account agreed payment terms. Revenue is reported net of discounts, rebates, taxes and returns. Since we have price discretion in our sales transactions and also bear the inventory and credit risk, we generally act as a principal and are therefore the principal party of all sales transactions. In addition, we purchase some products such as jewelry on a commission basis. In this case, we are acting as an agent, but are free in the setting of prices. Revenue is recognized net of commissions earned. Revenue recognition requires the fulfillment of the following recognition criteria: _Sale of goods and products_ Our contracts with customers for the sale of merchandise generally include a single performance obligation. We have concluded that revenue from the sale of merchandise should be recognized at the point in time when control of the asset is transferred to the customer. In the stationary retail business, revenue is therefore recognized upon handing over the goods and in online trading upon delivery of the goods to the customer. _Accounting treatment of returns in the online business_ Under IFRS 15, the consideration received from the customer is variable because the contract allows the customer to return the products. We use the expected value method to estimate the merchandise that will be returned because this method predicts most accurately the amount of variable consideration to which we will be entitled. We apply the requirements in IFRS 15 on constraining estimates of variable consideration such as return rate to determine the amount of variable consideration that can be included in the transaction price. We present a refund liability (other current financial liabilities) and an asset (other current non-financial assets) for the right to recover possession of goods from a customer separately in the statement of financial position, taking into account the costs incurred for processing the return and the losses resulting from disposing of these goods. We present the expected returns of goods on a gross basis in the statement of comprehensive income and reduce revenue by the full amount of sales that we estimate to be returned. The dispatch of goods that is recorded in full when they are shipped is 103 ----- then corrected by the estimated value of the returns. Generally, we allow goods to be returned within a period of 14 days of receipt. Longer periods may be agreed upon contractually. _Friends recommend friends – loyalty program_ We maintain a recommendation program for customers. Every time the invitee (recommended customer) places an order, the inviting customer (inviter) receives a one-time commission voucher of 10% to 20% (2020: 10%). The inviter also receives a 5% to 7% (2020: 5%) voucher based on the total purchases of the invitee within a period of 12 months. According to IFRS 15, both vouchers represent a payment to customers and therefore a revenue reduction when redeemed by the customer.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Current income taxes_ Current income tax assets and liabilities are measured at the amount expected to be recovered from or paid to the tax authorities. The tax rates and tax laws used to compute the amount are those that are enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in the countries where the Group operates and generates taxable income. For the purpose of measuring current German taxes, a uniform corporate income tax rate of 15% is applied to distributed and retained earnings and a solidarity surcharge rate of 5.5% is applied to that amount. That yields a tax rate of 15.825%. In addition, German trade tax is imposed on profits earned in Germany. The trade tax is based on the assessment rates of the various municipalities and the basic federal rate, which has been a flat rate of 3.5% according to Sec. 11 (2) GewStG (Gewerbesteuergesetz: German Trade Tax Act) since the corporate tax reform in 2008. The trade tax varies depending on the different assessment rates of the municipalities, but a flat rate of 11.41% for the year ended December 31, 2021, 11.62% for the year ended December 31, 2020 and 11.70% for the year ended December 31, 2019 is applied in our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The profits earned by the non-German Group companies are calculated on the basis of the national tax laws applicable in each country and taxed at the tax rates in effect in those countries. The country-specific tax rates range from 21 to 25%. Our tax rate is 27.23%. Current tax expenses are calculated on the basis of the taxable income for the year. Taxable income differs from the net income/profit presented in the consolidated statement of comprehensive income as a result of the expenses and income that will not be taxable or that becomes tax-exempt in later years. Our liability for current taxes is calculated on the basis of the tax rates enacted or substantively enacted in the near future. _Deferred taxes_ Deferred taxes are provided using the liability method on temporary differences between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts for financial reporting purposes at the reporting date. Deferred tax liabilities are recognized for all taxable temporary differences, except: - Where the deferred tax liability arises from the initial recognition of goodwill or of an asset or liability in a transaction that is not a business combination and, at the time of the transaction, affects neither the accounting profit nor taxable profit or loss; and - In respect of taxable temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries, associates and interests in joint ventures, where the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences can be controlled and it is probable that the temporary differences will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred income tax assets are recognized for all deductible temporary differences, carry-forward of unused tax credits and unused tax losses, to the extent that it is probable that taxable profit will be available against which the deductible temporary differences, and the carry-forward of unused tax credits and unused tax losses can be utilized except: - Where the deferred income tax asset relating to the deductible temporary difference arises from the initial recognition of an asset or liability in a transaction that is not a business combination and, at the time of the transaction, affects neither the pre-tax accounting profit nor taxable profit or loss; and - In respect of deductible temporary differences associated with investments in subsidiaries, associates and interests in joint ventures, deferred tax assets are recognized only to the extent that it is probable that the 104 ----- temporary differences will reverse in the foreseeable future and taxable profit will be available against which the temporary differences can be utilized. The carrying amount of deferred income tax assets is reviewed at the end of each reporting period and reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that sufficient taxable profit will be available to allow all or part of the deferred income tax asset to be utilized. Unrecognized deferred income tax assets are reassessed at the end of each reporting period and are recognized to the extent that it has become probable that future taxable profit will allow the deferred tax asset to be recovered. Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates that are expected to apply to the year when the asset is realized or the liability is settled, based on tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted at the end of the reporting period. Deferred income tax relating to items recognized in other comprehensive income or directly in equity is recognized in other comprehensive income or directly in equity and not in the profit or loss. Deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities are offset if a legally enforceable right exists to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and the deferred taxes relate to the same taxable entity and the same taxation authority. Tax benefits acquired as part of a business combination, but not satisfying the criteria for separate recognition at that date, are recognized subsequently if new information about facts and circumstances change. The adjustment is either treated as a reduction in goodwill (as long as it does not exceed goodwill) if it was incurred during the measurement period or recognized in profit or loss. As of March 31, 2022, deferred tax liabilities amounted to €74.1 million (compared to €76.3 million as of December 31, 2021) and mainly belongs to the acquired intangible assets in connection with the purchase price allocation (trademark and customer relationship) and the valuation of inventories. The deferred tax liabilities decreased due to the amortization of the PPA assets. _Value added tax_ Revenue, expenses, assets and liabilities are recognized net of the amount of value added tax (“VAT”) except: - If VAT incurred on a purchase of assets or services is not recoverable from the taxation authority, in which case VAT is recognized as part of the cost of acquisition of the asset or as part of expense item as applicable; and - Where receivables, payables and finance lease liabilities are stated with the amount of VAT included. The net amount of VAT recoverable from, or payable to, the taxation authority is included as part of receivables or payables in the consolidated statement of financial position.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Intangible assets acquired in the context of a business combination under IFRS 3 are recognized separately from goodwill and measured at fair value at the acquisition date. This includes customer bases and brand names. These are recognized as an intangible asset according to IAS 38, measured at fair value and amortized over their expected useful lives. An intangible asset is derecognized upon disposal or when no further economic benefits are expected from its use or disposal. Any gain or loss arising on derecognition of the asset (calculated as the difference between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset) is included in the statement of comprehensive income when the asset is derecognized. Intangible assets which are not acquired as part of a business combination but as purchased licenses are initially recognized at cost. Intangible assets with a finite useful life are amortized on a straight-line basis over their economic useful life. Intangible assets with finite useful lives are reviewed for possible impairment if there are indications of impairment at the reporting date. The remaining useful life and the amortization method for intangible assets with a finite useful life are reviewed at least at the end of a reporting period. If the reasons for impairment have been 105 ----- eliminated, a reversal to a maximum of the historical cost is set as the upper limit. Required changes in the amortization period and method are treated as changes in estimates. Impairment losses on intangible assets, e.g., customer base and brand names, with finite useful lives are included in amortization within selling expenses. As of March 31, 2022, intangible assets (mainly customer relationships and trademarks) amounted to €275.0 million. The main intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis and pro rata temporis over their customary useful lives: the brands Schustermann & Borenstein (useful life: 5 years) and BestSecret (useful life: 20 years) and the Schustermann & Borenstein customer base (useful life: 8 years) and BestSecret customer base (useful life: 8 years). Other intangible assets (software and licenses) are recognized at acquisition cost less amortization charged pro _rata temporis using the straight-line method (useful life of between 3 and 8 years)._ Due to the rebranding of the Group in 2019, the total useful life for the brand name Schustermann & Borenstein was reduced from 30 years to 5 years as of January 1, 2019. At the same time, the total useful life of the customer base Schustermann & Borenstein was reduced from 20 years to 14 years. Reviewing the useful lives at the end of 2021 showed the need for prospective alignment of the remaining useful life of the respective customer bases to 3 years from the 2022 reporting period onwards. This reduces the total useful life for the Schustermann & Borenstein customer base accordingly to 8 years. In the case of internally generated intangible assets, IAS 38 makes a distinction between the research phase and the development phase. Costs incurred during the research phase cannot be capitalized; instead they must be recognized as an expense. On the other hand, costs incurred during the development phase must be capitalized, _provided that the reporting entity demonstrably fulfills all six criteria set out in IAS 38.57 et seq. The Group_ primarily develops key components of software (Best Secret website and the Best Secret app as well as expenses for the Group’s other IT-systems and infrastructure) used by the Group. A useful life of 4 to 5 years is assumed for development activities in connection with the software.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Property, plant and equipment are recognized at cost and depreciated in accordance with their expected useful life using the straight-line method. The Group treats changes in the residual values or useful lives that arise during use as a change in estimates. Depreciation is charged over the following useful lives: 6–20 years for leasehold improvements, 5–14 years for plant and machinery and 5–23 years for furniture and fixtures. An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognized upon disposal or when no further economic benefits are expected from its use or disposal. Any gain or loss arising on derecognition of the asset (calculated as the difference between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset) is included in the statement of comprehensive income when the asset is derecognized. The residual values, useful lives, and methods of depreciation of property, plant and equipment are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted prospectively, if appropriate. If the carrying amount of a tangible asset exceeds the recoverable amount, an impairment loss is recognized, in addition to systematic depreciation, in order to lower the carrying amount to the recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair value less costs to sell (net selling price) and the present value of the net cash flows expected to result from the continued use of the asset. Whenever possible, the net selling price is derived from the most recently observed market transactions. As of March 31, 2022, property, plant and equipment amounted to €75.6 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Merchandise accounted for as inventories is recognized at cost pursuant to IAS 2. Cost is calculated on the basis of an item-by-item measurement, factoring in the additions from the point of view of the sourcing market or on the basis of the moving average price of the goods. Incidental acquisition costs are generally measured on a monthly basis. Supplier payments that are to be classified as a reduction of cost reduce the carrying amount of inventories. Consumption of inventories is recognized within the costs of sales in the statement of comprehensive income. 106 ----- Merchandise as of the reporting date is measured at the lower of cost or net realizable value. The net realizable value is the expected selling price less the costs necessary to make the sale. Adequate write-downs to net realizable value were made to allow for all risks from slow-moving goods and/or reduced salability. When the circumstances that previously caused merchandise to be written down below cost no longer exist, the write-down is reversed. Our inventories as of December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021 were €160.2 million, €155.7 million and €232.9 million, respectively, and €248.2 million as of March 31, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents are measured at amortized cost. The “Cash and cash equivalents” item in the consolidated statement of financial position previously comprised cash, bank balances and credit balances with Payment Service Providers with a banking license (cash in transit). In the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, the Group reclassified credit balances with Payment Service Providers not holding a banking license from ‘cash and cash equivalents’ (cash in transit) to ‘trade and other receivables’. The prior year figures as of December 31, 2019 and as of December 31, 2020 included in the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements have been adjusted accordingly. The cash in transit balances are presented as cash equivalents as these balances are immediately credited to the bank account with the payment service providers over which the company has direct power of disposal. For the purpose of the statement of cash flows, the cash and cash equivalents defined above are presented less overdraft facilities that have been drawn, as these are an integral part of the Group’s available cash.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The Group as a lessee_ We lease various properties, equipment and vehicles. Leases are typically entered into for periods of 2 to 22 years. Lease terms are negotiated on an individual basis and contain a wide range of different terms and conditions. The lease agreements do not impose any covenants, but leased assets may not be used as security for borrowing purposes. Leases are recognized as a right-of-use asset and a corresponding liability at the date on which the leased asset is available for use by the Group. Each lease payment is broken down into an interest component and a principal repayment. Interest is recognized in the income statement over the lease period so as to produce a constant periodic rate of interest on the remaining balance of the liability for the reporting period (effective interest method). It is remeasured when there is a change in future lease payments arising from a change in an index or rate, if there is a change in the Group’s estimate of the amount expected to be payable under a residual value guarantee, if the Group changes its assessment of whether it will exercise a purchase, extension or termination option or if there is a revised in-substance fixed lease payment. The right-of-use asset is depreciated on a straight-line basis over the shorter of the asset’s useful life and the lease term. When the lease liability is remeasured in this way, a corresponding adjustment is made to the carrying amount of the right-of-use asset, or is recorded in profit or loss if the carrying amount of the right-of-use asset has been reduced to zero. Assets and liabilities arising from a lease are initially measured on a present value basis. Lease liabilities include the net present value of the following lease payments: - fixed payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentives receivable - renewal options - variable lease payments that are based on an index or an (interest) rate - amounts expected to be payable by the lessee under residual value guarantees - the exercise price of a purchase option if the lessee is reasonably certain to exercise that option, and - payments of penalties for terminating the lease, if the lease term reflects the lessee exercising that option. The lease payments are discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease, if that rate can be readily determined. If that rate cannot be readily determined, the lessee uses the Group’s incremental borrowing rate. Right-of-use assets are measured at cost comprising the following: 107 ----- - the amount of the initial measurement of the lease liability - any lease payments made at or before the commencement date - any initial direct costs, and - restoration costs. Payments associated with short-term leases (lease term of 12 months or less) and leases of low-value assets are recognized on a straight-line basis as an expense in profit or loss. _The Group as a lessor_ We sub-lease office and retail space. When we act as a lessor, we determine at lease inception whether the lease is a finance lease or an operating lease. To classify each lease, we make an overall assessment of whether the lease transfers substantially all of the risks and rewards incidental to ownership of the underlying asset. If this is the case, then the lease is a finance lease; if not, then it is an operating lease. As part of this assessment, we consider certain indicators such as whether the lease is for the major part of the economic life of the asset. In case of finance leases, rental income is recognized using the effective interest method over the term of the subleases and reported under interest income. Payments received from operating subleases are recognized within other operating income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The “Trade and other receivables” item in the statement of financial position comprises balances with payment service providers not holding a banking license and receivables against customers. Trade receivables are initially recognized at the settlement-date fair value and subsequently measured at amortized cost, which is usually the original invoice value less a loss allowance for expected impairment losses. The loss allowance for trade receivables is determined based on lifetime expected credit losses, which are calculated as the present value of expected cash shortfalls. Changes are recognized as other operating expenses in the consolidated statement of comprehensive income. For its online customers, the Group offers the option to purchase on account. In connection with this payment option, the Group works with a factoring provider, transferring substantially all risks and rewards resulting from the receivables to the factoring company and derecognizing receivables in the statement of financial position.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Financial liabilities are recognized when a Group company is a contractual party to a financial instrument on the settlement date. Financial liabilities are recognized initially at fair value, net of transaction costs incurred. Financial liabilities are subsequently measured at amortized cost. Any difference between the proceeds (net of transaction costs) and the redemption value is recognized in the consolidated income statement over the duration of the obligation using the effective interest rate method. The effective interest method is used to calculate the amortized cost of a financial liability and to allocate interest expenses to the respective periods. The effective interest rate is the interest rate that is necessary to discount the estimated future cash outflows, including all fees and remuneration paid and received that are an integral component of the effective interest rate, transaction costs and other premiums or discounts, through the expected life of the financial instrument, or a shorter period to equal the net carrying amount upon initial recognition. The embedded prepayment option for the Existing Notes is considered to be closely related to the host contract according to IFRS 9. We define “closely related” up to a 5% difference between amortized cost and redemption price as of the redemption date. Other financial liabilities, for instance loans accepted, trade and other payables and other liabilities, are measured at amortized cost. Trade and other payables are amounts owed as consideration for goods or services provided to us in the normal course of business including amounts owed to a payment service provider governing the settlement of supplier liabilities. In the normal business cycle, all liabilities are due in one year or less and are 108 ----- therefore classified as current; otherwise, they are presented as non-current liabilities. For current liabilities, that means they are measured at their repayment or settlement amount, while non-current liabilities and long-term debts are measured at amortized cost in accordance with the effective interest method. Non-interest-bearing or low-interest-bearing financial liabilities are measured at their settlement value or nominal value. We derecognize a financial liability when the related obligation has been paid, canceled, or has expired. The difference between the carrying amount of the derecognized financial liability written off and the consideration received or due is recognized in the statement of comprehensive income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Provisions are recognized in accordance with IAS 37 when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, it is probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation, and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. A best estimate is made of the amount of the provisions, taking into consideration all the discernible risks arising from the obligation. This refers to the amount that is most likely needed to settle the liability. Provisions with a residual term of more than one year are discounted on the reporting date. _Provisions for restoration obligations_ The Group recognizes provisions for restoration obligations for leasehold improvements in the leased warehouses and office buildings. The provision is recognized at an amount equivalent to the present value of the estimated future restoration obligations. The restoration obligations are recognized as part of the cost of the leasehold improvements at the corresponding amount. The estimated cash flows are discounted using a discount rate that is commensurate to the maturity and risk profile. The unwinding of the discount is expensed as incurred and recognized as an interest expense in the statement of comprehensive income. _Provisions for restructuring measures_ Provisions for restructuring measures are recognized to the extent that decisions by management have been announced in sufficient detail to those affected as of the reporting date. The definition of a restructuring measure includes for example basic reorganization with significant effects on the focus of business activities. 109 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In preparing our Consolidated Financial Statements, assumptions and estimates have been made which affect the amounts and presentation of the assets and liabilities recognized in the statement of financial position, income and expenses, and contingent liabilities. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could result in outcomes that may require a material adjustment to the carrying amount of our assets and liabilities in future periods. By “significant,” we mean that the following accounting policies are both important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results and require management’s subjective judgments, often as a result of the need to estimate the effects of matters that are inherently uncertain. You should note that the preparation of our financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during each reporting period. All assumptions and estimates are made according to the best of our management’s knowledge and belief in order to present a true and fair view of our net assets, financial position and results of operations. Since the actual values may, in individual cases, differ from the assumptions and estimates that were made, these are continuously reviewed. Adjustments to the estimates that are relevant for the financial statements are made in the period in which the change occurs, provided that the change relates only to this period. If the change relates not only to the reporting period but also to subsequent periods, the change is taken into account both in the period of the change and in subsequent periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis is intended to assist in providing an understanding of our financial condition, changes in historical financial condition and results of operations as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021 and as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2021 and March 31, 2022. The financial information contained in the following section is derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements and should be read in conjunction therewith. The Audited Consolidated Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and the additional requirements of German commercial law pursuant to Section 315e para. 1 of the HGB. The Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS on interim financial reporting (IAS 34). In our 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, we reclassified and re-presented certain comparative amounts in the consolidated statement of financial position and the consolidated statement of cash flows, to implement the latest developments on interpretations of IFRS and to improve presentation of our consolidated financial statements. As a result, certain amounts in the Group’s statement of financial position and cash flow information for the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020 have been taken from the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. For more information see Note 2.4 of the 2021 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The financial information marked as “audited” in the tables included in this section of the Offering Memorandum is taken from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The financial information marked as “unaudited” in the tables included in this section of the Offering Memorandum is taken from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements and our internal accounting systems or is based on calculations of figures from the abovementioned sources. We present below certain non-IFRS financial measures and ratios that are not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS, including EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Capital Expenditure and Operating Net Working Capital, and certain leverage and coverage ratios, among others. There can be no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. The non-IFRS financial measures are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. The non-IFRS financial measures as presented in this Offering Memorandum may differ from and may not be comparable to similarly titled financial measures used by other companies, and EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA differ from “Consolidated EBITDA” contained in the section “Description of the Notes” of this Offering Memorandum and the Indenture. The non-IFRS financial measures may not give an accurate or complete picture of our financial condition or results of operations for the periods presented and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” Unless the context indicates otherwise, in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, references to “we,” “us,” “our,” “the Group” and “Best Secret” refer to the Issuer together with its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis. We encourage you to read the following discussion in conjunction with the section entitled “Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information” and “Selected Consolidated Financial Information”. In addition, the following discussion includes forward‑looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward‑looking statements. For a discussion of some of those risks and uncertainties please refer to the sections entitled “Forward‑looking statements” and “Risk factors.”_

The market for online off-price fashion is experiencing a consolidation trend, especially in Germany, where the top 5 players are estimated to hold a market share of approximately 47% as of December 2020. There are several structural reasons for this ongoing consolidation trend. Brands are looking to reduce the number of distribution partners they work with to reduce complexity and increase efficiency with respect to their distribution. We believe we are well positioned to capitalize on this trend given our ability to clear large quantities of overstock as well as our development of trusted, long-standing relationships with our brand partners. Further, the online channel is becoming increasingly professionalized and is also exposed to large economies of scale, thus providing further support for consolidation of the market. The competitors we face differ between our geographic markets as well as through different business models and product offerings. We compete with other dedicated off-price players, full-price platforms that offer discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion, as well as players within the wider fashion e-commerce landscape. Within the dedicated off-price market, our competitors include ZalandoLounge, Veepee, Brands4Friends, Limango, Dress for Less and Otrium. However, we believe that our business model and proposition is fundamentally different to these players. Many of these players pursue a flash-sale model, whereby the company offers a discount for a short period of time on a limited number of products. We believe this is less appealing for customers as they do not have access to a permanent assortment and often face long delivery times. The competitive landscape within the discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion segment is more fragmented and includes full-price platforms such as Zalando and Mytheresa. We believe that our unique proposition distinctly separates us from the above-mentioned peers, from both a brand and customer perspective. We are the only online off-price player to operate a closed membership model by invitation-only which allows us to offer much greater brand equity protection than our competitors who typically employ mass marketing. We are also able to purchase large quantities of overstock directly from our brand partners and so are well positioned to provide a structural and silent solution for their overstock. From a customer perspective, we offer a permanent assortment, unlike many of our competitors that focus on a flash-sale model. This gives us a strong advantage given the resulting longer delivery times that are associated with flash-sale models, and speed of delivery being a key factor in the customer experience. Our membership model also offers a high degree of exclusivity resulting in a highly loyal and active customer base. We believe we offer an experience that is at least on par with full-price platforms like Zalando, About You or Mytheresa, while offering our customers attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80% across our standing assortment. 113 -----

We are a leading members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the off-price market with a focus on mid-market to luxury fashion in Europe. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a portfolio of around 3,000 brands, while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a discreet and controlled channel and protecting their brand equity. With a heritage going back nearly 100 years, we have evolved from an offline retail business to a tech-driven online platform. We offer a wide range of midmarket to luxury fashion brands at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80%, providing a permanent assortment of approximately 250,000 items at any moment in time. Our online offering is available in multiple languages and in 27 European countries. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we generated revenue of €996.3 million, an Adjusted EBITDA of €131.4 million and an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 13.2%. Our online revenue, which accounted for 91.7% of total revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, grew at a CAGR of 41.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022. While 70.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 was generated in Germany, our international business outside of Germany continues to gain in importance relative to our Germany business and experienced strong revenue growth of 86.3% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2022 (with a CAGR of 62.2% from the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 to the twelve months ended March 31, 2022).

Subsubsection Title: Our business operates successfully in a large and resilient market with long-term growth supported by structural tailwinds
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the European online fashion market (excluding Russia and the United Kingdom) for mid-market to luxury brands, primarily in the dedicated online off-price and discounted in-season and end-of-season sectors. By targeting the online off-price sector, we are well-positioned to take advantage of three structural long-term trends in the fashion sector: (1) disproportional demand growth in the off-price market, expected to grow at 5% per year from 2021-2025, (2) a shift to more premium fashion, with the mid-market to luxury fashion market expected to grow at 4% per year from 2021-2025 and (3) rising online penetration in the European fashion market, expected to grow at 9% per year from 2021-2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). The growing importance of sustainability for consumers and brands makes the off-price sector an increasingly attractive choice for brands, as it allows for overstock, a structural phenomenon in the fashion industry, to be monetized in a sustainable manner, at discounted prices to consumers and thus avoiding the destruction or disposal of such overstock in landfills. Our closed-membership model offers brands the additional value of discreet overstock clearing at scale and we believe it presents a unique business opportunity to build upon the growing importance of sustainability. As a result of the above factors, and as illustrated in the chart below, the online off-price sector amounted to €44 billion in revenue across Europe (excluding the U.K. and Russia) in 2021, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 12% from 2021 to 2025 (source: a leading international consultancy firm, Company Analysis). 114 ----- (1) All market sizes refer to 2021 and continental Europe, excl. UK and Russia. (2) Market segments excluded: discount, value, pinnacle. (3) Off-price and discounted in-season or end-of season-fashion market for mid-market to luxury fashion. (4) Online, off-price and discounted in-season or end-of season-fashion market for mid-market to luxury fashion. Source: A leading international consulting firm; Company Analysis

Subsubsection Title: The most powerful flywheel in online fashion
Subsubsection Text: The “flywheel” that drives our growth and profitability is the result of several strong elements that feed into one another and that accelerate our viral engine. First, we develop strong brand relationships as a result of our closed and discreet model that allows us to “silently” clear our brand partners’ overstock at scale. Second, based on our strong brand relationships we are able to offer our members a current and attractive assortment of highly desirable brands at discounts ranging from 20% to 80%. Third, we believe this in turn, leads to our members preferring to shop with us, as reflected by exceptional customer key performance indicators (“KPIs”). In combination, these three favorable elements lead to a continuous acceleration of our “viral engine” in which existing members make use of their invitation rights to invite their families and friends. As a consequence, the “flywheel” has generated low double-digit top line growth every year, thereby attracting new brand partners and reinforcing relationships with existing brand partners. Our viral engine has contributed to an exponential growth engine as illustrated in the chart below. (1) Online revenue evolution prior to introduction of performance marketing in 2021. Financials from 2017 to 2020 in accordance with IFRS, German GAAP prior to 2017. 2) 2021. Online only. 3) Based on survey results in the DACH region (n = 1,059 respondents). Share of respondents stating “I like BestSecret and I want my friends and family to be able to get to know it, too”. Question: “What is your main motivation to invite family and friends to join BestSecret”. Source: Company To complement our “viral engine”, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter of 2021. Paid marketing efforts allow us to invite potential new members in a targeted manner to join our closed membership model who can then make use of their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral 115 ----- engine. Paid marketing efforts drive our non-viral growth, especially in areas with currently low penetration (such as international markets). See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition” and “Our Business— Marketing—Paid customer acquisition.” Our brand partners_ Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model enables brands to discreetly clear large volumes of overstock in a premium environment entirely separate from their full-price channels. Discretion is increasingly important to brands, as overstock potentially threatens brand equity when sold openly, because the high degree of price visibility in online shopping allows customers to view full-price and discounted offerings side-by-side. We recently introduced a marketplace as part of our online platform to provide our brand partners the option to market their products within our ecosystem without us having to hold these products in our own inventory. We believe that the marketplace model will strengthen the relationship with our brand partners as it allows them to increase their direct to customer (or “DTC”) revenue through our online platform while maintaining price control. We offer brand partners to clear their overstock within a closed ecosystem. This also provides our brand partners comfort that their merchandise is not being re-sold through the grey market (i.e., channels that our brand partners have not authorized) or other channels that could harm their brand image. Thus, our discreet model protects their brand equity and fosters our long-term and deep strategic partnerships leading to direct relationships with around 95% of all our brand partners, thereby avoiding intermediaries. Our model has also resulted in high brand partner retention: we have retained all of our top 50 brand partners from 2017 (excluding intermediaries, private label suppliers and suppliers who went out of business). These strong relationships allow us to offer attractive products at desirable prices, which in turn, allow us to provide our brand partners with access to an affluent and loyal customer base. _Our products, prices and services_ Our superior brand proposition in turn leads to our ability to offer highly desirable products at attractive prices to our customers and provide them with a service experience matching that of full-price online platforms. Our brand proposition and the resulting strong relationships ensure that we are able to secure an attractive brand portfolio of around 3,000 brands, comprising approximately 250,000 articles at any given time. Unlike almost all other online platforms in the off-price segment, our offered assortment is broad and available permanently: we do not rely on flash sales campaigns with long delivery times. Furthermore, our customers benefit from a fresh assortment: the majority of our inventory has been listed on our online platform for less than six months. This desirable assortment is complemented by attractive discounts of 20% to 80% on every single article and a fast delivery time of approximately 3 days on average in 2021. Our online platform is accessible to our customers through our highly rated app and website which offers a highend shopping and service experience on par with leading online full-price platforms, resulting in high customer satisfaction and an excellent net promoter score (“NPS”) of approximately 60 at the end of 2021. As the fashion market and its consumers increasingly make sustainability a driver of their purchasing decisions, we expect that they will increasingly turn to us for their fashion needs, as our model allows customers a chance to shop fashion in one of the most sustainable ways by giving them access to overstock and ensuring that every piece of fashion that is produced is worn. _Our customers_ Our desirable products, prices and service in turn attract a customer base that is active, loyal, and earns above average disposable income. Driven by our broad offering and incentivized by our attractive loyalty scheme, our customer base has been growing steadily. Our number of active customers was approximately 1.2 million, 1.5 million and 2.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, and 2.5 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, representing a CAGR of 38% between 2019 and 2021. Revenue by customer cohort, grouped by year, or customers who joined in a given year, typically stays stable during the first year of membership. For example, online revenue from our active customers from the years 2018, 2019 and 2020 changed in the respective subsequent years to 99% (2019), 96% (2020) and 118% (2021). Our strong revenue retention track record is further illustrated by the following revenue by cohort chart: 116 ----- (1) Revenue retention is defined as online revenue (NMV after returns incl. shipping income, but excluding cut-off effects and commission) of existing customers divided by revenue of previous year. Source: Company. We believe our value proposition caters to a highly attractive customer demographic, especially to affluent consumers, which drives our strong revenue retention rate, that has increased from 100% to 118% in the period between the year ended December 31, 2018 and the year ended December 31, 2021. Spend in the fashion industry is heavily skewed toward the most affluent consumer demographic: in Germany for instance, 70% of total fashion spending is made by 30% of the consumers (source: a leading international consultancy firm). These affluent consumers spend more than €1,000 per year on fashion. The off-price market is inherently attractive to affluent consumers. These consumers’ spend is approximately 2.5x more than the average consumer on fashion overall, and 2.4x more in premium, 2.7x more in affordable luxury and 2.9x more in luxury, when compared to the market average (source: a leading international consultancy firm). _Viral engine_ Our “viral engine” is a self-reinforcing model in which existing members invite their friends, colleagues or other acquaintances, thus creating multiple new customers. These new members then repeat the cycle, allowing a single original customer to lead to substantial growth over time. New “viral customers” are the primary drivers of our year-on-year structural revenue growth and an important driver for our expansion. Our viral engine resulted in our online business revenue growing at a CAGR of 22% from 2016 to 2020, after which time we introduced our paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter of 2021. Moreover, the viral engine is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue being spent annually to incentivize customers to invite other customers. The overall effect of this viral model is substantial, with four new active customers generated by ten active customers in 2021.

Subsubsection Title: Our proprietary technology platform supports our growing business
Subsubsection Text: We are investing, on an ongoing basis, in building what we believe to be a world-class technology organization to support our growing online platform. To provide for an engaging online storefront, we have designed attractive websites and one of the best-rated online fashion apps (4.8* average app rating), which we regularly update to match the high expectations of our customer base and the experience offered by full-price platforms. Our customers enjoy access to a multi-device shopping experience from their mobile phones, tablets and desktop computers that we believe allows for a convenient and frictionless shopping experience. Our technology supports all major online and mobile platforms, including dedicated iOS and Android applications for both smartphones and tablets. We program, develop and maintain our apps and website in-house, and we frequently update our applications to offer new features. Over the past few years, we have developed sophisticated IT systems which support our apps and websites, customer service, supplier connectivity, communications and the monitoring of customer sales and improved management of inventories. To support this effort, in addition to tech investments in our online platform, we have 117 ----- built a tech driven value chain that integrates tech into our online and offline operations (including for our supply, demand and onsite teams). To facilitate continued growth and build up our tech capacity in our operations, we are expanding our tech hubs in Germany and Spain. A significant number of our FTEs relative to our overall business are in tech-based roles (36% in tech, with tech and data headcount having grown more than 80% in 2021). We believe that we operate a state-of-the-art cloud-based data infrastructure, which allows key business data to be readily accessible across our business units to ensure faster, more data-driven decision making. Data analysts, data scientists and data engineers are embedded across all business units, ensuring that the data we produce and analyze is put to its best use. We have aimed to make technology and data a driver of each and every part of our business by eschewing a dedicated IT department and instead embedding technology and data teams within all of our business units.

Subsubsection Title: Our operations are enabled for growth
Subsubsection Text: To ensure customer satisfaction, we aim to make online off-price fashion shopping as convenient as with fullprice online players along the entire customer journey. From the initial browsing session to the customer receiving their new products at their home, to providing any support that the customer may need along the way. This has resulted in our online orders increasing by 29% and user sessions increasing by 37%, in each case, in the three months ended March 31, 2022 as compared to the same period in 2021. Our browsing sessions generally averages 7 minutes and 29 seconds per customer, with 84% of our browsing sessions in the three months ended March 31, 2022 being mobile share. Our operational platform includes (1) a highly developed content management system that quickly and efficiently develops all our online content according to our content guidelines, (2) our extensive array of payment methods, (3) our expansive logistics operation, with a modern fulfillment center in Poing, Germany and a second large fulfillment center currently under development and (4) a highly trained customer service team that steps in whenever a customer has a question or a problem – both pre- and post- order. In 2021, we simultaneously improved and scaled our operational platform. We improved our on-time delivery rate for our top customers, decreased the time-to-online for our merchandise and reduced the contact rate in customer service, while shipping significantly more orders than in 2020.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient business model with strong growth trajectory, adjusted EBITDA margins and high Cash Conversion
Subsubsection Text: Our business has delivered a consistent track-record of highly profitable growth and Cash Conversion, strongly outperforming the market. In 2021 we recorded revenue of €942.9 million, which represents an overall CAGR of 28.5% from 2019 to 2021 and again outperformed the wider fashion and our off-price market segment as illustrated in the chart below. Source: Company. Our online business is the strongest driver of our performance and its revenue CAGR was 41% in the period from 2019 to 2021. This strong growth momentum in 2021 was ahead of listed online fashion companies such as Zalando and Mytheresa, which saw revenue growth rates of 26.4% and 27.4% respectively from 2019 to 2021. 118 ----- Our revenue growth acceleration has been complemented by our strong Adjusted EBITDA margin. In the year ended December 31, 2021, our Adjusted EBITDA was €138.7 million and the Adjusted EBITDA CAGR was 18% in the period from 2019 to 2021. We are able to convert our profitable growth into attractive cash flows due to our high profitability, efficient working capital management and the limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements of our business model. For the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, our total capital expenditures were 6.4%, 5.5% and 3.0% of revenue, respectively, and Cash Conversions for these periods were 47.9%, 66.1% and 51.1%, respectively. In the first three months ended March 31, 2022, our cash flow development reflected temporarily increased investments in growth projects and inventory, as illustrated in the charts below, due to growing business volume. We have further demonstrated our fundamental resilience throughout the COVID-19 pandemic as illustrated by the following charts of the Group’s revenue year-on-year growth including strong Group revenue growth, Adjusted EBITDA margin levels and Operating Net Working Capital. Source: Company. Source: Company. 119 ----- (1) Trade receivables including cash in transit Source: Company We also believe that the segment of the market in which we operate exhibits attractive resilience from a supply and demand perspective through the economic cycle, it offers an attractive opportunity for consumers to spend less for highly branded fashion items in an economic downturn, in which brand partners are under pressure to sell overstock. Selling mid-market to luxury brands, we cater to a high income customer demographic that is less sensitive to the effect of economic downturns.

Subsubsection Title: Strong leadership team with proven track record
Subsubsection Text: Our leadership team is headed by Dr. Moritz Hahn who joined the Company after nine years of experience in various senior roles at Zalando SE. Dr. Hahn has since focused on recruiting a diverse and experienced leadership team that combines entrepreneurial spirit with longstanding industry expertise and a strong commitment to our vision. In the past year, we have grown our senior leadership team including with the addition of our COO, Dr. Andreas Reichhart, our Chief Technology Officer, Ramy Kamel and our SVP People & Organization, Annelot Fluitman. Further, on May 30, 2022, the Group announced the appointment of Axel Salzmann as new Chief Financial Officer of HoldCo, effective July 4, 2022. He follows outgoing Chief Financial Officer Claudius Peleskei. Together, our experienced leadership team has extensive experience in relevant areas. They are supported by an extensive team of professionals working in a variety of specializations who we believe are well-positioned to manage our growing business. We expect that our experienced and entrepreneurial management team will continue to achieve attractive growth for our shareholders while increasing profitability for our expanding business.
We believe that our business is characterized by a number of key strengths that set it apart from our competitors:

Subsubsection Title: Driving customer growth with paid customer acquisition
Subsubsection Text: To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the second quarter of 2021. Paid marketing efforts help us to invite potential new members who will act as new base for future viral growth in underpenetrated regions where we want to grow the most. These new members will drive our future viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members, accelerating our viral engine. Paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer demographics and regions to drive our non-viral growth in areas in which we have currently a low customer penetration (such as Northern Germany and international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly favorable marketing efficiency ratio (defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy divided by marketing spend) and has maintained short payback periods while scaling marketing investment. Moreover, our paid marketing strategy is closely aligned with our brand partners. As illustrated in the chart below, we have experienced strong profitability as the roll-out of performance marketing continues. 120 ----- Note: New segment reporting started in 2021. Adjusted operating expenses in the chart above have been presented adjusted to exclude exceptional items and depreciation and amortization. Source: Company. As a result of these successful performance marketing efforts, we expect our viral engine to further accelerate and continue to drive sustained growth while always focusing on maximum brand protection. See “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition” and “Our Business—Marketing—Paid customer acquisition._

We operate in the highly attractive and growing dedicated online off-price sector and discounted in-season and end-of-season sector in Europe. Our international expansion has increasingly diversified our geographic revenue streams, with the proportion of revenue derived outside our home market Germany steadily increasing in recent years. In 2021, almost one-third of our revenue was generated in our international markets. Our unique proposition provides us with the opportunity to continuously capture market share and participate in the structural growth momentum of our market. We believe that we have developed a proven expansion strategy that will allow us to expand into new international markets and increase penetration in our existing markets: (1) targeting and prioritizing future growth markets, (2) localizing our offering for specific markets, (3) using performance marketing campaigns to establish a customer base and (4) achieving viral customer acquisition that leads to selfreinforcing growth.

Subsubsection Title: Establishing the leading European off-price marketplace
Subsubsection Text: In 2021, we introduced a new marketplace model. Through our marketplace model, we offer our brand partners to market their products on our BestSecret online platform without having BestSecret to hold these products as own inventory. The marketplace model will allow our brand partners to increase their DTC revenue through our online platform. We expect to achieve full scale operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022. Through the expansion of our marketplace offering, we aim to expand our assortment through acquiring new brand partners in the luxury segment and further grow the end of season fashion segment on BestSecret. We view the marketplace as a unique growth opportunity. There are no existing online off-price marketplaces at scale in the sector and we aim to become the number one fashion marketplace for off-price fashion in Europe. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting _our Results of Operations—Marketplace.”_

Subsubsection Title: Taking advantage of the consolidation trend
Subsubsection Text: The dedicated online off-price sector in Germany, our core region, is expected to undergo significant consolidation through 2025, when the top five market participants are expected to command 68% of the market. This consolidation is predicted to be driven by brands reducing the number of their distribution partners, the increasing 121 ----- professionalization of the online space and economies of scale pushing out smaller participants (source: a leading international consultancy firm). As a leading player in the dedicated online off-price market in Germany, Austria and Switzerland, we are in a strong position to take advantage of the consolidation trend within the European market. Our scale, our highly professionalized operations and our value proposition to clear overstock in a discrete manner underline our advantageous position towards brands. With the aim of further benefitting from the consolidation trend, we will continue to invest in increasingly scaling our business and advancing our offering.
To build on our existing success, we have identified the following key elements of our strategy:

BestSecret draws on a heritage of nearly 100 years in the textile industry. In 1924, Herman Schustermann founded a textile company in Makredwitz, Germany and relocated to Munich in the late 1940s. In the early 1950s, Benno Borenstein established his textile business in Munich. The two companies merged in 1960, and, after the death of Herman Schustermann, a new cooperation was established with Herman’s son, Emil Schustermann, and Benno Borenstein as partners. While Schustermann & Borenstein initially started out as a combination of two textile trading companies with regional customer bases around Munich, ready-to-wear clothes were added to the portfolio over the next decades and the closed membership retail business model was born. Prior to 2007, our business operations were limited to our Schustermann & Borenstein offline retail stores in Munich. In 2007, we launched our BestSecret online platform. In 2011, we made the BestSecret online platform available in the Austrian market, setting the first milestone for our international expansion strategy. Since then, we have continued our online expansion with the launch of our online presence in Sweden (2015), Switzerland (2015), France (2016), The Netherlands (2018) and, most recently, Belgium (2021) and Poland (2022). Today, our multi-language online platform is available across Europe with shipping available to 27 countries. We have continued to maintain a limited physical presence with premium and outlet stores in strategic locations, with such locations designed primarily to support our online platform. In 2012, the BestSecret Group’s founding families sold a majority stake of 61% of the business to Ardian. In 2014, construction commenced on the new centralized fulfillment center in Poing, Germany (near Munich), which became operational in early 2016 and consolidated our then-existing seven warehouses. In 2014, we expanded our offline retail footprint through the opening of a new store in Vienna, Austria. In 2016, we acquired Swiss Online Shopping AG, a leading off-price player in Switzerland, to further expand our online presence in Germany, Austria and Switzerland (hereafter referred to as the DACH region). In January 2017, funds owned and managed by Permira acquired a majority stake in the Group. In 2019 and 2020, we expanded our fulfillment center in Poing, Germany by approximately 60% to support our business growth. In late 2020, Dr. Moritz Hahn joined us after nine years of experience at Zalando SE where he served as a member of the Executive Committee and held numerous senior positions. He has since built a strong leadership team of ecommerce pioneers with decades of relevant experience across the tech and e-commerce industry, complemented by senior individuals with long-term experience at and in-depth knowledge of the Company. In early 2021, this senior leadership team announced the new vision “to become the number one online destination for off-price fashion in Europe.” The accompanying strategy is focused on online pure-play, profitable growth across Europe. The offline strategy was sharpened to focus on supporting our online value proposition with premium stores designed to elevate our brand image and outlet stores to clear inventory that fails to sell online. In 2021, the structure and brand profile across the Group was simplified and harmonized, merging and renaming the companies to solely feature the BestSecret name across the Group.

We are committed to providing our customers with attractive discounts across a wide range of clothing, shoes and accessories, while maintaining a high-end shopping and service experience through our online platform on par with other leading online full-price platforms. With our unique proposition, dedicated customer service, comprehensive VIP Program and exclusive partnerships, we reward and care for our customers and seek to transform them into loyal members of our community.
