Our value proposition to customers: - We provide attractive discounts of 20% to 80% – on every article. 122 ----- - Our BestSecret online platform is an exclusive, invitation-only membership model. - During the last twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we provided customers with access to an average of around 3,000 brands, ranging from mid-market to premium to luxury, and currently ship products to 27 countries across Europe. - During the last twelve months ended March 31, 2022, our assortment comprised of an average of approximately 250,000 items, which was full and permanent with no flash-sale campaigns or extensive delivery times. We also offer fresh merchandise, with the majority of our articles younger than six months. - We ensure a high-end seamless shopping experience for our customers – on par with leading online full-price platforms. - We provide a highly integrated, user-friendly online experience with our online platform and app, multiple payment options, efficient and fast fulfillment, easy returns, and excellent customer service. - We offer customers a chance to shop fashion in one of the most sustainable ways – by giving them access to overstock and ensuring that every piece of fashion that is produced is worn.

Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model enables brands to discreetly clear large volumes of overstock in an exclusive environment entirely separate from their full-price channels. This protects their brand equity, supports their sustainability goals and fosters our long-term and deep strategic partnerships. Our value proposition to brand partners: - Our model provides brand partners with a sustainable solution for clearing structural overstock. - We limit the available outside information on brands and discounts through our invitation-only, closed membership model, providing our brand partners with an environment that discreetly clears overstock at scale, protecting retail pricing strategies and brand equity while maximizing overstock value. - Our ability to clear overstock at scale meets the brand partners’ strategies to reduce the number of off-price partners they trade with as they are looking for more control over their products and efficiency. - We provide our brand partners with access to an affluent and loyal customer base. - Our stock-taking wholesale model (in which the inventory risk lies with the Group) enables brands to efficiently and effectively clear overstock from their warehouses and, combined with our pre-orders, creates revenue certainty. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—Marketplace” and “— Operations—Marketplace.”_ - We offer brands the opportunity to participate in the structural shift towards online with their off-price offering while protecting their brand equity. - Our marketplace model gives brands the option to keep control over their inventory and engage with the end-customer directly, while still utilizing our valuable member base and closed platform to discreetly clear overstock. Our business model also works in a challenging macro environment because off-price fashion benefits from the ability to provide brands with a clear solution to handling overstock, including during the COVID pandemic for example, as illustrated by the chart below. 123 ----- Note: Financials refer to the year ended December 31 with the exception of ‘About You’ and ‘Boohoo’ (which each have a February yearend) and asos which has been calendarized in this chart to align with a February year end. Source: Publicly available information.

_Brands and merchandise offering_ Our ability to build long-term relationships with our brand partners is key to ensuring that we have first access to their stock lists. We have been able to retain business relationships with all of our top 50 brands partners from 2017 (excluding intermediaries, private label suppliers and suppliers that went out of business). During the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, we offered merchandise from approximately 3,000 brands on average. This has contributed to the breadth of our product portfolio and ensures that we are not dependent on any brand partner or fashion trend. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our largest brand partner accounted for approximately 4% of total revenue. Our top ten brand partners together accounted for less than 20% of our revenue in the same period. Due to the scale of our platform, we are able to purchase large volumes from our brand partners. We have significantly increased our purchasing budget in-line with the strong growth in our business. At the same time, our brand partners are reducing their number of total online off-price partners, and as the leading online off-price player in Germany by revenue, we believe we are well positioned to benefit from this market consolidation. We are currently implementing sourcing initiatives that enable us to screen and add new brand partners with a proven and systematic approach while allowing us to scale our biggest partners faster. We actively manage our supplier base in order to continuously align with the assortment and volumes of merchandise we require for our business. This enables us to maintain a fresh selection of merchandise year-round – as of March 31, 2022, more than 60% of our products had been in stock for less than six months and more than 90% for less than one year. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, by product category, our revenue comprised 34% womenswear, 25% menswear, 6% kids, 13% shoes, 8% sports and 14% accessories and other categories (including, bags, jewelry, among others). Our buying strategy combines overstock with in-season and end-of-season orders, as well as pre-season collection orders, to allow us to offer seasonally relevant merchandise and a permanent assortment to our customers, while providing additional revenue to our brand partners. We supplement our merchandise from our brand partners with our private label merchandise. Our merchandising teams supports our buying teams in driving sales and profitability by managing inventory investments and driving efficiencies in the purchasing process. Key elements of this integrated approach include financial planning, assortment planning, open-to-buy inventory management, merchandise allocation and management of initial and markdown pricing to enhance gross margin and improve inventory quality. Consistent with customary practice in our industry, our relationships with many of our brand partners are not based on formalized supply agreements but, rather, the regular submission of purchase orders or price agreements renegotiated periodically between the parties on order forms. Because our assortment is permanent, rather than following the flash-sale models of other off-price platforms (in which a discount or promotion is offered by the off-price platform for a short period of time), we are able to provide this broad selection to our customers at any time. As a result, our brand partners can sell their overstock to us on the spot, without having to wait for a flash-sale window. 124 ----- _Marketplace_ In addition to our core wholesale model through which we sell the purchased inventory of branded fashion merchandise at attractive discounts, we introduced a new marketplace model in the year ended December 31, 2021. Through our marketplace model, we offer third-party fashion brands the option to market their products on our BestSecret online platform on own terms without us acquiring these products. We expect to achieve full scale operation of our marketplace model in the second half of 2022. The new marketplace is one of the core pillars of our growth strategy. Our marketplace model has helped us expand into the market for discounted in-season and end-of-season fashion and we are well-positioned to provide our customers with a wider product assortment, which we expect to drive incremental revenue. We also expect the additional products to be from affordable luxury or luxury brands, who tend to prefer marketplace models that give them more control over merchandise presentation and prices. The expanded product selection could potentially contribute to an increase in order size and a reduction in the likelihood of products being out of stock, as we attract more multi-channel brands who hold their own stock in existing product categories. We believe that these features will further support our position as the go-to destination for online off-price fashion, increasing customer satisfaction and loyalty. Furthermore, we anticipate that the marketplace model will increase our profitability through commissions with attractive economics, while having limited inventory and working capital impact. We expect warehousing and fulfillment will typically remain in the hands of third-party suppliers. Our marketplace suppliers are also able to rely on us for fulfillment at their option, which will allow us to benefit from incremental fulfillment fees on marketplace sales.
Our business model offers a two-sided value proposition for both our customers and our brand partners.

As an online fashion platform, our product content is key to helping our customers decide whether to order a product or not, consequently driving sales and avoiding unwanted returns. Our content, both images and text, needs to be accurate, inspiring yet realistic, complete yet relevant, and promote diversity to support our ESG goals. Simultaneously, producing and/or onboarding this content should be fast and cost-effective. In 2021, we provided content for over 400,000 color variants of our merchandise, reduced the time for content to be published online by almost 40% (compared to the prior year) and restructured our content management team. We completely outsourced the creation of all content to two specialized service providers that follow our content guidelines, switched from virtual to real models for the production of the images and refocused our smaller internal team on vendor management, quality management and content innovations.

We offer different payment methods tailored to meet our members’ payment preferences, both in our stores and online shop including credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and pay by invoice. We believe that offering a wide array of payment methods enhances customer satisfaction and improves our check-out conversion with respect to online sales.

We operate a modern fulfillment center in Poing, near Munich, Germany. The facility was expanded by approximately 60% in 2019 and 2020 to support our growing order volumes. The expansion enabled us to regularly ship more than 400,000 online orders with more than 1.4 million items per week during the fourth quarter of 2021. We believe our logistics operations are well-positioned to sustain our future growth with an average increase of 55% in the number of online orders shipped per week from 2020 to 2021. The extended site in Poing now has a size of 173,000 square meters (on a footprint of 48,000 square meters) and can hold up to 14 million items of inventory. Our main fulfillment center in Poing is supported by a network of three smaller sites which 125 ----- are operated by third-party providers that we brought online in 2021 to support our high growth. These additions increased our total storage capacity to approximately 18 million items of inventory. We are in the process of launching a second fulfillment center in Poland, which is expected to start its operations in 2023. We anticipate that once this new fulfillment center is fully ramped up in 2024, it will more than double our current storage capacity at a lower operating expense than our existing network. In addition to our fulfillment centers, our logistics network also includes one externally operated returns processing center in Poland that specializes in processing all returns. In the period from January 1, 2019 to March 31, 2022, approximately 99% of all items have been sold within our ecosystem, with only approximately 1% of returned items being too damaged to be re-sold. In addition to managing our fulfillment and returns center network, we provide a smooth and fast delivery and returns experience at low cost to our customers, with an average delivery time of approximately 3.2 days across our focus markets. We regularly review our supply chain and last-mile setup according to customer expectations and our company priorities. For example, in 2021, we improved the delivery experience for our Dutch customers by switching to a faster last-mile carrier and by reducing delivery lead-times by one to two days on average.

Our customer service team is available to help whenever a customer has a question or a problem. The customer service team also strives to help us understand why our customers contact us in the first place and to ensure we address the underlying root causes. In 2021, these efforts resulted in a reduction of our contact rate per order by 11%. We offer support through telephone, e-mail, and our self-help section on the website. In 2021, the team handled approximately 900,000 e-mails and calls through three external vendors, the third of which went live in 2021 to support the peak volumes typical for the fourth quarter. In addition to fast service with a high contact resolution rate, we focus on offering convenient contact hours in our customers’ local language. We currently support in German (with local agents for our Swiss customers), English, Dutch, French and Swedish and Polish.

To promote customer satisfaction, we aim to make online off-price fashion shopping on our BestSecret online platform as convenient as possible along the entire customer journey. Therefore, the operational activities forming the backbone of our online platform BestSecret consist of four business activities (and corresponding departments): providing our onsite product content, offering convenient payment options, handling outbound and return logistics and answering our customers’ queries.

Our number of active customers was approximately 1.2 million, 1.5 million and 2.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2019, December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, respectively, and 2.5 million for the twelve months ended March 31, 2022, representing a CAGR of 38% between 2019 and 2021. We have established deep relationships with our customers, leading to outstanding retention rates, strong order economics, and high customer engagement. In the year ended December 31, 2021, our customers placed a total of 12.7 million orders. Our customer loyalty program (which we refer to as the “VIP Program”) is designed to deepen our customer relationships. The VIP Program includes three levels of status based on a point system: Silver (more than 300 points), Gold (more than 1,500 points) and Diamond (more than 2,500 points). Members collect points for each online purchase, with €1 spent (after returns) translating into one status point, as well as for recommending new active customers and other activities (such as newsletter subscriptions or special sales events), which we promote regularly. As of March 31, 2022, more than 75% have a VIP status. All Silver, Gold and Diamond members receive commissions in the form of vouchers and commissions for referrals of new active customers and receive a limited number of invitations which they can extend to potential new customers. Depending on their status, our members receive additional invitation vouchers, free priority shipping and sneak previews of new merchandise and benefit from the advantage of a 30-day free return period.

With our “viral engine” model, existing customers invite new customers. Our online revenue has grown at a CAGR of 22% from 2016 to 2020 as a result of the viral model, which we complemented with the introduction of our new paid customer acquisition strategy in the second quarter of 2021. To push our viral growth, we utilize a customer experience toolset that allows us to collect meaningful data for behavioral key drivers and helps us to 126 ----- understand the dynamics behind our viral engine, enabling us to further drive viral growth. Our viral engine is therefore tied into our membership system which grants customers a limited number of invitation rights that can be shared with friends and family. New invitees become members and get access to our assortment of products and also receive a limited number of invitation rights after their first purchase. Our viral model leads to exponential customer growth, expressed by an average of 16 active customers in 2021 stemming from a single customer that became active in 2009.

Beginning in the second quarter of 2021, paid marketing efforts have helped us to invite new potential members to join our closed membership model who can then in turn make use of their invitation rights to invite new members, thereby accelerating our viral engine. Targeted social media advertisements drive our customer growth, especially in areas with currently low penetration (such as Northern Germany and international markets). This “seeding” strategy has been implemented with scaled marketing expenses, while maintaining short payback periods. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key _Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition.”_

The growth of our sales depends on the success of our “viral engine” model and continued incentive programs for customer referrals from existing members. We use various tools, such as daily e-mail newsletters, push notifications as well as social media to support the positioning of our brand, acquire new members and retain existing customers, as well as increase the number of customer visits to our websites, the number of their orders and their basket size per order.

Our customers can access our online platform from their mobile phones, tablets and desktop computers allowing them a multi-device shopping experience. Our technology supports all major online and mobile platforms, including dedicated iOS and Android applications for both smartphones and tablets. We strive to update our applications on a monthly basis to offer customers new features in addition to the daily new themes and product offerings we share through our individualized newsletters. We believe we provide an exceptional experience on our apps with 5.1 billion screen views recorded in 2021. With our growing technology team, we are building a user experience that corresponds to the experience provided by leading full-price online platforms.

Subsubsection Title: In-house cloud native platform and site reliability engineering
Subsubsection Text: We are investing in building a cloud-native technology platform to enable new features to be developed and implemented easily while meeting all relevant resilience and security requirements from the outset. Our technology platform and operations utilize what we believe is best-in-class infrastructure and frameworks from leading cloud providers (such as Microsoft Azure).

Through our cloud-based data infrastructure, key customer and business data is made readily accessible across our business units to ensure faster, more data-driven decision making. We use data to enhance our operational systems, support our business teams in their day-to-day analysis needs, perform business performance reviews and develop artificial intelligence projects to drive value for both our customers and our brand partners.

Our business depends significantly on our ability to process transactions on secure information systems and to store, retrieve, process and manage information. Our primary front-office IT systems are used to market products to end customers, and to manage, track and deliver orders, monitor stock and interface with brand partners and other business relations. In addition, we have made significant investments into the scalability of the IT architecture across systems and processes, to support future growth of the business and to manage orders more efficiently. 127 ----- We also rely on licensed software for back-office operations, including managing financial and human resources activities. We regularly monitor and update our IT systems and processes to ensure reliability, business continuity and performance. Various business continuity plans have been created to respond to possible incidents. These plans are regularly reviewed, tested and updated.

We invest in building what we believe to be a world-class technology organization to support our growing online platform. We have aimed to make technology and data a driver of each and every part of our business by eschewing a dedicated IT department and instead embedding technology and data teams within all of our business units. We currently have more than 35% of our total employees (excl. operational employees) working, in our two main technology hubs in Germany and Spain as of March 31, 2022.

As of March 31, 2022, we owned or had the right to use approximately 40 trademarks (including German, EU, Chinese, Austrian and Swiss trademarks) as well as related tradenames and logos. We also have a portfolio of approximately 80 domain names, notably for our BestSecret website. We believe that our trademarks and tradenames are of value to our business, in particular our BestSecret trademark.

While we operate mostly online, our physical premium and outlet stores in Germany and Austria continue to be part of our business model primarily to support and complement our online platform. In our premium stores we showcase our high-quality value proposition and also cater to the request by some of our brand partners that we offer certain in-season fashion offline prior to an online listing. Our premium stores offer a high-street shopping experience with primarily in-season brand collections at considerable discounts to the recommended retail price, with products typically arranged by key brands and presented, in some cases, in dedicated brand areas. Our outlet stores serve as a sales channel for the overstock we are unable to sell profitably online anymore, such as high-return, single size or color articles and goods of second choice. This allows us to live up to our commitment to conduct our business in an environmentally responsible and sustainable way by selling the almost all of merchandise we receive from our brand partners within our ecosystem. Finally, our stores round off our customer proposition by providing us with an opportunity to interact with customers who still prefer to shop offline. With the combination of our physical retail stores and our online platform, we sold approximately 99% of all items within our ecosystem in 2021, with only approximately 1% of returned items being too damaged to be re-sold. Only items that are severely damaged and cannot be worn anymore are not sold in our outlets, representing a negligible part of our stock. Our offline retail store portfolio primarily comprises four free-standing sites. Two sites are located in Munich, Germany, one site is located in Dresden, Germany, and a fourth site is located in Vienna, Austria. Each of our sites is located on the periphery of the city center (i.e., off high street locations) which translates into higher sales density, lower rent expenses and attractive cost-margin advantages.
The table below sets forth our period average number of employees by subsidiary for the periods indicated:

Subsection Title: For the three months ended For the year ended December 31,** **March 31, 2019** **2020** **2021** **2022 Function

Subsubsection Text: Germany ............................................................ 1,629 1,508 1,493 1,634 International ...................................................... 231 200 202 254 Total ......................................................................** 1.861 1,708 1,695 1,888 During the year ended December 31, 2021 and the three months ended March 31, 2022, we had an average number of 1,695 and 1,888 employees, respectively. We use temporary employees for our logistics functions, in particular. 128 ----- The number of such employees fluctuates throughout the year and is typically higher in the second half of the year, particularly in the period leading up to the holiday season. We believe that our relationships with our employees are good. We have not suffered any disruptions to our business as a result of work stoppages or strikes in recent years. None of our employees are represented by works councils (Betriebsrat), and, except for Best Secret Wien, none of our subsidiaries is bound by any collective bargaining agreements (Tarifverträge) or is a member of an employer association (Arbeitgeberverband). Due to mandatory membership in the Austrian Chamber of Commerce (Wirtschaftskammer), Best Secret Wien is bound by two collective bargaining agreements for employees and apprentices in commercial operations (Kollektivvertrag für Angestellte und Lehrlinge in Handelsbetrieben and Kollektivvertrag für Handelsarbeiter). According to the German One-Third Participation Act (Drittelbeteiligungsgesetz), we may be required to implement a supervisory board with an employee representative at the levels of Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH in the future.

We have been, and may from time to time be, party to various claims and legal proceedings arising in the ordinary course of our business such as employee claims and intellectual property disputes, among others. We have not been within the past twelve months, and we are not currently a party to any governmental, legal, administrative, arbitration or dispute proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, that has had, or is expected to have, a material adverse effect on our financial position and results of operations.

We maintain insurance against various risks related to the ordinary operations of our business, including general business interruption insurance and third-party liability, property damage, electronic damage, transportation damage and directors’ and officers’ liability insurance as well as cyber-security insurance. We conduct periodic reviews of our insurance coverage, both in terms of coverage limits and deductibles. We believe that the types and amounts of insurance coverage that we maintain are consistent with customary industry standards. However, no assurances can be given that this coverage will be sufficient to cover the cost of defense or damages in the event of a significant claim.

Subsubsection Title: Our Business Model and Sustainability Program
Subsubsection Text: We aim to be part of the solution to the fashion industry’s overstock sustainability challenge: By focusing on overstock clearance, we aim to reduce resource use and waste in the fashion industry. While second-hand retailers work on extending the active use time of items and providing them with a second life, we aim to make sure that every piece of fashion has its first life. In addition, we also initiated our Sustainability Program to establish clear initiatives and transparent criteria against which we will measure our progress to becoming even more sustainable. We think of sustainability in two broad categories: what we sell (our articles) and how we sell it to our customers (our orders). Within these two broad categories, we have chosen to focus on environmental and social matters, in accordance with the external standards most relevant for the fashion industry.

We have created a governance structure to promote responsibility and accountability for ESG matters across the Company. Furthermore, we have also implemented a meeting and alignment structure that we believe will allow us to progress in our ESG efforts through regular alignments and meetings, in particular in our Sustainability Steering Committees and our broader Sustainability team, as well as through reporting back to our Advisory Board.

Based on numbers from recent years, 85% of all textiles in the fashion industry end up on landfills. Also, the fashion industry is responsible for 10% of global carbon dioxide emissions. We believe our business model inherently contributes to more environmental sustainability in the fashion industry. By focusing on overstock clearance, we help ensure that nearly every piece of fashion that is fit-to-wear finds an owner, thereby reducing the amount of fashion that is discarded as waste. In fact, in the year ended December 31, 2021, 79% of our total NMV was overstock merchandise. We give fashion its first life, just as second-hand retailers provide products with a second life. In addition, our online off-price model provides our customers with a more sustainable alternative to shopping in remote outlet centers. The majority of studies conducted on the topic conclude that online shopping on average leads to lower carbon emissions compared to in-store shopping. This can be attributed to consolidated shipments and well-utilized infrastructure and is especially the case for deliveries that replace private transport over long distances. We support and complement our online platform with our physical premium and outlet stores in Germany and Austria, which allow us to sell returns which we would have not been able to sell online because they have not met our strict quality standards after we have received them. We have made ESG one of our corporate priorities. In addition to our inherently sustainable business model, we plan to further increase sustainability in what we sell and how we sell through our own Sustainability Program. As part of this program, we strive to create a positive environmental and social impact, balancing the needs of our brand partners, customers, employees, investors, the environment, and wider society with the ultimate goal of becoming an even more sustainable online fashion company. Further, as part of our commitment to ESG, we recently published our sustainability report and are planning to publish this report annually going forward. 129 -----

We do not own any real estate. Our corporate headquarters and all of our stores are leased pursuant to commercial lease agreements. Lease agreements for our stores are generally long-term leases with an initial fixed term of up to 10 years and the option to extend the lease on one or more occasions for an additional period of up to five years. All lease agreements have been entered into by Best Secret GmbH with the exception of our site in Vienna, which is leased by Best Secret Retail Wien GmbH. A number of our lease agreements provide for the right to sublet the leased premises with the prior consent of the lessor. Our lease agreement for our premises in Munich expires in 2027. Our lease agreements for our Dornach premises expire in 2025 (premium store) and 2027 (outlet store), respectively. Our lease agreement for our site in Vienna expires in 2024. Our lease agreement for our site in Dresden expires in 2028. In addition, we have a lease agreement for our former Frankfurt site, for which we are currently seeking a sublessee. In September 2015, we entered into a lease agreement relating to our logistics center in Poing, Germany, for a fixed 10-year term. The lease agreement also includes options to extend the contract in five-year increments until 2035. In addition, in June 2016, we entered into an amendment agreement in relation to the existing lease agreement regarding our lease at Margaretha-Ley-Ring 10 and 27 in Aschheim-Dornach where we moved our corporate headquarters in the first half year of 2017, which will expire in 2024 and 2027, respectively. Most of our lease agreements for retail space in Germany are with entities controlled by the Schustermann and Borenstein families, and the limited partners of the lessor under the lease agreement relating to the Poing facility also include certain individuals from the Schustermann and Borenstein families. For more information, see “Certain _Relationships and Related Party Transactions”._ In May 2022, we entered into a lease agreement relating to our new fulfillment center in Sulechów, Poland. The new fulfillment center is scheduled to enter preliminary stages of operation in 2023 and is expected to be larger than our current main fulfillment center in Poing, Germany. In general, the amount of rent payable under our lease agreements is fixed upon the signing of the relevant lease agreement. Certain of our lease agreements provide for rent adjustments based on consumer price indices or provide for step ups of rent amounts every several years.

We operate in several countries and our business is subject to various regulatory requirements under the laws of the European Union (“EU”) and national laws in relevant countries. Laws and regulations applicable to our operations may differ due to different national and local laws. Applicable regulatory requirements relate, in particular, to our dealing with customers, consumer protection, and the processing of customer data. By creating a common regulatory framework for the member states of the European Union (“EU Member

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: The processing of personal data within the EU and the EEA is primarily governed by the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (Datenschutz-Grundverordnung, “GDPR”) which became effective on May 25, 2018. The GDPR applies to any enterprise that is processing the personal data of living individuals (data subjects) within the EU/EEA regardless of its location and the data subjects’ citizenship or residence. It is also applicable where the processing activities are related to (1) the offering of goods or services, irrespective of whether a payment of the data subject is required, to such data subjects in the EU/EEA, or (2) the monitoring of data subject’s behavior as far as their behavior takes place within the EU/EEA. The GDPR aims primarily to give control to individuals over their personal data and to simplify the regulatory environment for international business by harmonizing the EU regulatory framework of data protection. Under the GDPR, personal data may only be processed for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and only if the processing is covered by a legal basis (e.g., consent of the data subject, if it is necessary for the performance of a contract, to comply with a legal obligation, or if we rely on our overriding legitimate interests). Furthermore, data subjects must be informed transparently before the processing of personal data about the circumstances of the intended processing activities (e.g., purposes, retention periods, recipients of the personal data). This aims to enable the data subjects to effectively exercise their rights under the GDPR (e.g., the right of access to or the right to erasure of their personal data, if the relevant requirements are met). Furthermore, the GDPR provides restrictive requirements as regards solely automated decision making and profiling activities, which could for example impact marketing activities based on such processing of personal data. The GDPR also stipulates that certain technical and organizational measures must be implemented to protect the personal data depending on the amount of and potential risk for the personal data processed. These measures may include physical security against unauthorized access and manipulation, password security, reasonable encryption as well as protection against accidental data loss, destruction, or damage. Based on the general accountability principle of the GDPR, the processing activities and the corresponding data protection measures must be sufficiently documented (such as keeping records of processing activities). Furthermore, under the GDPR, special care and safeguards must also be taken when transferring personal data to countries outside the EEA to ensure that a level of data protection equivalent to the EU is in place for the processing of personal data. Recent legal developments in the EU, e.g., the ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union (“CJEU”) of July 16, 2020 (case no C-311/18, Data Protection Commissioner v Facebook Ireland Limited and Maximillian Schrems, socalled “Schrems II”), have created complexity and uncertainty regarding such data transfers. The GDPR provides for fines of up to €20.0 million or 4% of global turnover on a group basis, whichever is greater and depending on the respective breach for non-compliance with GDPR provisions. Failure to comply with the GDPR can also result in claims for compensation for financial or non-financial damages claimed by individuals under Article 82 GDPR and cease and desist claims. Non-compliance may further result in proceedings or actions against us by governmental authorities, including corresponding costs for litigation, or require us to change our operations and/or cease or modify our use of certain personal data sets. We may also be contractually required to indemnify and hold harmless third parties from the costs or consequences of non-compliance with data protection requirements. Individual EU Member States, like Germany, also provide criminal sanctions for specific severe violations. Finally, in addition to these regulatory risks, infringement of the GDPR can lead to reputational risk and significantly undermine customers’ trust in our business. In the event of a breach of the protection of personal data, we are required to submit data breach notifications to the relevant local data protection authorities (“DPAs”) within 72 hours beginning with the awareness of a possible breach. If the breach concerned entails a high risk to the rights of the data subjects, they also need to be informed. Data subjects, DPAs and competitors, as well as consumer associations, and other authorized associations may pursue claims, including potentially mass litigation, against us for breach of the GDPR. We are subject to the supervision of the Bavarian State Office for Data Protection Supervision (Bayerisches _Landesamt für Datenschutzaufsicht). To comply with regulatory requirements imposed on us, we have, inter alia,_ established a data protection organization as well as data protection processes, including, without limitation, 131 ----- appointing data protection officers, where required, and have implemented data protection policies for all employees dealing with personal data. However, the task of meeting all the data protection law requirements is complex, in particular taking into account that there are still material legal uncertainties in various respects and that data protection authorities continuously publish more detailed GDPR guidance. In addition to the GDPR, the German Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, “BDSG”) applies to the processing of personal data within Germany. The BDSG provides further data protection rules by making use of derogation and opening clauses in the GDPR. It stipulates, inter alia, additional requirements to limitations on the scope of data subjects’ rights and personal data processing in the employment context. Other EU Member States implemented similar local data protection acts. Furthermore, based on its data strategy, the European Union plans to comprehensively further revise the legal framework for the handling data, for example through the proposed Digital Markets Act and the Digital Services Act. Such future changes of the legal framework may have further impacts to our processing of data.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: Our business activities are also subject to the German Telecommunication and Telemedia Data Protection Act (Telekommunikation-Telemedien-Datenschutz-Gesetz, “TTDSG”), which came into force on December 1, 2021 and consolidates the previous data protection regulations of the German Telecommunication Act (Telekommunikationsgesetz, “TKG”) and the German Telemedia Act (Telemediengesetz, “TMG”). To the extent the TTDSG transposes the provisions of EU Directive 2002/58/EC on privacy and electronic communications (“ePrivacy Directive”), it prevails over the GDPR. The TTDSG provides special data protection rules and also stipulates provisions on the use of cookies and similar technologies, regardless of whether the data is personal data or not. Generally, the end user must actively consent to the use of cookies and similar technologies on the basis of clear and comprehensive information, except for cookies and similar technologies that are technically strictly essential for a service requested by the end user and for cookies and similar technologies that are used exclusively for the transmission of messages via a public telecommunications network. This is also in line with recent case law by the European Court of Justice and the German Federal Court (Bundesgerichtshof), which have both specified the requirements on the use of cookies. These provisions and rulings are relevant for our online business and the use of web tracking tools, each of which relies on cookies and similar technologies, and must be taken into account by all website operators. In addition, the TTDSG stipulates that we as a telemedia service provider must implement certain technical and organizational measures in order to protect our customers’ data and our IT systems (e.g., protection against unauthorized access and (technical) interference). The TMG continues to remain relevant to the extent information requirements are not superseded by either the GDPR or the TTDSG. The TMG requires telemedia service providers to provide certain information on their website, such as name and address and contact details (Section 5 TMG). Non-compliance with the provisions on cookies and similar technologies under the TTDSG may result in monetary fines of up to €300,000. Moreover, the requirements for the use of cookies and similar technologies is constantly evolving. For example, there is a draft Regulation of Privacy and Electronic Communications (“ePrivacy Regulation”) that would replace the current ePrivacy Directive and national implementation laws, such as German implementation laws in the TTDSG. While the text of the ePrivacy Regulation is still under development, data protection authorities’ recent guidance is driving increased attention to cookies and similar technologies.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: We are affected by consumer protection laws that apply to businesses generally and, in particular, to businesses that operate on the internet. At the EU level, consumer protection is comprehensively regulated by various directives, inter alia: - Directive (EU) 2019/771 of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 20, 2019 on certain aspects concerning contracts for the sale of goods (“EU **Sales of Goods Directive”); - Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of October 25, 2011, as amended, on consumer rights; 132 ----- - Directive 2005/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 11, 2005, as amended, concerning unfair business-to-consumer commercial practices in the internal market; - Directive 2000/31/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of June 8, 2000 on certain legal aspects of information society services, in particular electronic commerce, in the Internal Market (“eCommerce Directive”); - Council Directive 93/13/EEC of April 5, 1993, as amended, on unfair terms in consumer contracts; - Directive 98/6/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 16, 1998, as amended, on consumer protection in the indication of the prices of products offered to customers. With Directive (EU) 2019/2161 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 27, 2019 as regards the better enforcement and modernization of Union consumer protection rules, the EU amended the existing EU instruments for strengthened consumer protection. EU Member States had to transpose the new rules in their national laws by November 28, 2021 and must apply these new national laws since May 28, 2022. In Germany, for example, we are therefore subject to various laws concerning the protection of consumers, which have been primarily laid down in the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch). Pursuant to these laws, we are responsible for the conformity of the shipped products with the agreed or implied quality at the time the purchase is made. And a consumer has certain statutory warranty rights (irrespective of our fault) should a product be defective at the time of delivery. If a product is defective, consumers may generally require the retailer to repair or replace the product in question free of charge. The German Civil Code also regulates distance selling contracts (Fernabsatzverträge) to protect consumer interests. The consumer benefits, among other things, from a statutory right of withdrawal from a distance selling contract within a period of 14 days after the consumer has received the respective goods and has been informed about his right of withdrawal in a manner compliant with the statutory requirements. During this time, a purchase may be cancelled without any specific reason. If the consumer has not been properly informed about his/her statutory right of withdrawal, the respective right expires twelve months and 14 days after receipt of the goods. If customers exercise their right of withdrawal, they must return the goods and the retailer must refund the purchase price, including any shipping costs originally charged. However, the retailer is not obliged to reimburse consumers for any additional costs if the consumer has expressly opted for a more expensive type of delivery (e.g., express delivery). On the other hand, the consumer must usually bear the costs of returning the goods, unless the retailer failed to inform him or her accordingly or the retailer has expressly agreed to bear these costs. The consumer also has to compensate the retailer for any loss in value of the returned goods in case such loss is due to the consumer’s handling of the goods in a way that was not necessary to examine its condition, features and functionalities of the product and the retailer has informed the consumer accordingly. With the substantial 2022 reform of German contract law (Schuldrechtsreform 2022), the German legislator has introduced further consumer-friendly regulations based on the EU Sales of Goods Directive, e.g., the reversal of the burden of proof regarding the defectiveness of the purchased item at the time of handover at the expense of the retailer extended from six months to one year. The introduced amendments to the German Civil Code entered into force on January 1, 2022. The German Civil Code, in connection with the Introductory Law to the German Civil Code (Einführungsgesetz _zum Bürgerlichen Gesetzbuch), also stipulates that certain mandatory information must be provided to the_ consumer, including material characteristics of the purchased goods, the identity of the seller, terms of payment, delivery and/or service, price and payment details and the statutory right of withdrawal. In addition, in accordance with the German Price Indication Regulation (Preisangabenverordnung), retailers must ensure, among other things, that the price of each product is displayed clearly, precisely and legibly and shall be accessible, legible and intelligible on websites. Against the backdrop of Directive (EU) 2019/2161 as regards the better enforcement and modernization of Union consumer protection rules, the German Price Indication Regulation has been amended to include, as of May 28, 2022, new regulations for the announcement of price reductions for goods. The overall aim is to make the original price on which a price reduction is based more transparent to the consumer. To this effect, each announcement of a price reduction also has to state the lowest price applied by the retailer within a period of 30 days prior to the application of the price reduction. The aim is also to put a stop to short-term price increases in advance of price 133 ----- reductions. Infringements of the Price Indication Obligation may constitute administrative offenses that can be sanctioned with an administrative fine (Bußgeld) of up to €25,000. We are also subject to rules and regulations relating to unfair competition in the jurisdictions in which we operate. In particular, in Germany, competitors, consumer associations (Verbraucherverbände) and other authorized associations may seek to enforce alleged violations of, or the failure to comply with, the Act Against Unfair Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren Wettbewerb). Based on the Act Against Unfair Competition, unfair commercial practices are illegal. Unfair commercial practices include, inter alia, commercial practices which are misleading (including untrue information as to the existence of a special price advantage, the price or the manner in which it is calculated), which constitute an unreasonable nuisance, which make use of harassment, coercion, or undue influence, as well as unsolicited marketing (including unsolicited e-mail marketing). Additionally, we must comply with information requirements relating to the European Online Dispute Resolution (“ODR”) platform for consumers. On January 9, 2016, Regulation (EU) 524/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 21, 2013 on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes (“ODR Regulation”) entered into force. It requires online retailers to disclose certain information on their websites to ensure that consumers are aware of the new ODR possibilities. Another information requirement is set up by Directive 2013/11/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 21, 2013 on alternative dispute resolution for consumer disputes (“ADR-Directive”). In Germany, for instance, the implementation act, the Consumer Dispute Resolution Act (Verbraucherstreitbeilegungsgesetz) generally obliges online retailers to inform their customers to what extent they are willing or obliged to participate in alternative dispute resolution procedures. Anyone who has undertaken or is obliged to participate in dispute resolution proceedings must provide information on the address and website of the competent alternative dispute resolution body.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: We source many of our products within the European Union. Within the European internal market, the principle of free movement of goods, as stipulated in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, applies. With respect to import and export of goods from countries which are not members of the EU, we must comply with national and European foreign trade and customs regulations. At the EU level our relevant regulatory framework is based on the Union Customs Code (Regulation (EU) 952/2013). In Germany, the Foreign Trade and Payments Act (Außenwirtschaftsgesetz) and the Ordinance on the Foreign Trade and Payments Act (Außenwirtschaftsverordnung) constitute additional regulations which, _inter alia, set forth rules of procedure. Infringements of customs or foreign trade regulations may be sanctioned with an administrative fine (Bußgeld) if categorized as administrative offenses or with a fine (Geldstrafe) or custodial sentence (Freiheitsstrafe) if categorized as criminal acts. Depending on the extent and nature of the underlying administrative offense, the respective fine may amount to up to €30,000 for violations of procedural regulations and up to €500,000 for violations of other regulations of the Foreign Trade and Payments Act. Even higher fines are possible in case of skimming of profits (Gewinnabschöpfung). The authorities may from time to time undertake external audits (Außenwirtschaftsprüfung) to assess whether we have complied with the regulations of the Foreign Trade and Payments Act and the pertaining ordinances. Whereas imports and exports within the EEA are in principle not liable to customs duty, the movement of goods beyond the frontiers of the EEA may be subject to customs. The customs control charges, _inter alia, statutory import duties (Einfuhrabgaben). Customs offices may from time to time initiate customs inspections (Zollprüfung) to assess whether customs regulations have been infringed. The countries belonging to the EEA may charge customs duties if products are exported into such non-EEA countries. We also distribute our products in Switzerland (which does not belong to the EEA). Switzerland, however, is party to a preferential agreement (Präferenzabkommen), such agreements being concluded with the European Union and certain other countries in order to facilitate the exchange of goods. The rate of customs duty for goods exported into countries which are parties to the preferential agreement is considerably lower than the regular customs duty rate. The customs administration assesses in a preference inspection (Präferenzprüfung) in accordance with the Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/2447, as amended, which applies from May 1, 2016, whether the requirements and conditions set forth in the preferential agreement are complied with.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Title: Product Liability and Textile Labeling Law
Subsubsection Text: In Germany, in addition to the general liability under civil law, we are in general subject to liability under the Product Liability Act (Produkthaftungsgesetz) which is based on Council Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985 on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the EU Member States concerning 134 ----- liability for defective products. Under this act, we are liable, regardless of fault, for damage to life, body, health and property caused by defective products to the extent we qualify as the “manufacturer” under the Product Liability Act. This may be the case if we actually manufacture the products but also if we place our own logo or name on the products of if we import the products into the EEA. The producer`s liability is limited to an amount of €85 million. In the case of damage to property, the injured party has to pay for damages up to an amount of €500. Furthermore, although there is no coherent legal framework for trade in textiles in Germany, certain laws and regulations may apply to us. For example, the German Food, Consumer Goods and Feed Act (Lebensmittel-, _Bedarfsgegenstände- und Futtermittelgesetzbuch) and the German Ordinance on Consumer Goods_ (Bedarfsgegenständeverordnung) include special regulations which aim at preventing possible damage to human health caused by textiles, especially due to toxic substances or contamination. Similarly, the German Chemicals Prohibition Ordinance (Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung) prohibits the placing on the market of certain substances and preparations as well as products containing such substances or preparations as listed in detail therein. Furthermore, textiles may only be made available on the German market if they comply with the German Product Safety Act (Produktsicherheitsgesetz) which is based on Directive 2001/95/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of December 3, 2001 on general product safety (“Product Safety Directive”) and complements the EU regulations on market surveillance and compliance of products (Regulation (EC) 765/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of July 9, 2008, as amended, setting out the requirements for accreditation and market surveillance relating to the marketing of products and Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 of the European Parliament and of the Council of June 20, 2019 on market surveillance and compliance of products). Under German jurisdiction, this regulation is accompanied by the Market Surveillance Act (Marktüberwachungsgesetz) which came into force on July 6, 2021. These provisions on product safety apply to a wide variety of non-food products, including clothing and footwear and are applicable to both the e-commerce and physical stores. They oblige retailers to ensure that their products comply with applicable safety requirements. Moreover, a retailer is generally required to participate in the monitoring of the safety of its products. Infringements of product safety regulations may be sanctioned with fines and in severe cases with criminal sanctions. We are further subject to the Regulation (EU) 1007/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 September 2011 on textile fiber names and related labelling and marking of the fiber composition of textile product pursuant to which textiles may only be made available on the European market if they are labeled or marked with certain information, in particular regarding textile fibers. Depending on the implementing laws of the EU member states, infringements of the textile labeling requirements may constitute administrative offenses. In Germany the Regulation is supplemented by the Act on Textile Labeling (Textilkennzeichnungsgesetz). This law creates the necessary conditions for effective enforcement of the Regulation (EU) 1007/2011 and, in particular, lays down regulations on the powers of the authorities involved in market surveillance and on administrative offences. Administrative offenses may be sanctioned with a fine of up to €10,000. Moreover, violations of the provisions may be considered as unfair trade practices which are prohibited under the German Act Against Unfair Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren Wettbewerb). As regards sold footwear, Directive 94/11/EC of European Parliament and Council of 23 March 1994, as amended, on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the EU Member States relating to labelling of the materials used in the main components of footwear for sale to the consumer is applicable. The German legislator transposed the directive into national law by means of the German Ordinance on Consumer Goods which contains regulations concerning the content and form of footwear labeling.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to statutory provisions regarding waste management and packaging. Directive 2008/98/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 19, 2008 on waste (European Waste Framework Directive), as amended, provides for the legislative basis of a recycling society in the EU. Its provisions on the collection, transport, recovery and disposal of waste requires the EU Member States to take appropriate measures for prevention of waste as a matter of priority and to ensure that waste is recovered or disposed of without endangering human health or causing harm to the environment. In Germany, the main waste disposal provisions are set forth in the Waste Management Act (Kreislaufwirtschaftsgesetz) which is supplemented and concretized by a number of regulations. Online retailers are subject to regulations on packaging. Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste and its German implementation law, the Packaging Act (Verpackungsgesetz) aim to reduce the impact of packaging waste on the environment. To this end, various obligations are imposed on the manufacturers and 135 ----- retailers. The German Packaging Act requires both to participate in a disposal and recycling system and imposes certain takeback obligations. Typically, these requirements are complied with by registering one’s activities in the German waste packaging register and paying a license fee based on the amount of packaging waste put into circulation. In general, online retailers are only responsible for the shipping packaging. When importing products, however, the retailer may also be responsible for sales packaging. Infringements of these regulations may be sanctioned by administrative fines of up to €200,000.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: We are also subject to regulations on cybersecurity. The GDPR and national laws like the German BDSG and TTDSG require us to implement certain technical and organizational measures to protect our customers’ data and IT systems. These measures may include physical security against unauthorized access and manipulation, password security, reasonable encryption as well as protection against accidental data loss, destruction, or damage. In case of a personal data breach, we are obliged to notify the breach to the competent data protection authority within 72 hours after having become aware of it, unless the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons. When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons, we are also required to communicate the personal data breach to the affected data subject without undue delay.

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: Directive (EU) 2015/2366 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 25, 2015 on payment services in the internal market, among others, covers online-based payment services, provides for a uniform regulation of payments via internet and mobile phones and increased customer protection and requirements for user authentication, such as two-factor authentication. The German legislator has adopted the Law on the transposition of Payment Services Directive Two (Gesetz zur Umsetzung der Zweiten Zahlungsdiensterichtlinie) which mainly amended the German Payment Services Supervision Act (Zahlungsdiensteaufsichtsgesetz) and the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch).

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Title: Supply Chain Duty of Care Act
Subsubsection Text: On June 25, 2021, the German Supply Chain Duty of Care Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz¸ “Supply

Subsection Title: States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our
Subsubsection Text: business. EU law comprises both directives as well as regulations. While the latter apply directly in all EU Member 130 ----- States, EU directives need to be transposed into national law. Therefore, standards contained in EU directives may slightly differ from one EU Member State to another depending on the actual implementation into national law. The following section provides a brief overview of selected EU and German legislation and regulations which are applicable to our business. Similar laws and regulations also apply to our business in other jurisdictions in which we operate.

Subsection Title: Chain Duty of Care Act”) was passed and published in the Federal Law Gazette on July 16, 2021. The Supply
Subsubsection Text: Chain Duty of Care Act will become effective as of January 1, 2023, with the exception on certain administrative regulations. The legislation will require affected companies to conduct adequate due diligence throughout their supply chains in relation to human rights and (certain) environmental risks. This includes conducting a risk analysis, establishing internal responsibilities for human rights and environmental protection, comprehensive preventative measures, and grievance mechanisms. Additionally, companies concerned are obliged to continuously document the fulfillment of due diligence obligations and to keep records in this respect for at least seven years. In an annual report, which must be published on the company’s website and submitted electronically to the competent authority, companies must report on their adherence to due diligence obligations. The report needs to be submitted no later than four months after the end of the business year. Infringements of these regulations may be sanctioned by administrative fines of up to €800,000. However, from January 1, 2023, the Supply Chain Duty of Care Act will only be applicable to companies in Germany with generally at least 3,000 employees. From January 1, 2024, companies in Germany with generally at least 1,000 employees will be covered as well. Therefore, our business does not have to comply with the Supply Chain Duty of Care Act until the later date. The Supply Chain Duty of Care Act may be subject to change based on European legislation. 136 -----

The Issuer is a company with limited liability (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung) organized under the laws of Germany. It was incorporated on July 19, 2016. The Issuer is registered with the commercial register of the local court of Munich (Amtsgericht) under registration number HRB 227078 and its registered office is Margaretha-Ley-Ring 27, 85609 Aschheim, Germany. The managing directors of the Issuer are responsible for managing the day-to-day business of the Issuer in accordance with applicable German law and its articles of association (Satzung) (the “Articles of Association”) and the rules of procedure (Geschäftsordnung) for the board of managing directors of the Issuer. In addition, the managing directors must ensure appropriate control of risk within the Issuer and its subsidiaries so that any developments jeopardizing its future as a going concern may be identified at an early stage. The managing directors legally represent the Issuer in dealings with third parties and in court. Currently, the Issuer has also established an advisory board (Beirat) (the “Advisory Board”) in accordance with its Articles of Association. The Advisory Board may not exercise management functions, it advises the managing directors on the management of the Issuer and monitors its conduct of business. The managing directors and the members of the Advisory Board owe duties of loyalty and care vis-à-vis the Issuer. In discharging their duties, the members of these corporate bodies must consider a broad range of interests, which in turn includes the interests of shareholders, employees, creditors and, to a certain extent, the general public. The managing directors or the members of the Advisory Board are jointly and severally liable to the Issuer for any damages that may arise if they fail to discharge their duties, provided that the liability of members of the Advisory Board towards the Issuer is limited by the Articles of Association to willful misconduct and gross negligence. As a basic principle under German law, a shareholder has no direct recourse against any managing director or members of the Advisory Board in the event that they breach a duty _vis-à-vis the Issuer. Except as otherwise provided in the Articles of Association, only the shareholders’ meeting (Gesellschafterversammlung) of the Issuer (the “Shareholders’ Meeting”) may exercise the right to bring claims for damages against the managing directors or members of the Advisory Board. The Issuer has taken out a directors and officers liability insurance policy for all managing directors and all members of the Advisory Board. The Shareholders’ Meeting may issue instructions which are binding upon the managing directors. Instructions that would result in violations of mandatory provisions of German corporate law and in particular, capital maintenance rules, are in any event prohibited.

The managing directors are responsible for managing the business of the Issuer in accordance with the German Limited Liability Companies Act (Gesetz betreffend die Gesellschaften mit beschränkter Haftung, GmbHG), its Articles of Association and the rules of procedure (Geschäftsordnung) for the board of managing directors of the Issuer (the “Management Board Rules of Procedure”). Members of the managing directors are appointed for an indefinite period, but the Shareholders’ Meeting may revoke the appointment of each managing director at any time. The managing directors have overall responsibility for the Issuer’s business. Managing directors may not deal with, or vote on, measures relating to proposals, arrangements or contracts between himself or herself and the Issuer. The ‘Articles of Association provide that it can only be legally represented by two managing directors or by one managing director in conjunction with an authorized signatory who holds a power of attorney (Prokurist). According to Article 7 of the Articles of Association, the shareholders’ meeting may assign sole power of representation (Einzelvertretungsbefugnis) to certain or all of the managing directors. 137 ----- _Managing Directors_ The following table sets forth the managing directors of the Issuer.

Subsubsection Title: Dr. Moritz Hahn studied economics in Stuttgart, Germany and holds a PhD in Economics from the University of
Subsubsection Text: Munich. After his studies he started his career as a consultant at McKinsey & Company Inc. In 2017, he became Member of the Executive Committee at Zalando, after working at Zalando since 2011. He is also a member of the Supervisory Board at Mast-Jägermeister SE. Claudius Peleskei was CFO of the_** BestSecret Group until June 30, 2022. He joined in 2015. From 2019 to 2020 he was CFO at Wunschgutschein GmbH before rejoining BestSecret as CFO in 2020. He holds a degree in Economics and began his career as auditor at KPMG, where he qualified as a Certified Public Accountant and completed his Tax Advisor Certificate. He later held the position of head of finance at international companies, namely Decathlon, Josef Gartner and, from 2015 to the beginning of 2020, at BestSecret Group.

Dr. Moritz Hahn ......................................... 43 2020 Chief Executive Officer Axel Salzmann[(1)] ........................................ 63 2022 Chief Financial Officer (1) On May 30, 2022, the Company announced the appointment of Axel Salzmann as new Chief Financial Officer of HoldCo, effective July 4, 2022. He follows outgoing Chief Financial Officer Claudius Peleskei. Mr. Salzmann’s formal appointment as managing director of the Company will follow in due course. The business address of the managing directors is Margaretha-Ley-Ring 27, 85609 Aschheim, Germany.

According to the Articles of Association of the Issuer and the rules of procedure of the Advisory Board (the “Advisory Board Rules of Procedure”), the Advisory Board may comprise up to ten members which are appointed by the Shareholders’ Meeting. The Shareholders’ Meeting also determines the term of office of the members of the Advisory Board and may remove members of the Advisory Board at any time. One of the members of the Advisory Board is designated as chairman (Vorsitzender) by resolution of the Shareholders’ Meeting by a simple majority of the votes cast. Such appointment can be recalled under certain circumstances by resolution of the Shareholders’ Meeting without cause. In accordance with the Advisory Board Rules of Procedure, resolutions of the Advisory Board are passed by a simple majority of the members of the Advisory Board. In order to constitute a quorum, at least three Permira members (partners, board members, directors and employees of Permira Beteiligungsberatung GmbH and its affiliates, excluding the Company) of the Advisory Board must be present at the meeting. The Advisory Board is required to meet at least once per month. While the managing directors have exclusive power to manage the business affairs of the Issuer, certain significant matters set forth in the Management Board Rules of Procedure shall not be taken by the managing directors without having obtained the prior approval of the Advisory Board, unless the relevant matter has been approved by the shareholders of the Issuer. _Advisory Board_ The following table sets forth the Advisory Board of BestSecret Group.

Subsubsection Title: David Haines holds a degree with first class honors in Business Administration from the University of Greenwich,
Subsubsection Text: London. In 2018, Mr. Haines was appointed group chief executive officer of Upfield Europe B.V., the world’s largest plant-based consumer product company. Prior to his current activities, Mr. Haines held numerous executive positions in leading corporations, including Unilever plc (1985 – 1989), Mars Incorporated (1989 – 1998) and The Coca Cola Company (1998 – 2000). Between 2000 and 2004, he served in executive positions at Vodafone Group plc. After 2004, Mr. Haines was managing director of Grohe Holding GmbH and Grohe Beteiligungs GmbH as well as chief executive officer and chairman of the management board of Grohe AG, a leading manufacturer of bathroom appliances, and its predecessors. Between 2012 and 2018, he also served as non-executive director at Imperial Brands plc and was chairman of its remuneration committee. Jörg Rockenhäuser_** holds a Master’s degree from University of Münster, Germany, and a PhD from the University of Bochum, Germany. He is managing partner and head of DACH at Permira, where he has also served on the Investment Committee since 2009 and on the Executive Committee from 2008 to 2021. He is also the Chairman of Neuraxpharm.

Subsubsection Title: Kim Felixmüller holds a Master’s in International Business from ESCP Europe, France. He is currently working
Subsubsection Text: as Principal at Permira where he focuses on investment opportunities in the consumer sector. Prior to joining Permira, Kim worked as Engagement Manager at McKinsey & Company in Germany for three years, where he focused on strategy and corporate finance projects across industries.

Subsubsection Title: Boris Mittermüller holds a Master’s degree from ESCP Business School, France, an MBA from INSEAD and a
Subsubsection Text: PhD in Finance from RWTH Aachen, Germany. He is currently working as Principal at Permira where he focuses on investment opportunities in the consumer and technology sectors. Prior to joining Permira, Boris served as SVP International Markets for Delivery Hero SE where he was part of the global management team. He also worked for Rocket Internet SE and co-founded foodora (a food delivery platform sold to Delivery Hero SE) and circ (a micro-mobility platform sold to Bird). Prior to that he spent ten years with McKinsey & Company. He is also a member of the advisory board of Wesang. Daniel Schustermann_** has a degree in Business Administration from EBS, London. After graduating from university, Mr. Schustermann worked as a consultant for CMA Consult & Management International GmbH from March 2001 to September 2003. From October 2003 to April 2021, Mr. Schustermann was CEO of Schustermann & Borenstein GmbH and several subsidiaries, including Best Secret. In addition, Mr. Schustermann holds management positions for several investment companies, of which he is also a shareholder. Amir Borenstein_** studied economics in Toronto he has been in various positions at the company since 1987, including management positions since 2010 and as chief product officer from 2014 until April 2021. He is also President of Keren Hayessod South Germany.

Subsubsection Title: Marian Gradl-Schikora studied Management Studies in London, and started working in 2000 for Schustermann
Subsubsection Text: & Borenstein as a freelance advisor. In 2007, Marian was a founding member of Beset Secret GmbH and stated as the managing director. In 2012 he was appointed the managing director of the Schustermann & Borenstein Group, a position held until June 2021.

Subsubsection Title: Cheryl Potter has a degree in Biochemistry from the University of Liverpool and is a Chartered Accountant. She
Subsubsection Text: is currently Chair of Level 20, a not-for-profit focused on getting more women into senior roles in the private equity industry. She joined Permira in 1999, becoming a partner in 2005 and retiring from the partnership at the end of 2019. During her time at Permira she lead the Global Consumer Team and the London office. She also served on the firm’s Executive Committee and the Compensation and Partnership Committee. During her time at Permira Cheryl served as a Non-Executive Director on the boards of Allegro, Birthdays, Dr Martens, Gala Coral, Homebase, Iglo, Maxeda and Best Secret. Cheryl is Founding Patron of Women Supporting Women (part of The Prince’s Trust) and a member of Tick Tock, a fundraising committee for Great Ormond Street Hospital. Prior to joining Permira, Cheryl worked at Royal Bank Development Capital and at Arthur Andersen. In 2021, the expenses for remuneration of the corporate management amounted to €4.5 million and for termination benefits amounted to €3.8 million and the expenses for remuneration of the advisory board amounted to €0.4 million.

Subsection Title: Further Information about the Managing Directors
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer’s Shareholders’ Meetings take place at least once a year. Each of the shares carries one vote at the Shareholders’ Meeting. There are no restrictions on voting rights of the shares of the Issuer. Unless mandatory provisions of the German Limited Liability Company Act or the Articles of Association state otherwise, Shareholders’ Meeting resolutions are passed with a simple majority of the votes cast. Subject to certain prerequisites and exemptions, certain significant matters set forth in the Management Board Rules of Procedure shall not be taken by the managing directors without having obtained the prior approval of the shareholders of the Issuer. Such significant matters include (i) selling, leasing, transferring, licensing or otherwise disposing of or purchasing, leasing, licensing or otherwise acquiring any shares or other interest in material businesses or in material undertakings; (ii) incorporating or liquidating any subsidiary undertaking or branch, or effect any change of legal form, hive-up, hive-down, merger, spinoff, amalgamation, demerger, corporate reconstruction or group reorganization, if the effect would have a material impact on the BestSecret Group; (iii) redeeming or repurchasing any shares; (iv) issuing any shares, or other equity, convertible or debt interest or securities, including pursuant to the creation of derivative securities; (v) amending or otherwise altering the annual budget that has been approved by the shareholders of the Issuer or taking any action inconsistent therewith; (vi) giving notice of or proposing any resolution to wind up any BestSecret Group entity, filing or making any petition, application, notice or filing for insolvency, bankruptcy, receivership, moratorium or suspension of payments or similar procedure or for the appointment or intended appointment of an administrator or liquidator or provisional liquidator or invite any person to appoint an administrative receiver or administrator or do anything similar or analogous to the aforementioned matters in any jurisdiction, in each case except where mandatorily required by applicable law; (vii) refinancing any of the indebtedness provided under the financing documents or effect any recapitalization or repatriation transaction; and (viii) granting any share-related incentive or establishing any share-related incentive scheme (whether legally binding or not) for directors and/or employees of any BestSecret Group company or vary any such scheme which has been established. 140 -----
